RATING: 10
Building your engine in this game is so much fun. There are so many different strategies that you can try, and the cards really dictate the course of the game. I would say that drafting is a must. 

Solo gameplay is great. CO-OP we played 12 generations with 12 starting income and the need to terraform completely. That was a lot of fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good fun, nice mix of card play, tile laying and resource production.

Lovely production quality (apart from the player boards which are flimsy and impractical), beautiful artwork on the cards and board.  It all looks very attractive.

Our 4 player game took us about 4 hours but everyone was very absorbed and didn't notice the time pass.  We played 4 player again (4 hours again) and that time I felt it went on a bit long really and was glad when it ended.

There were three things I didn't like so much.  The main thing I wasn't so keen on was that you might have spent some time developing your position towards a particular bonus/milestone only to have another player take the third and final slot, which means that your effort was wasted. 

I also didn't like the "Most science" award which obliged me to keep looking closely at all the cards all the other players had played, to see if I could succeed at it.  With small icons on lots of cards placed some way from me I had to keep leaning over the board to scrutinize what my opponents had played.  A bit tiresome.

And in both games I've been a recipient of the minor "take that" type of event in which another player plays an event card and chooses which player loses 3 or even 6 plants. If your plant production is only 1 per round it's a bit frustrating to have your efforts arbitrarily ruined by a random event.

Overall I enjoyed the game and would have scored it a 9 without the niggles mentioned above.

Tip: keep your player board some distance in front of you.  The board is slippery and the marker cubes you place on it are easily scattered by a passing sleeve.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.79
After 3 games I can conclude that I very much like this game. It has everything I like in a game: huge pool of different cards, engine building, good amount of player interaction, area control and blocking others...

There are a few things that I don't like, but they don't affect gameplay - graphic design could have been better and the player board... is not just ugly, but the UX is just plain bad. Markers can be bumped, marking your production over 10 is just clunky. It should have been a lot better.

Regarding the gameplay, I can see that it may be possible that this game could suffer from "bad hand drawn" (as any other card driven game) but we are still to see if that has that much influence since you can mitigate bad draws in lots of ways.

For now, this is a solid 9 for me. One of the top games on my shelf. I hope it stays that way.

We've tried it with:
2 players - good
4 players - fantastic

RATING: 9
6/27/2017 Update: I've now played the game several more times.  Due to the necessity of drafting to make the game fair, it does tend to take 3.5-4 hours to play. I admit I tend to freeze up a bit and the game might move faster with people who a) know cards well and b) aren't prone to AP. That said, I love this game. I appreciate the strategy a lot more than when I first played it and am thoroughly enjoying developing synergies between corporations & cards. It's also surprisingly interactive: although direct attacks are rare, there is a lot of blocking that can happen, and another player's actions can greatly affect the profitability of your action at certain points in the game. It'd be a perfect 10 if not for the length issue (..it does always feel too long, for some reason) and if the components were better. Specifically, the player mats are easy to damage (even just by putting them not carefully enough in the box) and really need to be double-layered with indents to place cubes on. Every time I play this game, the cubes get knocked over, often several times per game. If it wasn't for those two things, it'd be an absolute 10.
--
One play so far. Wonderful game - lived up to my expectations. I don't know if it's truly all that unique, but there's plenty of strategy, many feasible strategies, and fun card synergies. My only concern was that for a teaching game, it took us almost five hours. I don't know why exactly - maybe we all took too much time to think, maybe the rules explanation was unusually long, maybe because it was so long until anyone built greenery, but the long playtime makes it a more niche audience game for me. I enjoyed it thoroughly and never felt bored or like it was actually 'too' long at all, but it was certainly a surprise given the time on the box.

RATING: 6
2 plays / 3 players

LIKE: An enormous amount of unique cards and the cards are thematically fun, from asteroids to amoebas. Lots of combos to discover, and a possibility to build a big engine. Some interaction when racing towards objectives before others, creating some tension. I liked hanging on to powerful cards that could be used later.

DISLIKE: Iconography overload and tiny text on cards. It took me a while to understand the flow of the game. It takes one entire play to digest the different cards and how they work together. Difficult to directly slow another player down. The player mats are fiddly. The game plays on the long side, which turns me off.

OVERALL: A fun card-driven, engine building game. We draft cards each round, which increases playtime. Sifting through cards and trying to figure out combos is the game. So therefore, the more you know the cards, the better you do. This game keeps my interest for now, but I am finding it too long.

RATING: 6
My initial impression on Terraforming Mars was positive. Relatively good looking with an interesting theme. Symbology was a bit daunting and we needed a few rounds of play before we began to understand what was really going on. The rules are not the most intuitive ones but not the worst either.

Basically you are just trying to build up your resource production by buying cards so that you can buy victory points by playing further cards, constructing buildings or by terraforming the planet. There is some competition for certain milestones awarding VPs for the first player reaching the milestone or for having the most of something at the end of the game. The meat of the game is in choosing your strategy and setting up your engine for it. Which cards to play and in which order, is the question. 

After the game I felt like I could play again. However, there is one major concern I have about Terraforming Mars... The game does not have a fixed duration. Instead it is on the players' responsibility to push the game to the end. And my worrying observation is that the mechanics do not necessarily encourage working towards triggering the game end. This might make the game drag unnecessarily long which is never good. Another negative about the game is that after a while the necessary information becomes scattered all over the table which slows down the play when you are squinting to read the symbols on other players' cards (which will be many). 

One more thing that is not necessarily a negative but in my opinion does not make the game any better is the "take that" cards in the game. Sure, in the end game they serve a purpose if you need to prevent someone from ending the game too soon but in early to mid game these cards can be quite devastating for the victim's playing experience. They also slow down the game even further.

But in the end I found the game ok, although I have my concerns that some sessions may be very long and frustrating.

RATING: 9
This is a great engine-building game, where you have to raise temperature, oxygen level and sea level on Mars, by building cities and green areas. The engine building consists in playing different types of cards in your area: green cards for one time bonuses, blue cards for extra actions and red cards which give you instant resources. The downside of this, that besides the main board there is only a minimum interaction between the players, and getting familiar with the huge amount of cards and finding out the optimum chains can also take up time. Overall it is good game: easy to learn and fun to play.

RATING: 5
Dec - :d10-5:

1st play: Really an enjoyable game.  The cards and actions are thematic, if a bit random.  Mars is the new-hotness theme and this game does it well.  I enjoyed the thematic text on the cards and although it played loosely with the science, it felt close enough to be believable. I think the game would be improved by drafting as it feels a bit multi-player solitaire without that.  I think if drafting is not used, then there needs to be a way to increase number of cards drawn, or at least be able to spend money to cycle cards in some way.

2nd play: Not nearly as good as the first playthrough.  The length was way too long, vast differences in corporate powers and drafting helped some, but not too much with the random cards feel.  There is almost no interaction between players other than occasional comets which you just lob at whoever has the most plants saved up.  These comets can be crushing if you've saved up enough plants to set up a combo, all the way to meaningless if no one has any plant life or if turn order is such that they can spend plants before you get a turn.  The theme is still amazing but that's about it.

Note: This is one of few games where the plays are so different that I'm not exactly sure how to rate it.  I am willing to bet there's a good game in here, but the card selection mechanism bugged me through both plays and I really didn't feel like there was much interaction.  The theme is so good that I want to try it again, but I'm dreading a 4 hour long slog like my last playthrough.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Terraforming Mars has been a BGG darling since its release. Usually, this means I'm going to either love or hate the game (BGG top 100 is just a dumb popularity contest, and popular is not the same as great). In this case, I found myself on the supportive side of the game.

The gameplay consists of building your tableau from resources by paying for cards. Like Race for the Galaxy and other tableau builders, these card contribute to some kind of future endeavor until finally the game ends. This part of the game seems really nice and tight. It's enjoyable to have those extra blue cards for alternate actions, green cards for nice traditional passives, and reds for expensive but powerful one time effects.

The board is where the game first starts to show signs of design neglect. There just isn't a whole lot of interesting stuff going on, on Mars...the titular character of the game. With only 3 basic tiles and a rare sprinkling of a few unique tiles, the board looks very homogenous during play. At the end of the game, barely anything has changed on the surface, due to the weird placement rules. It's understandable that the sparesness represents that your only goal is the bare minimum of terraforming, however it does make the board feel like an incredibly waste of space (and time).

Obviously like any randomized card-based game, the cards can be really devilish to one player at the table. In this game, if that's you, you're not having a good time. Be aware of this going in. On the flipside, any player who happens to get insanely good early card drafts is going to be nigh-unseatable for most of the game.

One criticism I have for the scoring system is how absolutely required the awards et al are. You cannot skip being the first (or most) at something in the game, otherwise you miss out on 5 VP which is quite a lot. This is a problem since people tend to rush the first-to-do-whatever conditions for the guaranteed VPs and it's like a game of musical chairs in some cases, where you know one player is never going to win but they have to remain playing under the obviously false pretense that they could pull some magical 5 VP out of their ass that no one else can.

The card quality is pretty poor (couldn't even play without sleeves) but the board looks very nice. Card art is hit or miss and while I can tolerate the card UI, as a designer I feel that it's obtuse with its early 2000's internet gradients.

Despite its negative points, Terraforming mars is a very tactile and satisfying game to play. When you're done, you can look at your tableau (not necessarily the board) and feel like you really accomplished all those projects and contributed to bettering humanity. Due to the simulationist feel that doesn't make TOO many sacrifices to gameplay, I have to recommend this one. Maybe not as heavily as its popularity suggests, but nevertheless it's enjoyable.

In the 2400s, mankind begins to terraform the planet Mars. Giant corporations, sponsored by the World Government on Earth, initiate huge projects to raise the temperature, the oxygen level, and the ocean coverage until the environment is habitable. In Terraforming Mars, you play one of those corporations and work together in the terraforming process, but compete for getting victory points that are awarded not only for your contribution to the terraforming, but also for advancing human infrastructure throughout the solar system, and doing other commendable things.

RATING: 6
Terraforming Mars does have excellent fidelity to its theme; players are rewarded for warming and oxygenating the environment, and for placing lakes.    These activities also act as a clock, with the game ending when the planet is inhabitable.  There are alternative strategies around mining, settlement building, power generation and the greening of the planet. 

The game's engine is tableau building and as tableau builders tend to be, it is pretty solitaire-ish.  Interaction is limited to some minor take thatery.  Stop blubbing, it is minor.  As with other turn-based tableau builders, there is quite a lot of downtime.  In the one game I have played it seemed as though money just wasn't tight enough and the end game really dragged as those capable of raising the temperature instead chased the leader.  The hex map of the surface of Mars serves little purpose beyond corralling the players' developments.

The artwork has come in for some criticism; it is somewhat uneven.  Production quality is decent.

RATING: 6
I love the theme of this game, the emphasis on raising the temperature and oxygen levels, and the forest, ocean and city building.  I give these elements a 9 of 10.   I also appreciate the "labor of love" feel of this game, crafting (and presumably balancing) all the cards, etc.   

Having said that, for my gamer tastes, Terraforming Mars did not provide a particularly interesting or compelling gaming experience.  Virtually the entire game consisted of collecting and playing cards within the confines of my private player tableau.  Then, after we had built up our huge collections of cards, the game ended, and we tallied up the points.  During our game, the other players showed virtually no interest in my cards, and likewise, I showed no interest in their cards.  All in all, Terraforming Mars felt like it was about 95% multiplayer solitaire.

Admittedly, there are a lot of cards to read and think about, and as such, there are a lot of card combinations to ponder and potentially test out in future plays.  So, yes, if you like card combo games with lots of re-ployability, this could be a good game for you.  Unfortunately, I am not a card combo gamer, and I prefer much more player interaction in my games.  Having little interest in playing the game again, have to give it a 6.

RATING: 5
Terraforming Mars, the game that takes Race For The Galaxy as a starting point, removes the phases, adds a board and 4-6x the play time.

I wanted to like this game.  Race isn't my favourite, but I like it for what it is, and I hoped TM would improve upon that while making even more of a game out of it.  Unfortunately, it's almost the opposite.  You have a game with all the same problems as Race (that your strategy is mostly dictated by the cards you are dealt, and that you have very little control over what those cards are), but without the interesting phase mechanisms (this'll be hit or miss depending on the person, but I think phases are the best part of Race and without them TM has almost zero player interaction), and takes a whole lot longer to play out.  
It just isn't worth it.  I understand what people like about this game, but it's so much more fluff than substance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game that's absolutely steeped in the near-future science of colonising the Red Planet. Richly themed science games are rare, and most of them (looking at Phil Eklund) are more simulation than game. The game play here is rich, engrossing, and as well-oiled a euro tableau building game as you could ask for. Interaction with other players is indirect but present, either racing to complete milestones or jockeying for position on the planet's surface.

Hearing about the take-that elements on some of the cards (e.g., "remove 2 plants from another player") was a worry . I'm quite sensitive to the issue and consider it a design flaw in a game that isn't explicitly about conflict. In practice, it's usually no more than a minor annoyance. You could even make the case that it's a useful disincentive to stockpiling resources. If it still annoys you, an easy fix might be to house rule that "remove X" effects are equally distributed among different players rather than targeting only one.

The criticism about terrible art I think is much ado about nothing. I appreciate art, and found the art on the cards perfectly nice looking and appropriate to the theme. There are plenty of games with BAD art, and I don't think this is one of them. The symbols on the cards are clear, sensible, and always well explained with text.

RATING: 6.5
Sorry, German Review, because I already wrote it up for a German friend:

Terraforming Mars ist ein gutes Spiel, wenn auch vielleicht etwas overhyped. Im Prinzip gefällt es mir sehr gut. Es hat allerdings zwei Nachteile: Zum einen ist die Qualität der Komponenten wirklich nicht gut. Schade für so ein teures Spiel, aber man kann damit leben. Der andere, gravierende Minuspunkt ist, dass es eine ganze Menge von Karten gibt, die destruktive Effekte für wählbare Mitspieler haben, z.B. sowas haben wie "Klaue einem beliebigen Mitspieler X Ressourcen". Oft auch Ressourcenproduktion, was für den Betroffenen gerade am Anfang des Spiels noch deutlich schlimmer ist. Mein größtes Problem damit ist, dass ich mir überhaupt einen Spieler aussuchen muss/kann, den es trifft. Ich will einfach nicht entscheiden müssen, wen von meinen Mitspielern ich "am wenigsten mag". Das hätte man auch anders designen können. Dazu kommt noch, dass dieser Wert "X" in manchen Fällen gar nicht mal klein ist, in einigen Fällen höher als die Produktion dieser Ressource in einer gesamten Runde. Im schlimmsten Fall hat man sich seinen Zug schon genau durchgeplant, wird beklaut und kann dann nur noch passen und erst in der nächsten Runde wieder etwas machen. Sehr schade. Ich hätte dem Spiel sicherlich eine 8 gegeben, vielleicht sogar 8.5, wenn der Designer das besser hinbekommen hätte. Diese destruktiven Spielelemente beeinflussen mein Spielgefühl allereings so gravierend, dass es bei einer 6.5 bleiben musste.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Amazing Euro game with a scientific twist. We have all been hearing about this game for months, so there isnt much I can write here that has not already been written, however, based on the fact I gave it a 9 means I quite enjoy it. 

Another gamer in our group recently purchased Terra Mystica, and after a few play through of that, we found we really enjoyed those mechanics, so we were hoping this would offer some of the same which it does. I have played 3 times now, and really look forward to it hitting the table a lot more in the future.


Solo Play - As an intro to teach others, I  attempted it once, and I didn't have a great grasp on the rules, so it went pretty bad. I look forward to playing again with a full grasp on the rules.

3 Player game - We all played with the beginner corp and no advanced cards. The game went slow and we missed a few (major) rules. All three of us really enjoyed it and looked forward to playing again.

4 Player game - We have done one 4 player game so far. It went well, 3 of the players had played once and one was new. The 3 selected our corporations and the newbie used the beginner corp as per the instructions. We used all advanced corp cards as well, which made a huge difference. The game went well but dragged...4+ hours.

Pros - Too many to name, but the biggest that comes to mind is the theme of it all. There are real reasons behind what you're doing, when you do it. The mechanics are solid, but the theme makes sense and when the two work together, it really shines.

Cons - the art is not very consistent. It seems to be photo-realistic in some areas, and cartoonish in others. The player and resource pieces are too small and light. This would be fine if they just sat, but there is a lot of movement and a lot of them. It can be very difficult to keep tabs on them etc. The length is a bit off from whats on the box. Of the 3 games I've played, the average length is about 3 hrs. I suppose it could get down to around 2.5 if you really pushed the standard projects, but 90 mins?...I don't think that's possible for our group.

Calling those things "cons" is tough because its like knocking Super Mario Bros. for poor graphics. It all comes down to game play, theme & mechanics, which this has nailed.

Terraforming Mars is an amazing game, and is an instant classic. Get it.

RATING: 9
Only played once so far, 2-player. Surprisingly easy to learn despite the rulebook being slightly opaque in places, and the huge amount of iconography.

We started with normal corporations, rather than the beginner, too.

This is one slick game, with mechanics that just about purr. We'll definitely be trying corporation era next game, and I would like to try card drafting because it very much felt like luck was on the other player's side. I, on the other hand, never got any Power or Space cards, and couldn't get much going in terms of smooth engines until very late in the game. But I did get Phobos and Ganymede, which my opponent was desperate, so that felt nice ;)

Still, it was challenging, engaging, and extremely thematic. Really looking forward to another game.

Will agree with others those - those player mats are complete crap for the game's price.

RATING: 9
A thematic euro, with a huge deck of unique and thematically appropriate cards. Playing this game does feel like you are playing a depoliticized version of Kim Stanley Robinson's Mars trilogy, with mining projects, building mines, boreholes, lakes, forest and cities and even terraforming the Galilean moons and sending an interstellar expedition.

It's not without its flaws. It is somewhat thin on player interaction beyond take that cards and some light blocking. More problematic is the achievements and milestones, this game's 6-cost developments. They feel so arbitrary and artificial. I can understand how they didn't want to put them in the deck, but could have had their own deck, with more thematic tie-in?

RATING: 7.5
I really enjoy the theme and arc of this game but the combined graphic/game design  issues will likely get in the way of me acquiring the game. 

On the graphic design side: the game is problematic without using a game "frame" accessory to lock in your production and resources. One nudge of the table and the accounting becomes a mess. Also not a fan of the inconsistent art direction. 

On the game design side: generally speaking some of the chrome gets in the way of the game while also making the game longer than feels absolutely necessary. While the chrome makes the story arc interesting, it creates problematic cross table information tracking. 

While the game design choices wouldn't stop me from buying the game, the graphic design choices will. Without a "deluxe" reimagining and republishing (along the lines of a Scythe production), I won't be picking this up. I'll gladly play on someone else's copy who's made the extra investment in the required tracking accessories. A deluxe version might rate at 8.0-8.5 for me.

RATING: 7
It's an enjoyable game which can really suffer due to high amount of randomness and can outstay its welcome. 

Lots of things to like, but games can be pretty long (around 3 hours no problem) and if you are out of luck, the whole game from start to finish can feel really frustrating, which is a big problem for a game of this length. Especially for a euro where you want to plan you strategy. In TM you are trying to get the best out of the cards you get, instead of actively trying to form a strategy (which might be possible if you are getting the cards you need, but with the amount of cards in the game, it's not reliable). 
Drafting might mitigate a bit of randomness, but can bring other problems, like lengthening an already long game or 'hate drafting'. My 2nd game was a 3 hour long exercise in frustration from the very start to the end. Left a sour taste in my mouth, will see after future play(s).

Another problem of the game is the fact that there doesn't seem to be much choice. Every turn it's pretty obvious what you should play from the cards you've been dealt, you simply play the best cards you get and hope they'll be good enough. The only limit becomes the money you can spend.

RATING: 8
Lassan kezdek hozzászokni, hogy totál nyelvfüggő játékokat is kiadnak magyarul, sőt már szinte mindent, ami a fősodorba tartozik. A Mars az eddigi legörvendetesebb magyarítások egyike. Sajnos a szabályban vannak hibák, némelyik elég durva, de ez sem szegte kedvem, bizakodóan álltam hozzá.

Nekünk 3 fővel 3 óra volt tisztán, de egy szólót szerintem simán lenyomok 40-50 percen belül, majd ki is próbálom hamarosan remélem. A szabály nem vészes, 20-30 perc alatt elmondható.

Sok helyen hallottam, hogy vékonyak a kártyák. Ez igaz, de kártyavédőzve nem zavaró.

RATING: 6
Played it once, a 3-player game. We felt it was an ok game, yet it overstayed its welcome. We played the shorter variant with advanced corporations, no drafting. So almost the simplest game, apart from the corporations and the initial purchasing of cards (which we did). Yeah... my fears about limited interaction turned out to be right. There's a big emphasis on your own engine optimization. There *is* interaction though, and it potentially may be significant with more experienced players: on the map, fights for milestones, awards or final opportunities for terraforming. We just felt that most of the time we weren't really interested in what cubes other players pushed left and right on their player boards. Interaction came close to the end. However the game lasted more than 2 hours, so we were a bit tired towards the end. Then we felt like there was a luck of draw. Could be fixed by the official drafting variant, but at the same time the game would drag even longer. Overall we think there are better games with limited interaction that we can play in shorter time, which we enjoy more at the same time: The Castles of Burgundy, Bruges and Suburbia came to our minds, they kind of scratch the same itch for us (although imo Suburbia has nice level of interaction, but it has that tableau building thing).
With that said, it's a decent game, but there are so many better ones, so it's up for trade.

RATING: N/A
06.01.03.03 Leerer Karton
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terraforming Mars is one of the more thematic eurogames out there.

Mechanically it has three distinct parts:
- card-driven tableau-building, with more than 200 distinct unique cards (each with its unique artwork!)
- tile-placement where each tile position matters for final scoring
- resource-management, with lots of different - and thematically meaningful - resources

The game flows very smoothly, with a drafting phase, then players alternate in taking 1-2 actions, with a small production/upkeep at turn end.
It is very "combolicious", with players trying to perform medium/long term strategies, while adapting tactically to new cards and moves mad by the opponents.

It has some flaws, though: some may find the luck a bit too much (but I definitely love this kind of tableau-building: it reminds me a bit of Race for the Galaxy), and the graphic design could be a bit less confusing...

Anyway, Terraforming Mars is one of the best games of 2016, and perhaps one of the best around...

RATING: 7
Initial Impression: This game is a tableau builder with a player controlled endgame trigger. The heart of the game is the large stack of cards, most of which seem to be unique. The game ramps up slowly as players set up their resource engines. 6 separate resources must be taken into account and many combinations will reap VPs. There a set collection aspect mechanism, as most cards have suits which may combo other cards. The game also includes a tile-laying mechanism which may net a player extra resources and some endgame scoring. This is a game that I enjoyed playing but am still unsure of what all the hype is about. The game doesn't bring anything new to the table but the mechanisms integrate well together.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Non-drafting version feels too random for my tastes. Drafting version is better, but can play way too long. Under either variant, the combination of the basic actions and the incremental efficiency gains you receive from the cards results in a sorting exercise that doesn't justify the play time of this game. 

The card play, in my opinion, could have gone through more development. My mind keeps going to other games that implement aspects of the card play better. For example, Race for the Galaxy includes similar decisions and plays in a much shorter play time. Pax Porifiriana, Nations and Agricola, among others, are better as games where each play uses a subset of cards -- the resulting combinations are more varied in those games, and a player needs to compete against the players and the game itself, which pushes a player to stay apace of the power curve. In this game, you are given lots of options and sort through them to incrementally gain power, but its primarily happenstance if the presented options push you along its intended power curve. I think this game would have been better if the cards were split into different decks/ages, like in Through The Ages and Nations. 

Perhaps the card drafting should have been integrated more closely to the turn structure, like in Ginkgopolis. The card drafting often makes this game drag on too long. Perhaps there should have been a modification or two to lessen the playtime when certain game states/play styles are present. This game simply should not go more than 2 hours, and it often does--especially if players refuse to move up the various end-game triggering tracks. Perhaps there should have been a way to combat runaway leaders aside from the take that cards. The take that cards don't play that badly in practice, but seem out of place if compared to other player-interactive euro games (and the high number of those cards that simply destroy plants points to a band-aid in design). In the end, when you combine the average card play mechanisms, the overlong play time, the sub-par components and the amateurish card art/design, you're left with a game that, charitably, is overpriced versus competing games. 

It has a couple of positives, as its fairly accessible (true medium in weight, fairly easy to teach and understand) and it has a good theme. But the theme isn't enough to get me to play this over other games. Maybe in a couple of years they'll iterate a second edition (Terraforming Mars: A New Story of Terraforming). The concepts have so much potential and this is one of the most thematic euro-style games that I've played. But, from my point of view, the current implementation is only average. 

Edit, Nov. 2017: Played this again after staying away from it for a few months. My original opinions haven't changed for the most part. It plays too long for what it is and many, many games do aspects of its game play better. To add another to the list of games mentioned above, First Class is another that has better game play. Similar to TM, First Class throws out a bunch of engine-building options for you to sort through, but does so in a way that provides more tense and interactive decisions. First Class also plays in a fraction of the time. 

I do want to revise two things from my original opinions, though. One, the more I play it, the less thematic Terraforming Mars feels. The theme is a welcome change of pace from typical euro fare and the production shows that more effort than normal was taken to bring the theme out. The particularity of the theme and the effort to bring it out, however, distracts from the pasted-on nature of the theme. This collection of mechanisms could be easily used without much modification in another theme (e.g., building competing kingdoms, competing/warring factions in a solar system). Mars just happens to be the chosen setting for the collection of mechanisms. Second, the take that cards are a slight problem in the 2 player game. At higher play counts, the cost of the take that cards are such that playing the card is the right move only limited circumstances (e.g., to bring a clear leader back to the pack). In a 2 player game, the primary purpose of the take that cards--to combat a runaway leader--matters less in deciding whether to play the card.

- Varied

RATING: 9.5
I generally abhor space-themed games for reasons I cannot fathom but this game is an exception. It's a solid thematic engine-builder that may feel like a multiplayer solitaire at times. This game grew on me with repeated plays, I think it was a decent game the first time I've tried but thoroughly enjoyed my subsequents playthrough once I'm more familiar with the concept and cards. It's essentially an Euro game, so there's subtle interactions with your opponents that I only realized later on. The game length varies depending on the players, you need to realise when to stop engine-building and focusing on points and to end the game instead. I can see this game gets even more fun with repeated plays. 

Finally I get to try drafting variant (3/9/17) with two experienced players. The game is so much better as engines are built even more efficiently and there's less luck involved. I will always play with drafting variant if possible from now onwards.

RATING: 7.25
Terraforming Mars is an engine building, card combo game that keeps you engaged with the decisions on timing your actions, spending your resources and playing your cards. The interaction between players is sufficient to not make it multi-player solitaire, but if card combo games are not your thing; stay away.

The terraforming theme is well integrated. The ambience of the game gives you the feeling of creating oceans, increasing the oxygen levels and lowering the temperature while maintaining the tension of accomplishing these tasks before your fellow players.

Component wise; the player boards could have been designed better as a bump in the table could send your indicators flying and ruin the stats of your progress. There are now plenty of aftermarket solutions to this problem, but these add an unforeseen cost. Still, a keeper.

RATING: 8
It feels sort of like Race for the Galaxy with a lot of cards plus a map with tile placement and a bunch of resource management. Players are all working to raise the temperature on Mars, increase the oxygen level and add water. Like Race, you build a tableau of cards that provide benefits and symbols which can stack and unlock other options. Players draft the cards and pay for those that they keep. On the map, players build cities and plant trees and establish oceans to score points and make Mars more habitable. Replayability with this game seems strong as there are so many cards and multiple paths to victory. Players do start with a corporation card too that begins their path.

I will certainly play this more and I see it everywhere, so I have no doubt it will be easy to get into a game.

RATING: 4

RATING: 9.5
Terraforming Mars is one of the best strategy games to come out of 2016. It's incredibly thematic, highly engaging, and somewhat interactive but not to the point of frustration. I've also found it to be incredibly balanced. In a two player game I played, my opponent got off to a much quicker start, but I overcame him halfway through and looked to be dominantly in the lead. However when we counted our scores, I had only won by 4 points in a game where we each had well over 100.

Update 5/17/2017: Bumping my rating up to a half a point after playing this game solo. It had a lot of the intensity and strategy from a normal game, but the mindset is a bit different as you are racing to get all 3 terraforming goals completed in 14 rounds. The rules recommend you gauge how you did based on your points at the end of round 14, but I found I prefer to see how few rounds I can complete the game in. It's one of the best true multiplayer game solo variants I have ever played.

RATING: 7
There are some enjoyable mechanics here, including getting a ton of cubes at the beginning of the turn with which to buy cards, the fact that everyone is contributing to the end-game timer which is neat, and that fact that you won't see even half of the available cards in a single play, much like Agricola, and it accelerates nicely towards that end. However, it is a looong game, can feel like VP salad, the board state won't vary much game-to-game as many of the spots are pre-programmed, and the player cards don't really match the quality of the rest of the components. Maybe most disheartening was the loss of narrative throughout the game. Mainly, you will be playing cards, the cards will do something once, and then you will forget about it for the rest of the game. When you play 30+ cards in a single game, it is hard for your corporation to develop an identity which really detracts from the theme and makes it a cube-shuffling exercise. I will still play it at least a few more times for it's good traits, but would not try to sell the hobby with it.

I can see why Terraforming Mars is popular. As an engine builder, it allows players to create a suggestive display of originality. Furthermore, all of this is done within a theme that is quite relevant today. Despite being a Euro, there are moments in which Terraforming Mars feels cooperative because of the general direction that players are taking together. Sadly, its not a very good two-player game: sometimes the four-card draw tends to play itself and it can potentially be a pretty uneventful 2 hours especially when the table interaction is low and the terraform rating track is constantly reminding you that you are losing and there is nothing you can do about it.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is very well designed and balanced "engine builder", where your heat, energy, plant and other resource generating capacity slowly but steadily increases, allowing you to complete the overriding group goal of "Terraforming Mars".

Game play consists of players spending their wealth on events (asteroid impacts), buildings (ore mines) and capabilities (improved heat generation) that take the form of cards that are drawn from a random deck. The deck is generally larger than needed for a single play through, so each game played may have a slightly different feel, or difficulty, as some cards are unavailable through different play through sessions.

Once the planet has been "fully terraformed", the winner is determined by essentially figuring out who contributed the most during the whole process. There are points available by activating (via purchase) milestones [mid game achievements] and awards [end game comparisons], and various buildings and events earn small amounts of points along the way. In addition, cities score points for each vegetation sector that neighbors it, and vegetation sectors are also worth a single point each.

This game supports a single player variant, which plays very much like the multiplayer version, but is more of a race against the clock, as you have only so many generations (14) to complete the terraforming of the planet. A score is calculated, which can be used to compare your performances between solo runs of the game.  The ability to win, in solo play, is mostly a factor of what cards become available during the game; Experience, however, makes it easier to win, no matter what, as you become more comfortable and efficient at creating the best terraforming engine possible.

RATING: 10
Terraforming Mars! Just what the box says. What a great theme! I developed my love of reading from Asimov, Heinlein, and Bradbury, and speculation about what we will find, or develop, on Mars figured largely in their works. This game relates totally to my long standing love affair with the mysterious Red Planet! 

Card/action selection to build a terraforming engine better than your opponents, yet at the same time you are cooperating to make Mars survivable. Recognizable traces of Race For the Galaxy here, but based more firmly on science or believable extrapolations of scientific theory. What an extensive job of research went into the mechanics in this game.

Watching the run-throughs and finally playing my first game confirmed my enthusiasm for this game. It is a bit random in the card drawing which can be devastating or extremely helpful in the early going.so I expect to explore some drafting variants.. But so far, a definite keeper!

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
Es un juego de cartas, a pesar de que existe un tablero central y cada jugador tiene su propio tablero. TODO son las cartas. Cada jugador, usa su tablero para almacenar recursos y controlar los niveles deproducción de las materias (dinero, acero, titanio, plantas, energía y calor).
Cada turno (generación), consiste en recibir unas cartas y decidir si te quedas con ellas (pagando 3 por cada una) y después se suceden las rondas de juego. En cada ronda, cada jugador puede hacer una o dos acciones, o pasar. Una vez que pasa queda fuera.

Al final hay una fase de producción y comienza una nueva generación. El juego continua hasta que se consigue terraformar marte, elevando los parámetros fundamentales (se construyen todos los océnamos, se sube el nivel de oxígeno a 14 y la temperatura a 8ºC).

Es un juego de hacer combos y están muy bien pensadas las cartas (trae muchísimas, más de 200). Además, cada jugador juega con una de muchas corporaciones posibles, lo que da rejugabilidad. 

Muy absorvente. Una delicia para jugones. Para no jugones lo veo dificil, porque hay mucho símbolo, y muchos parámetros que dependen a su vez de otros, y puede hacer pensar bastante.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
At the outset I want to make a few philosophical comments based on reviewing previously written comments and criticisms of this game.  This is the second time I have written a review of any game on this site.  Having read reviews about this game reinforces my opinion on just how fickle human nature is.  Some reviewers have ascribed 3's and 4's and 5's based on "randomness," "chance based," "asymmetry" - to exclude the element of "luck" is to remove 50% of what life experience on planet Earth (or Mars, or anywhere in the known universe for that matter) is all about.  Fundamentally our very existence as individuals (just the biochemistry of it all), as a species, this planet itself, the fate of this planet, the potential for us to make another planet habitable, have as much to do with Divine Providence (yes even the writers of the US constitution included this language) as it does with strategic planning.  Terraforming Mars is a game where one must make the most of what the chaos of the universe has offered them.  
Secondly, other reviewers have criticized this game for providing nothing "Novel," of generating a mechanic that "will fade in a month or two on the Hotness scale once another game comes out" - these comments reflect the intellectual depth of the people who authored them.  At the risk of discrediting myself and to emphasize what I'm about to say - in one specific important dimension this game rivals Twilight Struggle, Dominant Species, or any other of the like - it has great authenticity - the mechanic of the game has an impact the matches the theme of the game.  Great educational value.  For example, when a player raises the Temperature to 0 degrees Celsius, they have the added bonus of creating a lake (given that frozen water within the soil will now melt and collect in low topographical points) which also triggers economical boosts to the Corporation that accomplished that - in other words affecting one metric in the ecosystem has Newtonian impact on other metrics.  Great from an educational perspective, wonderful portrayal of the interconnectesness of human actions on the environment. of the interconnectedness of temperature, oxygen, plant life, water abundance.  Twilight Struggle and Dominant Species also do a supreme job of matching game mechanic to their respective themes also.  
Third, other reviewers have criticized it for its theme.  Irrespective of whether a person likes space themed games or not, in order for a legitamite ruling of how well a game helps its players detach from the day to day and lose a sense of space and time getting "lost" in the experience and ultimately start daydreaming in the moment - Terraforming Mars does a stellar job of accomplishing just that - it is a space/economic/survival themed game and everyone of we five people who have played the game agreed that the game designers excelled in this department.  And as an aside to those nay sayers of space themed games - BEWARE THE UNCURIOUS.  In fact to be Human is also to wonder about the Heavens above and what lies beyond our green planet.  I am grateful to the game designers for generating such a power packed game that may be played in a reasonable time of two hours.  This game gets my Essen Vote for sure - certainly over Scythe or any of the other contenders
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
The game itself is very engaging and fun. I like the sheer number of cards and options within the game. It appears that there is a lot of replay-ability built in. Having the ability to start off with easy corporations, then adding in corporations that have their own abilities, and then adding the Corporate Era cards in later games makes for a nice way to start off learning the game and then 'expand' the game when you become more familiar.

I reduced the rating due to the quality of the components. The player mats and cardstock are very thin. The box insert is also thin. The sides that are supposed to hold the board above the other components was ripped even though the box itself shows no damage. Fortunately, all of the components for the game were not damaged. 

The resource management is very fiddly when using the resource allocation cubes. They can very easily be knocked out of position. If you are not constantly making sure you know exactly how much of each resource you are generating, or the number of resources you currently own, one bump of the table can mess up your entire game.

= Terraforming Mars: Hellas & Elysium

Terraforming Mars seems to be one of the hottest games out there right now. Honestly I don't think it deserves it. RATING: 10
I've played with 2, 4, and 5 players so I have no doubt that it's fun with three players as well. This is my favorite game that has come out this year (2016). The Corporate deck doesn't add too much more length to the five player game but it really makes the two player game a lot longer.

RATING: 10
There are so many reasons I shouldn't like Terraforming Mars. It is essentially an economic snowball game where the rich get richer, and since the ability to get richer hinges on... card draws, ahem, already we are treading on thin ice. There is very little chrome to the game. It is simply draw cards, buy them, play them, maybe buy things, repeat ad infiniutm. In this, the game hearkens back to titles of yore, almost mass market in its concepts and execution (cult favorite SolarQuest comes to mind).

I can understand why people might dislike this game. And yet... it fascinates me. It is addictive as hell. It is intense, and immersive. I can't see a day when I wouldn't want to play it. Card luck can be significant, especially with fewer players, so I do recommend always using the draft (a definite with two). This is the poster child for a game that is more than the sum of its parts. Love it or hate it, it is indelible.

RATING: 8
Really great card-driven game that does a nice job of "simulating" terraforming the planet. Decisions are interesting and competition can be fierce over board spaces and scoring goals. The player powers are just different enough to make each game feel a little different, but seem really balanced. 

A few things I don't like about the game: it's a little too easy to get stuff, and there are almost too many cards drawn and played every turn, such that by the end of the game I feel my player area is a total, incomprehensible mess of cards. The game is also very fiddly in the sheer number of resources you get: I wish the economy were a little more limited and the number of cards you can draw had been reduced (maybe something more along the line of Seasons). As it is, the game feels like you're winning the lottery every turn. Which is still fun, but it makes it a little too easy to do whatever you want.

RATING: 8.45
juegazo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I see a number of comparisons of Race for the Galaxy and Terraforming Mars; not to state the obvious, but Race for the Galaxy is a similar but clearly far superior game. But, you can't play Race *all* the time, and there are people in the world who for whatever misguided reason like Terraforming Mars but not Race :) Race also has the problem of punishing experience differentials pretty hard, and differentials are pretty easy to rack up, so that's sometimes not great. Still, as I say below, I think it's pretty clear Terraforming Mars isn't a long-term winner (unless the expansions really bring it in an unexpected way), even if it's a fine game-of-the-moment.
---
Docking the rating a point as the inevitable replayablity endpoint encroaches. I'm at 10 plays and it's getting pretty samey as it's clear there are a limited number of paths through the game. The Corporate Era may have better balance and be more interesting, but the once I played it just outstayed its welcome considerably. Still, will try that again, see if it gives the game some more life. 10 plays is not bad, but not enough to rate it an 8 on my scale :)
---
I haven't been super-impressed by the Corporate game. It adds length, the balance doesn't feel that great, and it adds a bunch of dead-end options (the game is still basically won or lost on greenery and/or cities, the corporate game just adds a bunch of stuff you can do that seems unwise). Because of the super-restricted start on the corporate game, there will sometimes be a point - often well over an hour before the game is actually over - when you know you just don't have the economy to be competitive but your kinda stuck watching the other players do cool stuff while you sit and struggle (Agricola has kinda the same issue - usually you know about 45 minutes from the end or so whose in it to win it and who'se just a spectator at that point).

Anyway, still enjoying it and this will probably easily hit 10-15 plays (unless I end up disliking the corporate game when that's the version everyone else wants to play), which is pretty great. But like Agricola, there is clearly a hard endpoint to the replayability.
---
I'm always a little surprised when the new hotness actually turns out to be something I like, but I've enjoyed Terraforming Mars quite a bit. They've put some effort into breathing life into the setting. The card deck seems pretty well balanced, and you'll see enough cards over the length of the game for some synergies to fall out. At 6-7 turns, the length is sensible, and it has a nice arc - a fairly long period of buildup followed by a flurry of action in the last two turns.

Top play tips: You need some points from the goals and awards to win. Pay for the standard projects to lock these in if you need to; they are a bunch of points. Don't let your corporation cause you to over-focus; none of the corporation powers are super-strong so don't let them blind you to other combos. With the game being as short as it is, turn-wise, don't neglect the option to stand pat for a turn and see what the next project draw brings. It's certainly not a power play, but if you're in a tricky spot and really just need more info, sometimes it can be better to punt.

Like Core Worlds, Terraforming Mars plays 5 but it makes the downtime a little tough, or even punishing in the wrong groups. Stick to 3-4 by preference.

The game this reminds me most of is actually Agricola. They're not very similar mechanically, but they both have the feel of playing the hand of cards you've been dealt and looking for efficiencies and synergies. Like Agricola, the interest of the game space is bounded by how often the card mix you see interests or surprises you. So I suspect this won't have a ton of long-term replayability (although I haven't played the full corporation game yet). But I suspect it has a while to go yet before I get bored of it :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My 7th 10 rating of all time out of about 1,500 total games played! 

I'm a fan of games where you get a selection of cards, and you make the best of what you get, trying to form some sort of engine out of them. This game has it in spades, with a huge number of cards, all of them unique! You're building cities, fostering wildlife, forming seas, founding corporation, starting energy plants, and a ton of other stuff, which all give you various resources and advantages.

As experienced gamers, we just went straight into the full deck of cards, which we really enjoyed. The recommendation for new players is to remove a bunch of cards which seem to have more of an economic/business focus, but I really thought they were interesting would always play with them, even though they make the game a bit longer.

I also really enjoyed that, while I was building an engine, my focus was able to change throughout the game due to all of the things going on. One engine got me to a certain point, at which point another engine became useful, and so on. So, it wasn't an engine building game where you got things up and running and then ran on auto-pilot. You could still find new twists and turns to explore, even as the game neared the end.

Overall, just a really cool game, and I really look forward to more of it!

Regarding the component quality, I've seen complaints, but I really don't get what the concern is. I thought everything was very nice. Yes, the player mats are card stock, but they just sit on the table in front of you and you never move them. Everything was of a quality I'd expect of a modern board game, so no complaints here, and any complaints you see are likely overblown.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
Based on 1 play with 5 players:

It's like someone made Race for the Galaxy into a full-length Eurogame. And hey, it works! The engine building feels great and comfortingly familiar. There's some minor racing/blocking aspects to the board, which work really well.

But I do have one problem: this is a 2 hour strategy game where you can get fucked by luck of the draw. The game is exceptionally balanced so players are unlikely to run away with the lead, but you can find yourself in a position where you don't see any resource generation cards until late in the game. There's several things that could solve this - having ways to cycle cards, drafting, or a tiered card system like 7 Wonders - and it's a pity that the game doesn't address it.

With that, this is a very good game that I'm pretty happy to play whenever offered. But I'm unlikely to personally suggest it over my favorite meatier Euros.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I was expecting a really good game. Exceeded my expectations 100 fold.

This reminded me of Race for the Galaxy in some ways with card synergy. This is probably going to be a top 10 game of all time for me...just need to get more plays in to confirm.

The Meeple Realty insert is pretty much a necessity with this game.

Component issue side note: I do think the publisher should have made the paper player boards cardboard with cut outs for the cubes with as much use as they get AND how significant they are to the gameplay (a bump could ruin a game!). I think anyone whom plays this game would have paid more for something like that. While it doesn't sour the game, it could sour A game. It is frustrating to do this with a "gamer's" game.

Also, the cubes paint chips. Even after 1 play. They feel great, but what are these going to look like after 10 plays? I'll probably have to end up re-painting them and resealing them myself, or buying upgraded components. 

I do appreciate this game is made in my backyard (Lafayette, IN), but the selection of paper player boards and quality of the cubes still needs to be corrected.

RATING: 10
This game is FANTASTIC!  Tableau based engine building, resource management, board and area control, and lots of other things that you want to explore and exploit in a game.  So much replayability that this games needs to hit the table all the time, whenever an opportunity arrives.

The only thing lacking is the player interaction on a larger scale.  I guess there can be some "take that" with the placement of a tile or the play of a Red Card that can affect your opponent, but it does have a flavor of "multiplayer solitaire", which can be a symptom of some engine-building types of games.  But I can look past that, as I think this is a gem to enjoy for a long time.

RATING: 4
On the plus side, there's certainly a crunchy strategic underpinning to the game, so if that's all you require to enjoy a game, you may like this. But that's pretty much where the positives end for me. "Terraforming Mars" is as dry as Martian dirt. It's just numbers soup. So many numbers! My credit production is 49! My heat production is 17! My energy is 12! What's it all mean? CUBES! A multitude of cubes coming and going off your playmat - a non-recessed playmat, mind you, meaning one slight bump and you'll have lost any official record as to your production values. Meanwhile, your tableau is growing. Great! Only it won't stop growing, leading to multi-minute turns which end with you begging your fellow players to allow you some extra power you'd forgotten you possess because the associated card had gotten lost in the shuffle. Games can thus drag on and on, making the whole affair fairly wearying. That the game board starts ugly and really doesn't get much prettier despite the additions of ocean and greenery tiles doesn't help.

"Terraforming Mars" is an admirable game. It's a crunchy game. But it's not a particularly fun game, and you never really feel its admirable theme. There are few games I would flat out avoid playing again. This might be one of those few.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Once upon a time... there was the Snowball Engine. And gamers all around the world gazed in wonder upon the Snowball Engine, and saw that it was good. They proclaimed it Strategic. Tactical. The harbringer of world peace. 

And this day and age—2017'ish—the Snowball Engine is still very much alive and kicking. Witness this design which is almost pure Snowball. It contains five or six currencies you can mix and combine... but don't assume you'll be going anywhere anytime soon. The first hour of the game is spent doing almost nothing. You don't have the money, and you don't have the resources. Cards don't seem to [i]get[/i] you anywhere. Then, in the second hour, near the end, something seems to happen. And then you're done. The pacing is mind-numbingly glacial; and you suddenly realise you've spent the vast majority of your game time reading cards and pushing cubes around.

Surely you can [i]plan[/i] for something? Well... no. Cards are drafted, then passed around 7 Wonders / Notre Dame / Ginkgopolis-style, presumably to make it appear the game has a strategic streak. Such an approach may work in a game lasting 30 minutes. It is completely bonkers in a game lasting 120. It just goes to show that people don't really want complex interaction patterns. They want excessive sameness, for hours on end. Oh yes, there are cards which allow you to peek at the deck for a little foreknowledge. If you obtain them. 

Basically, I can't really imagine why people would want to play this with the solid Race for the Galaxy around the corner. It's the same principle, but taking only 20 instead of 120 minutes. In short, Terraforming Mars was never my type of game, and never will be either.

RATING: 9

RATING: 9
Birthday gift for my oldest son's 13th. He loves the movies "The Martian" and "Interstellar". Surprised that my 10 year old grasped the game quickly. I just help him through the details after he first reads the card. Both boys, and me, thoroughly enjoy playing.

High marks for production quality, artwork, theme, the variety of cards to play, and the number of things going on the board without the game being beyond the grasp of a bright 10 year old. I also like the huge variety of strategies / courses of action available. No two plays are alike.

Addition: I strongly disagree with the negative reviews I have read on this game. My top criteria for Euro games like this are:

1. Do my kids enjoy playing it?
2. Do I enjoy playing it with them?

Considering that my 13 year old son adores, and I mean ADORES, playing this game, while my 10 year old is nearly as enthusiastic about it, and I really enjoy it....what more is there to say? The reviews are over-analyzing negatives. The game is fun for all ages....over and over again. That makes it a home run, period.

RATING: 8
TL;DR: Terraforming Mars game mechanics are exceptional but it desperately needs a second edition to do a complete art design overhaul, new playmates (similar to Scythe), rules/guidebook re-write, and improve overall quality of the product.

The biggest issue I have with the game is that the art design is really bad, it’s as if the game designer had provisioned multiple artists and had a deadline of 2 weeks. I’m serious AF when I say this. I thought the design was intentional , i.e. retro cheesy science mix, but after our first game I noticed a lot of layout errors that would be caught during review. If you have TM a good example of this is the margin spacing on the instructional cards (which is inconsistent between cards and left/right of some cards).

Speaking of instructions — I want to applaud the person that can read the guide and fully understand how the game works without any help (YouTube or friends). The guidebook needs a re-write with an easier way to reference common mechanics of the game.

It just seems to me that the overall quality wasn’t a priority for the release, almost as if this was a beta testers edition to test the mechanics.

The playmates (and the cards) are fairly low quality glossy paper, and any slight bump of the table or the playmates you’ll be asking to yourself “where were these cubes exactly?”. It’s no wonder I see a lot of alternative playmates for TM.

Again, the vibe of Terraforming Mars is a beta release stands out as soon as you open the box. Everything is simply thrown in baggies, there are no dividers. With this game having tons of cards the expectation is at least a card tray in the box. It’s no wonder (again) there are a lot of organizers for TM.

I know, I know, this is all superficial and that’s why with all these quality issues I still see it being an excellent game. One that I highly recommend playing.

I’d recommend when playing drafting process for selecting project cards, it’s going to add some time but it will prevent the game from titling in a players direction based on a random draw. That said it has a trade-off of extending the game time, especially if you have slower players, so ‍♂️

After playing for a bit you will notice how well thought out everything is; which allows for you as a player to be fully engrossed in terraforming mars.

RATING: 10
I was considering for a long time whether to get this game as I felt the theme is not my thing. Fortunately Czech version was released and it meant as usual that my interest grew.
And it was great decision. The game became one of my favorites shortly. I have never been into the new game before. It almost feels it is taylored just for me. Also it is great both as solo and multiplayer mode (some games can be played solo, but for sake of loosing some appeal - but this is not the case).

What I like:
- Card draft. I like drafting a lot (see MtG), and there is an awesome draft mechanism - it is just optional, but I would always play it this way (there are some exceptions, for example when teaching the game to the new gamer). It is so cool to pick what you need or deciding to "hatedraft" what your opponent really needs.
- paying for cards you actually want to own and play later. Wow this adds a lot. I would say this is one of the cores of the game and one of the reasons why the game is so successful. You simply need to decide whether you need this card so you will pay 3$ for it or it would be better for you to save the tight sources for some other cards or for actually building something. Clever, very clever.
- I like the engine building implemented there. You started as a weak corporation but you become more and more powerful with more abilities. First few rounds are usually very short as you can do only few actions, but later in the game the action's decision tree grows a lot.
- Each corporation demands a bit different play style, some are more specialized, some are more open, but all are more or less balanced (for multiplayer games).
- Cards. There are plenty of cards. With variable effect and power. This adds a bit of luck to the games as you can pick a great card for you or not. I believe this is good, I like having some sort of luck in my games.

What I dislike:
- Player boards. They are awful. I would accept that they use unappealing font and the graphics is not so nice, but the cardboard is so thin. It is just a piece of paper. and storing all the cubes in the game on it? painful. Hopefully nobody would move with a table because it this case you would lost every track of your progress. Bad.
- Sometimes you feel you just move cubes here and back. A lot of cubes. And all the time. This is so annoying especially when you use some resource repetitively each generation and in produce phase you need to take them back. This is not cool.

Other than that, I don't have any gripe with the production quality of the game - the board is nice and it shows everything you need to know in a game, the resource cubes are nice. Just made player boards similar as in Scythe and it will be great.

RATING: 8
Overall, a lovely experience. It's taken longer than printed on the box, but I've enjoyed it enough that I haven't cared. Three caveats:

1. Drafting makes this game 10x better, but doesn't work well on a first play, and adds slightly to play-length.

2. All my plays have been with the owner's house-rule on attacks: rather than "choose a player to lose (eg) 8 Plant", losses are divided equally among all opponents. [i](Remainder taken from the players with the most; break ties clockwise.)[/i] This loses  some in-your-face interactivity, but I think the game's a better experience for it, unless your group happens to be particularly fond of take-that dynamics.

3. While overall I like the "pay to keep a card" dynamics, I'm not fond of needing to do the "will keeping all the cards I want torpedo my plans for the turn?" math.

For some reason, Terraforming Mars is a game that I really enjoy playing in spite of its evident flaws. At its core it's just a too damn long engine-building resource conversor, but the brilliantly implemented theme and satisfying tile-placement mechanisms keep me coming back for more. My biggest complain, though, is the monotonous card design; most of them just read "rise this and/or reduce that", which keeps the game a bit too simple and repetitive for its own good. RATING: 6.5
It's not a perfect game. The central game board feels sort of arbitrary; the area control is pretty uninteresting, the points you get from it at the end of the game feel very secondary to points you get elsewhere, and it ends up feeling like an overly small band-aid for the game's lack of player interaction. The cards are interesting but, by the end of the game, you've played so many of them that any amount of theme or character they may have had totally disappears, which is a shame given how intensively researched this game is. And it does seem like the player lucky enough to draw the cheaper, more playable cards early on is at a distinct advantage. Also, holy shit, what a terrible rule book.

To its credit, the player-selected awards and milestones are really smart and make for some very interesting gameplay decisions. I wish these were a bigger focus. And, of course, it's very satisfying to watch one's engine work in the second half of the game, even if it's working sub-optimally. This satisfaction is a bit of a crutch as far as the entire game is concerned.

What this game does well it does very well. But I'm not sure that what it does well is enough to make it worthy of worship.

RATING: 7
It's only my initial rating after having played only five 2-player games.

The game itself is very good and satisfying. Building your own engine and searching for the best possible combinations is interesting and forces to think and to calculate. There is atmosphere to be found despite the game being an eurogame - you can actually FEEL the projects you're executing.

Yet I have a few problems about Terraforming Mars. In spite of popular opinion, I would love to see more negative interaction, even to the point when you're able to destroy other players' tiles or steal their projects. Why cannot an asteroid annihilate a city with its population? At this point, I feel like each player is making their own engine and doesn't care about others' actions too much. Yes, there is a race for the titles and prizes, there is stealing good spots for cities, greenery etc. - but that's not much. This is especially seen in the late game, where everyone makes a lot of actions and focuses only on himself. Maybe it's specific in my group only and not a serious issue. Another thing is that I think the game is a bit overlong and tends to be tiresome at the end, leading to the point where both of us are able to gain more victory points but instead we just raise temp/oxygen to finish the game. The last thing is randomness. This is a card-driven game, every card is unique and you try to do combos. Yet you may find yourself in a situation where you play city-oriented corporation and you don't draw a single card that allows you to place a city on the board. Doesn't sound fun? :P I haven't played with draft yet but I suppose this could solve the problem at least partly.

I think that the game has a HUGE potential that is not fully tapped. Therefore I'm waiting for an expansion in which I would love to see more interaction between players and more possibilities for card drawing/searching in the deck.

So, my INITIAL thoughts are: Terraforming Mars is a very good game, although a little bit overhyped. I say this as a person who's more keen on ameritrash though. I say this as a person who has played only 2 player game and without draft - so far. It's definitely not a final opinion and I'm especially looking forward to playing a 4-player game to see how it works.

Edit: After playing two 3-player games I keep my rating & overall opinion. The game is simply overlong. I noticed that I lose my interest for the actual game during the final 30-60 min and I just want it to end. It gets just tiresome to constantly calculate and optimize your moves and you want to raise oxygen/temperature to finish it. The interaction between players is too low. Everyone is just sitting and thinking about themselves, sometimes not even watching what others are doing. I get the fact that some more "peaceful" players would enjoy it. As a player who enjoys games like Forbidden Stars or Chaos in the Old World I find that Terraforming Mars is a game not entirely for me.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Players are at the helm of a corporation. Together they terraform Mars. Each time they augment the oxygen level, the temperature or the number of ocean tiles their terraform rating (=VPs + important part of income) increases. This is done by buying and playing cards (each card is unique!), performing a standard project, or placing tiles on the surface of Mars. The city and greenery tiles placed are worth VPs at the end of the game. Extra VPs can be gained by achieving a milestone (and paying 8 M€) or by gaining an funded award (funded by any player). Many cards are also worth VPs (some negative). There are 3 types of cards: red event cards, green immediate effect cards, and blue action cards. The latter can be used once per generation (=playing round) or each time a certain requirement is met. During the action phase players take turns performing 1 or 2 actions until everyone has passed. Then the playing round ends. A production phase follows (production of money, steel, titanium, plants, energy and heat). Steel and titanium can be used as money to buy building cards and space cards respectively. Plants are used to place greenery tiles and augment the oxygen level, heat to augment the temperature, energy to buy specific cards. Energy left at the end of the action phase is automatically transformed into heat at the start of the production phase.
The game starts off slowly, as one has to build up production capacity. There are a lot of things one can do. Choosing is never easy. This can lead to some down time during the game. The plethora of unique cards make for a unique experience, though.

RATING: N/A

In the 2400s, mankind begins to terraform the planet Mars. Giant corporations, sponsored by the World Government on Earth, initiate huge projects to raise the temperature, the oxygen level, and the ocean coverage until the environment is habitable. In Terraforming Mars, you play one of those corporations and work together in the terraforming process, but compete for getting victory points that are awarded not only for your contribution to the terraforming, but also for advancing human infrastructure throughout the solar system, and doing other commendable things.

RATING: 9.5
This is one of my favourite two player games going, with the drafting rule there's plenty of opportunity to mess with your opponents plans, and although the number of attack cards is minimal, they feel useful in the two player game.

The major reason I like this game is the diversity of strategies and engines you can build from game to game, it feels like many strategies are possible and you generally have the freedom to try out a number of different things per game.  With drafting you see a lot of cards, and are also generally prevented from assembling an overly degenerate combo.

The major issue with this game is that it loses a lot of its charm with a higher player count.  Drafting feels almost pointless, and without drafting the interaction goes way down.  Attacks feel less useful because you only effect one of your opponents, and it's difficult to pay attention to what everyone is doing to try to prevent them from carrying out their plan.  Maybe it's alright with three, but it's definitely only a 9.5/10 with two players.

RATING: 6.75
[01 Nov 2016] - 8.25 (1 play)
Had one playthrough of this game at 4 players and loved it. Lots of things to do and lots of planning. Ended up coming in second on my first playthrough and didn't even mind the 3.5 hour playtime. Other reviews from various podcasters seem equally as favorable so I might have to pick up a copy of this game.


[24 Jan 2017] - 7.0 (3 plays)
Played this two more times at the four player count mark. The second game I was the tree corporation (can't remember the name) and was pretty much getting hammered by the other players until about a 1/3 of the way through the game I found a card to prevent being a target from tree attacks. Managed to claw my way back into the game but not enough. This game was really long with two players taking a lot of time to read each card and try to plan their turns.

In the third game, my corp was able to turn heat into money. I also combined that with an effect that would give me heat and money for every space card I played. That worked well but about halfway through the game I stopped getting space cards. Had to reconfigure the engine but it wasn't enough and I didn't get anything played onto Mars. This game was shorter since the players really pushed the terraforming parameters up hard.

After three games, I'm finding that the shine on this game is wearing off. The game is already long and most people don't want to play with the draft because of the extra time. This leaves most of it up to luck. Even with drafting, there's only one of every card making it possible to not get the cards you need (hate drafting) with no possible recourse. It would have been ideal if the designer provided more ways to mitigate this (bid for turn order, card auction, ability to go through discard pile, etc).

[15 Aug 2017] - 6.75 (4 plays)
There is just too much randomness in the cards, even with drafting, for this game to take 3-4 hours to play. With around 500 unique cards, it's almost near impossible early on to determine if you're going to see enough cards to make a strategy viable. Trying to solve with the simple draft at a fixed cost also makes it easy for players to hate draft cards and sell them for patents later on. In the last game, two of the four were doing that and killing all the Jovian tagged cards leaving me with very few early on and none come mid game. After hour 2 and finally understanding what had happened, there was no enjoyment in the game. The game really needs an auction for cards, but this would make the game unplayable.
