RATING: 6
Possibly the most enjoyable to play flawed game out there -

- Random card draw can deliver an easy win if one player draws cards with some obvious VP synergies. Not an issue with shorter games like 'Race for the Galaxy' but Terraforming Mars runs quite long for the winner to be possibly decided in this manner. If you use the drafting option this partly mitigates it but at the expense of a longer game. 
- There are a few 'take-that' cards but not enough to ensure that everyone takes their fair share.
- Financial and resource accounting can be a little fiddly.
- The player boards are not great for recording details as they are easily knocked.
- Overpriced in the UK 
- For the money the artwork on the cards should be stellar but it's a real hotch-potch of styles and quality. 

So a fun activity but significantly over-rated as a game on BGG.

RATING: 9
A clever, thematic Euro, where players represent companies all contributing to the terraforming of Mars.  This is achieved by increasing the temperature, pumping oxygen into the thin atmosphere, and getting liquid water into the low bits on the planet.  

At heart its simply an engine building game where cards are purchased from a massive deck, and injected into the player's engines to accelerate their agendas.  There are about six resources to manage so Euro gamers will be in hog heaven.  However what impressed me was the solid science and well balanced cards (dozens and dozens of them) in the game.  

Very good.

RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The game is very thematic but unfortunately the mechanics of the scoring suffer from such theme-emphasis as they can be very fiddly and not very streamlined.  Generally, the game just feels very “fiddly": there were so many occurrences when we would place a tile and then ask, “do I raise the temperature or O2 level?”, or “Oh, did you raise the temperature already?”, or we would put down a tile of one color next to another tile of another color and ask, ‘wait do I get points for this color tile combination, but not for this other color tile combination?”  I guess placing curtain combinations of colored tiles next to other colored tiles makes sense from a thematic standpoint, but honestly, I wasn’t paying much attention to the theme and it all just felt very fiddly.   

The text on the cards (and the board) are very thematic in their terminology, but it just seemed to cause confusion amongst players as to what the cards actually did.  I can’t count how many times the game stopped dead as someone asked, “What does this card mean here?”  We would draw our four cards at the beginning of each round and then just sit there in silence as we pondering what the cards did.  There are just SO MANY cards, and they are SO varied and random; you can’t possibly aim for any specific cards (or even types) to develop some specific strategy.  Its all about hoping to get lucky.  And some of those “Take That” cards; WOW (!) they can be so detrimental to other players and become real game-changers: even MORE randomness here!  Randomness in a shorter game is tolerable, but not in a three hour game.  

Honestly, I pretty much ignored the use of the cards for the most part both because of drawing really crappy cards and out of frustration trying to figure out what they do.  I mostly focused on getting money, and placing tiles and filling up the board with my colored cubes.  This is a low scoring game, so every point is valuable.  If I was lucky to draw a card with a high victory point value, I would spend the money and put it down, regardless of its ‘ability’.  I really neglected my engine and really thought I would come in last place as all the other players had tons and tons of cards in front of them.  To my surprise, I came in second in a five-player game because I had a city surrounded by lots and lots of forests and oceans and some brown-tile thing that I still don’t know what it did.  There doesn’t seem to be a direct a correlation between building your engine and getting enough points to win the game.  

Generally, I found the game too random, fiddly and long.  I would recommend this game for hard-core gamers that have a strong interest in the Terraforming Mars theme and the patience to play this a few times to let the idiosyncrasies of the rules settle in (there is a high learning-curve here).  However, for the general audience looking for a card-driven game that manipulates a board, I would recommend ‘Bruges’ or the original ‘Agricola’ as their rules are more streamlined, cards well-balanced, play faster and less prone to Analysis Paralysis.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I played Terraforming Mars for nigh on 3 hours and that time sped by. Come the end I felt that I could have played for another 3 hours. The game was so interesting with such a diverse but interesting selection of cards to see on every round that I was fully involved and engaged throughout.

We played the full game including drafting and I would recommend that even for your first game. The game is not complex and there really is no need to play the intro starting cards nor the stripped down deck (unless you want a shorter game). Drafting is essential to allow you to get the cards you need to work combos well.

There are some take-that cards which are a little blunt, but that aside on the whole this is multi-player solitaire on a shared map.

An excellent Euro game with a huge amount of replayability.

I've played at least 6 times and have used a different strategy each time thanks to the variable player powers (in the form of unique corporations) you get at the beginning of the game. There are so many corporations, I don't see this game feeling repetitive any time soon. Plus, all the cards feel extremely well balanced and unique.

It's cool, it's easy to learn and pretty satisfying. The theme alone is likely gonna make it for most sci-fi fans boardgamers out there. After 8 or so playthroughs I lowered my ranking a bit, but still a solid game.

RATING: 7.41
This game an example of how [b]Dominant Species[/b] would play like if it was exclusively played using 300 different cards. Oh yes, there are 300 cards and no 2 cards are the same. At first it seems like a huge amount of information because every card does something different and there is a lot of text, but after two games you realize it is indeed true: there is a lot of information in your hands. Cards are drafted every turn, but still, there is a huge amount of randomness.
The game play is fun. Story arch is very enjoyable since all players are trying to make habitable planet out of Mars, and you watch oceans, forests and cities grow as well as temperature and oxygen level. But there can be only one winner in the end - the corporation who did the most stuff. And while the leader can be seen early, there is always competition until the very end. 
Enjoyable game but a bit slow, and random.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Asymmetric factions which greatly direct the play style. And drafting.

[b]Update:[/b] I acquired this game at Essen Spiel 2017, with all expansions and designer's signature, for 85.00 EUR, which is certainly a great value.

RATING: 9
I thought the art would really put me off this one, but once I saw it in person I thought it was actually kind of charming - the mashup of different styles actually seems to lend itself to the theme of here are some snapshots of what martian terraforming may look like.  Looking at the art made me feel like I was being pitched different models for terraforming.  I also really like when games give you personal action cards to exploit, and TM seems to be chock full of them.  

The only negatives I have are that the graphic design is ugly and the iconography is kind of confusing - but it’s still better than Race for the Galaxy.  After half a game you should have it down.  The length of the game could be a knock against it as well, except that it’s tied to one of the factors that makes this game so fun - the race to terraform the planet.

Despite the game’s complexity it feels really sticky - after one play I feel I could go back to the game months from now and just start playing with very minimal rules referencing.  

Out of the 2016 darlings, I’d definitely say this is the best on the Euro end of the equation.  And were it not for Star Wars Rebellion I’d say it’s the best of the year.  I need to play both some more to see where I stand.

If you love card driven games like Deus, Imperial Settlers, Lewis and Clark, etc, and don’t mind a longer one, Terraforming Mars is great!

RATING: 9.5
An excellent game that has quickly become one of our favourites to play!  Although lengthy, the science concepts, and the heavy emphasis on a current, engaging theme make the time pass enjoyably.  All of the cards are unique which provides many options for developing your production engine.  However, randomness of 4 card draw necessitates playing with some form of drafting variant.  Rulebook could be tweaked a bit to more clearly explain actions/turn vs. actions/generation, as well as the stacking of cumulative effects.  Production markers need a firmer footing on player board to avoid confusion – perhaps thicker player board with recessed slots, or trays (which a third party is currently developing).  Except for the minor complaints listed (which can be easily addressed in subsequent iterations), this is a game that has us thinking about it even when the game is not on the table – a definite sign of a top notch game!

RATING: 8
Terraforming Mars, over the past 6 months-ish, is the new darling euro. I didn't really like the mish-mash of artwork on the cards. I also didn't like that I've heard this game can go 3+ hours. Upon playing this, I can see it's appeal. It's an engine-building game that focuses on the production of 6 main resources, with money being the most versatile. Using money and potentially resources, the players will play cards that will increase their production, give them special icons, help fulfill terraforming goals (such as creating oceans, increasing the oxygen level, and increasing the temperature on the planet), attack players, create settlements on the planet, and a variety of other effects. The game ends when all of the terraforming goals have been achieved. 

The card count for this game is actually quite staggering compared to most games. In addition, you can play with a unique faction that has it's own unique special ability and starting money. There is quite a variety of these as well. The game has an interesting goal system where you spend money and use an action to claim a 'most goal,' but if another player has the most by the end of the game, they get the points. There is also a race to achieve "first goals." These should sound familiar to Race for the Galaxy, with the 'most' being a little different. In fact, I feel this game has a lot in common with Race for the Galaxy... it's just played on a board and is about 4 - 6 times longer, depending on how quickly you play either game.

Not only can I see its appeal, but it's a good game that I enjoy. A thing of note: there doesn't seem to be a 100% consensus on how people enjoy playing this game. Some people like to draft cards, some don't. Some people like to use the unique factions and some don't (because they think they could be unbalanced). Some people like to start this game with having a production of one in all the six main resources to speed up the somewhat long play time and others don't. 

Basically, if you hated the icon system in Race for the Galaxy or you wanted to play a longer, more complicated version of that game, this is definitely one worth trying.

Note to Self: Try these coop rules...

* Set up the board per the solo rules. Generally, follow all solo rules.
* Players start at 14 TR (per the solo rules)
* Players have 12 generations to fully terraform Mars and score as high as possible.
* Any card that would remove resources/production/tokens from an opponent instead ADDS those resources/production/tokens to your partner, if possible.
* When players receive cards at the start of a round, they may each give one card to their partner. However, a player can still only buy a max of 4 cards at the start of the round.

If wanting to try for high scores: Alternatively, start with 20 TR instead of 14. Still play for 12 generations; aim to break 200 points and fully terraform Mars.

RATING: 7
Terraforming Mars is littered with both greatness and mediocrity. The product value is shoddy, with thin cards and player boards, and pitifully incongruous art. It also lacks focus. The objectives are clear (terraform mars), but there are several tangential paths players can take which divert the focus from the objective at hand, to marginal victory point gains. Length is also a bit of an issue, and the game would benefit greatly from a balanced set of production asymmetries, which would add variety and speed up the game. Lastly, due to the sheer amount of unique cards, some are certainly more powerful (and/or) situational than others, which over such a long game makes this imbalance more noticeable. However, the game is fun. Crashing comets, erecting cities, and building solar lenses is fun, and the cards help establish the scope of the game. The paying for cards is this game's most unique contribution. Not only does needing to pay to draw cards help mitigate card draw luck, but it monkeys with your pace and creates a lot of interesting interplay between long- and short-term strategies. All together, I enjoy Terraforming Mars, but its definitely a short term relationship. Once the novelty of its cards has run dry, there will be little reason to tolerate its shortcomings.

RATING: 8
In the 2400s, mankind begins to terraform the planet Mars. Giant corporations, sponsored by the World Government on Earth, initiate huge projects to raise the temperature, the oxygen level, and the ocean coverage until the environment is habitable. In Terraforming Mars, you play one of those corporations and work together in the terraforming process, but compete for getting victory points that are awarded not only for your contribution to the terraforming, but also for advancing human infrastructure throughout the solar system, and doing other commendable things.

The players acquire unique project cards (from over two hundred different ones) by buying them to their hand. The projects (cards) can represent anything from introducing plant life or animals, hurling asteroids at the surface, building cities, to mining the moons of Jupiter and establishing greenhouse gas industries to heat up the atmosphere. The cards can give you immediate bonuses, as well as increasing your production of different resources. Many cards also have requirements and they become playable when the temperature, oxygen, or ocean coverage increases enough. Buying cards is costly, so there is a balance between buying cards (3 megacredits per card) and actually playing them (which can cost anything between 0 to 41 megacredits, depending on the project). Standard Projects are always available to complement your cards.

Your basic income, as well as your basic score, is based on your Terraform Rating (starting at 20), which increases every time you raise one of the three global parameters. However, your income is complemented with your production, and you also get VPs from many other sources.

Each player keeps track of their production and resources on their player boards, and the game uses six types of resources: MegaCredits, Steel, Titanium, Plants, Energy, and Heat. On the game board, you compete for the best places for your city tiles, ocean tiles, and greenery tiles. You also compete for different Milestones and Awards worth many VPs. Each round is called a generation (guess why) and consists of the following phases:

1) Player order shifts clockwise.
2) Research phase: All players buy cards from four privately drawn.
3) Action phase: Players take turns doing 1-2 actions from these options: Playing a card, claiming a Milestone, funding an Award, using a Standard project, converting plant into greenery tiles (and raising oxygen), converting heat into a temperature raise, and using the action of a card in play. The turn continues around the table (sometimes several laps) until all players have passed.
4) Production phase: Players get resources according to their terraform rating and production parameters.

When the three global parameters (temperature, oxygen, ocean) have all reached their goal, the terraforming is complete, and the game ends after that generation. Count your Terraform Rating and other VPs to determine the winning corporation!

RATING: 9.2
The only complaint I have with this game is the lengthy setup. Otherwise this is one of my favorite games and my wife's favorite. It truly is one of the best engine building games I've played and the complex cards are made beautifully straightforward by the simple explanations and clear symbols. Yea, the components aren't the best but the gameplay makes up for it. It's great that the game timer depends on the players and they drive the game. I've found that with each card drawn my strategy tends to change. The game is very rewarding as each card provides unique gains and losses, sometimes from your own resources or from another player. Do you buy a bunch of cheap cards to quickly build a small engine or do you wait to buy that expensive card that gives you an abundance of resources immediately. Choices. An awesome game that hasn't been given as much attention as it deserves.

RATING: 5
The game itself is a solid design but it's just boring, and after three games I have no interest whatsoever in revisiting it. Not enough exciting card synergies to give you an arc to be excited about. It's just micro synergies for micro advancements over and over for 3 hours. Pretty much the same thing throughout the game without much of a source of tension. Player interaction is a bit of lame "take that" in resource/income thieving. Competition on the board for spaces is mild. Yawn. 

The game is not an engine builder but rather an income builder. The ostensible fun of the game is building up your income so you can play more and better cards as the game goes on. But turns out without an engine of your own, you're just hoping for fortuitous card draws to give you something interesting to do with your monies. The happenstance of the cards you draw relative to your intended strategy combined with how lame the synergies of the cards are results in a solid game that works but just is uninspiring.

To be clear, I don't think it's a bad game, just a squarely mediocre one. For a better implementation of card/tile combinations and player interaction, I highly recommend Zhang Guo, The Capitals, or Race for the Galaxy.

RATING: 7
I really like the theme and how it is implemented somewhat realistically. Terraforming Mars takes generations in the game; I don't think it would happen overnight in real life either. RATING: 2
I enjoyed:
- being able to select scoring conditions
- looking at the pretty main board

I disliked:
- how terrible the component quality is (One slight movement of the table, and we're all freaking out about where our cubes were on our tracks. Why are the player boards such thin, flimsy paper? Why not put the time and money into making thick boards with indentations for cubes to lay into and prevent movement? Why is the art so inconsistent in style on all the cards? Why not put in the time and money to come up with solid, consistent art on all the cards? Why would a publisher half-ass SO MUCH of the game? Why would a publisher hate its customers like this?)
- the kinda arbitrary placement of stuff on the map (Why can I only build this specific city only in this spot? Maybe I want it on the tile above? Or on the other side of the planet.)
- the so very repetitive nature of it all (Buy cards. Maybe use them. Move a/some cubes. Get more cubes. Repeat.)
- that for how "scientific" this game is, it's still not very realistic (Smashing a moon into the planet would wipe out pretty much everything that we have accomplished up to this point. Puppies? Warm temperature? Yeah, they're gone. Welcome to the Ice Age.)
- the engine that I'm building with the cards is just not satisfying at the end of the game ("I did it. There are cubes and tiles on the map. Huh." Just such a hollow feeling after so long a time spent looking at awful cards and rearranging my cubes because of table bumps.)
- that the game does not reward more plays because it's so ridiculously balanced (I was just two points away from the winning player, who had played this game many more times than me. This doesn't feel right.)
- there's not much strategy beyond "Use the cards to build your engine" (You avoid this, and you lose. The corporation you play as is just a trick to make you feel like you're playing a different game every time, but you're not.)
- that the corporations are too simple in the asymmetry that it doesn't really matter what you choose to play as (It's just such a tiny tweak that it's not even worth bothering to play as a corporation.)
- that there were so many occasions that I actually DIDN'T want to advance the game because it would mean someone else would score something on a track, thereby prolonging the repetitive nature of the game even more (The game rewards you RESISTING playing the game. This is messed up.)
- that the game drags on for far too long, and if you play the game strategically, it drags on for EVEN LONGER

Final verdict: How are people just so blind to this game's ridiculous list of problems?

RATING: 9.5
A fantastic well-themed game, and as an undergraduate chemistry major, I applaud the designer who has a Ph.D. in it.  The only reason I don't give this game a 10 is because of the small print on the cards which makes it a bit challenging for those, like me, who are now farsighted, as well as chance that the cubes used on the player board to mark production rates could accidentally move (for which there is now an overlay from Broken Token).  Otherwise, this game is a splendid gaming experience of tableau building, drafting (I prefer the variant for allocating the cards draw each generation), replayability galore, a solitaire variant, and multiple paths to victory-deserving of the best game of the year award for 2016, if Great Western Trail doesn't get it.

RATING: 7
After 4 plays: Interesting asymmetric interactions of the different goods (money, steel, titanium, plants, energy, & heat) plus cards in hand and tiles added to map.  Map building aspect adds a bit of player interaction and thematic depth to a basic hand management game.    Tokens are nice.  Interaction of cards and theme icons is difficult to strategize, but adds interesting synergy effects (overall a plus).

Some weaknesses: suffers a bit from from victory point salad, with some arbitrary goals ("milestones" and "awards") and bonuses strewn about (though they also add a race aspect with the other players).  Tends a bit toward solitaire with most of your focus on your hand and not reacting to your opponents' plays.

RATING: N/A
55.00
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I shall start by saying that this was not what I was expecting.  I hadn’t read a lot about Terraforming Mars as it looked to me like a heavy weight, dry euro game and I’m just not enjoying those at the moment.  However, I was quite surprised to find that it is a light-medium weight card game that has a board in the same way that Trains is a deck builder with a board.

It is an interesting beast and seems to be a patchwork of different ideas ripped from other games; in fact, I haven’t played a game, watched a film or read a book in recent memory that so obviously and so liberally borrowed concepts and ideas from its piers.  I’ll get on to that a bit more later, but first we’ll look at how it plays.

We started with “Beginner Companies”, which is to say that they are all the same.  The same starting resources, the same starting production and no special powers.  You then get dealt a hand of 10 cards each from the top of an enormous deck (which would have been twice the size if we hadn’t taken out the ‘advanced cards’) and that’s it.  Almost the entire game revolves around these cards.

The cards themselves are loosely split into 3 types: green, blue and red.  Green are the most common and usually involve a onetime bonus, such as increasing the amount of one resources that you produce at the end of the round or increase the amount of that resources that you have right now.  Others are a more complex, such as exchanging one unit of one resource for 2 of another, but once they have been used they are added to your tableau where the squat there until the end of the game.  They have no further effects but there are icons at the top which may be relevant for scoring.  Then you have the rarer blue cards, which usually give you a powerful bonus of playing them, such as a pile of resource X and then sit in your tableau and can be activated again once a round for a benefit, usually a resource cube.  Lastly there are the somewhat common (Although I only got 1 throughout the entire game) red cards, which usually (but not always) screw over another player by targeting their resources, ability to produce resources, or their tableau.  These again are one shot and are then discarded.

You can take one or two actions on your turn, or you can pass, which means that you can no longer take part in the rest of the round.  There is a list of actions that you can take, but mostly (and especially early on) you will be simply playing cards from your hands to create a tableau.  Except that sometimes you won’t. 

Issue 1

An issue that I picked up on early in the game is that a lot of cards have costs or requirements that have to be met, similar to Spartacus where you have to have a certain amount of influence to play.  Here it may be that one of the 3 tracks has to be above or below  or on a certain number.  This created a peculiar situation whereby within my initial hand of 10 cards, there was only one that I could play.  It wasn’t until later in the round and through other players affecting the game state that I was able to play a second card, which would turn out to be the last.  This somewhat uneven setup can create a real imbalance within the first round, whereby some players with rush of with the beginnings of fantastic engines, whereas some will just be left floundering, which leads me into my second issue.

Issue 2

Issue number 2 with the game, is that it has a bit of a runaway leader issue and also tends to reward those who are doing well and punish those who are not.  For example, after the first round Andy had been able to play quite a few cards from his hand: 2 greens, 2 reds and 1 blue.  As such he had quite a substantial lead and has knocked me and Stephen backwards as well as getting a powerful blue card out that could be activated each round for free.  I was in second and Stephen was in third, and this is exactly how the game finished.  I think the issue herein lies that your current victory point total is your base income!  Meaning that the more VPs you have, the more money you have in the next round meaning you can play and more importantly, buy more cards, making your tableau and therefore your position stronger.  Interestingly, the only way (apart from a few spaces on the board) that you can obtain new cards is between round where you are dealt 4 at random and can then choose to keep as many as you like, but have to pay 3 credits each.  Therefore, the better you are doing, the more money you have, the more cards you can buy, the more cards you can play, the better you do.  It ramps up exponentially.  Furthermore, the red cards can be devastating; if you are lucky enough to be dealt them then you have to be able to afford to play them.  This again means that the player with the most resources can further trample on the weak engines of those who they are trying to catch up.  Then we come to the mile stones.  These add a race element to the game, such as being the first to put 3 cities on the board, or the first to put down 8 vegetation tiles or build 8 buildings (represented by the brown building symbol on some of the cards in your tableau).  So, if you are doing well and winning, chances are you will be the first to complete one or more of these, giving you a 5 VP bonus for each.  However, to complete them you have to buy them at a cost.  Now, a balancing mechanic that I have seen in a lot of games is that the first person to a powerful achievement has to pay the most, or faces an additional barrier, such as in Le Havre where in order to use the dock to build an iron ship, you also have to ‘modernise’ it by paying additional brick resources.  In Terraforming Mars, it is the opposite; the first person to reach a milestone gets it for 8 and then the price goes up to 16 and then 24 for subsequent ones.  Furthermore, there are 5 available but only 3 can be claimed and each only once, so it is entirely possible that you could be locked out of ever getting one.  There are also awards which work in much the same way to further exasperate the issue.

Issue 3

This game can be extremely random, with the cards that you draw and that your opponents draw determining what actions can be taken over the course of the entire round.  At this point I should point out the on the board are printed a selection of “Public Endeavours”, which can be used by anyone and function in a similar way to the green cards, in that you spend credit and take the action, such as putting down a vegetation tile, ocean tile etc.  The issue with these, and the reason why I have neglected to mention them up until this point, is that they are just far too expensive and limited.  Furthermore, as there are not cards involved, there is nothing to add into your tableau, therefore potentially denying yourself VPs at the end of the game from scoring certain icons.  However, they are there and it would be remiss of me not to mention them.  Back to the issue in hand.  This game borrows quite heavily from Seasons (and apparently Race for the Galaxy, but I haven’t played that), but without the ability to plan out your turns.  To mitigate the inherent luck in Seasons, you claim all of the cards that you will be using over the course of the game at the beginning, and then can allocated them evenly to each of the games 3 round.  This way you know in advance what is going to be available and therefore you can plan accordingly.

As I mentioned earlier, in Terraforming Mars you are at the mercy of your starting hand, a massive deck of unique card, and then at the mercy of what cards you draw throughout the course of the game.  There is simply no way to get around the fact that some cards are just much better than others, and some cards combine really well, but only if you get them both into your hand.  This wouldn’t be such an issue with a smaller car pool, but the deck around 200 unique cards and therefore the chances of getting the 2 or 3 that you need is slim at best.  Other games that rely heavily on cards get around this by having a central pool of cards that you can purchase, think Nations, Through the Ages, City of Iron, which allows you to mitigate some of the randomness and plan accordingly.  Furthermore you can see if a player takes a card that could affect you negatively compose a strategy to protect yourself against the potentially negative effects of that.  In Terraforming Mars you never know what card players have received or have in their hands.  Furthermore, anything that they choose not to buy is discarded face down so that you have no idea what they are planning and how it could potentially affect you.  This can be problematic, especially as the margins between success and failure can be so small, but also removes some of the interaction as you are no longer interested in other players turns until they hit you with something that causes your economy to crumble.  Furthermore, there is also the issue that as there are is not a set number of turns - there are no ages and therefore no progression in what cards are available and when.  This means that you may be dealt a hand of late game cards early on, which are effectively useless, or early game cards at the end when all you want to do is add VPs to your tableau, both of which can be very frustrating.  Going back to Spartacus, which often is criticised for the blind drawing of cards during the intrigue phase, this offsets these issues by allowing you to sell the cards as you get them, with a reward that is roughly equivalent to the cards usefulness, meaning that if you have cards that you cannot or do not want to use, you can sell them immediately for a sizeable reward in coins which you will be able to use on a later phase.  In Terraforming Mars, if you are dealt cards that are of no use, then tough luck, you just discard them for nothing and the actions that are available to you on the following turn are now far more limited.

A way to get around this somewhat is by using the card drafting variant, as described in the back of the rule book, which leads me on to …

Issue 4

Playtime.  This game is not quick, despite being relatively simple.  Our first play with 3 of us clocked in at around 2 hours 45 minutes, which is quite a chunk of time.  As a point of reference it took us longer to play Terraforming Mars with 3 then it did to play Mage Knight the week prior with 3.  The drafting method, which follows standard drafting rules and is implemented between rounds when you received the 4 random cards, would further add to this play time.  Furthermore, I’m not sure how suited this game is to drafting, as all of the cards are so random, or situational, or unique that you can really plan or create combinations as you don’t know if you will ever get the other cards required in a later draft, if at all, to make your engine work, or if a really situation card will ever be relevant.

Issue 5

I won’t spend too long on this one, but the components are a joke for a game that costs £65.  The card stock is some of the thinnest I have ever seen, then player boards are the same and look like they have been designed in MS paint and the art across the game is inconsistent and poor.

In conclusion, Terraforming Mars is, in my humble opinion, an okay game, but one that mechanically just isn’t very good.  It reminds me of a pop song that is at first striking, but on subsequent listens just doesn’t hold up.  It is also endemic of the myopic nature of board games that this currently resides at number 10 on BGG, as it does make a great first impression, after which the masses rush to the website to rate it as the best thing ever, when in reality and upon reflection, it is anything but.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Clearly this is a rich, complex game. But for the moment, though I'd be willing to play it again, I won't seek it out.

RATING: 7.5
After one play, I now know why so many are impressed with this game.  Lots of choices but I never felt bogged down.  Unlimited actions! --I love this game! 

 I agree with others that there should be some compensation in the game for going last, as I did.  Everyone else got two turns of going first, but I got only 1.  Going first is critical especially during the last few rounds of the game, and also for opponents taking your resources before you can use them.

I detest the cheap playboards.  One little bump & you have no idea where all the production cubes were.  For a few bucks more cardboard cutouts would have greatly improved the quality.  Yes I can purchase from Etsy, etc., plastic overlays--the cheapest for 5 being $30 plus shipping.  I much rather pay an extra $20 for the game.  This is why I am not buying the game --except maybe used so can afford the  3rd party overlays.  This is also why I did not rate the game an 8.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
For many years I have been strongly against card-driven games that use cards where you target a single opponent while gaining nothing for yourself. Unfortunately, this game has a lot of those cards. Fortunately, you receive so many cards in this game that you could simply discard any of that sort that come your way. However, it would be better if they didn't exist in the first place. Probably comes off as sour grapes given that I lost 16 Green during my first game due to attacks, but even by the end of the rules explanation I knew I wouldn't like this. It's not that it feels mean (I certainly don't care about that), but rather because from a design-theory perspective it's simply a bad mechanic if there are more than two players. The designer should have listened to the Ludology podcast. 

I also think I'd prefer that the cards be separated into eras -- at least a first and second era. It feels kinda silly to get a card on Turn 1 that couldn't possibly be played until the late game. 'Automatic discard' is not an interesting game decision.

Map play didn't seem very interesting either. Limited space, dedicated spaces for specific tiles, and constraining adjacency rules made the board feel a bit lifeless. 

It also needs to be about 1/3 shorter. 

I've read all three of KSR's Mars Trilogy books, so the theme was fun and compelling for me. The sheer volume and variety of cards was nice, too.

RATING: 6
Terraforming Mars looks like a (fairly large) boardgame but is really an oversized card game. It is sort of a tableau building or engine building game but the card combinations are actually fairly tame most of the time so it becomes more of an income building game instead. The game is solid but somewhat long for what it provides, and some aspects feel rather unnecessary and tacked on. The "take that" elements, for example, feel to me like they realized "Oh, hey, our game is not very interactive, is it? The positional play on the shared board is largely irrelevant and everybody just micro-manages their own income. Well, there's an easy fix for that..." Luckily, these effects are usually fairly minor. So, yeah, solid but mostly unspectacular.

RATING: 8.5
Mein Verhältnis zum Mars ist massgeblich von Ray Bradburys fantastischen "Mars-Chroniken" geprägt, eines der besten SF-Bücher überhaupt. Die Mars-Chroniken beschreiben die Kolonisierung des roten Planeten in Kurzgeschichtenform analog zur Kolonisierung Amerikas. Die Besiedelung des roten Planeten rennt bei mir also thematisch offene Türen ein und bleibt als ganz normales Euro-Kartenspiel im Raum stehen, das dem überhitzen Hype im Hip-Thema Mars nicht standhält: ein sehr gutes, gängiges Karten-Ausspiel-Spiel mit dem schönen Glückselement des zufälligen Kartenziehens, kombiniert mit überwiegend taktischen Überlegungen à la "Mach das Beste draus!" Das Ganze auch noch Draften? Never ever! Die visuelle Gestaltung ist RTL2: der Mix aus Perry Rhodan in Aldi und billiger Foto-Auffassung aus Bildarchiven Marke Corbis oder Getty verleiht TM den unfreiwilligen Charme von Hobbykeller. Dafür nimmt man TM die wissenschaftliche Grundlage des Chemikers Fryxelius als globale Parameter ab. TM ist jenseits der Hysterie gut genug um im oberen Mittelfeld bestehen zu können. Dort, im Trash seines DIY-Artworks, macht es seinen Job recht unterhaltsam ohne den Spielenobelpreis zu gewinnen. Und ich warte am Grab von Ray Bradbury auf die Reise zu den Lotosessern von der Venus von Stanley G. Weinbaum.

RATING: 7
Liked it! Almost an 8 game. I love the theme and the way that Mars develops in front of your eyes. This game works best with drafting and trying to get the most of your cards without letting your opponents get the most out of theirs. I can't believe the draft is a "variant" suggestion! This game would be - actually - terrible if you had to rely on the cards that you were dealt and that's it. Why would anyone want to play that?! However, I do think the game goes on a little long and takes on too much of an overloaded look with each player having 30 cards are so on the table by the end of the game. (Though admittedly they are all stacked.) I'm not sure how much lasting power the game would have. Nothing felt like you could create a variety of cool combo moves with each game. Just play good cards and hope for good cards later on. Not much strategy with the draft. Players can still get lucky. And maybe the worst part of the game is it's so MPS. Turns come by quick as a 3-player game. I don't think I'd want to play this with 4 and certainly not with 5! But not a whole lot of interaction. Overall, a very good game that might end up being just a good game if I played it too much. But that's never going to happen! I'd play it again!

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have often wanted Race for the Galaxy to go on a bit longer. To me Terraforming Mars is like playing Race for the Galaxy for 4 hours. With more turns and more cards you can really build an amazing engine. 

It is one of the most AP prone games I have played. We played with a draft variant. And the cards you draft you can choose to put in your hand by paying 3. You really have to calculate if you have enough money to play the card you buy and all other cards you play before it. All cards have costs and modify resources so you might be abel to afford playing a card now by using resources instead of money for a type of card and then get the discount for the next card of a type but when you do that you increase the income of another recource....It gets really complicated. And can slow down the game, but I really enjoy it. 

- The theme is not engaging to me. 
- The art work is not great, not as bad as the graphic design, but if I call it ok I am too kind. 
- The board is not interesting to look at and does not offer much strategy or interest to the game. 
- Take that is on a lot of cards and it is not enjoyable at all. Especially since alot of it can be directed to one player if he is the only one who has plants for example. Or if a player is percieved as the leader. If you do something I also get something is way better then to have sabotage and other cards that destroy for other players. 

It is the engine building and huge volume of cards that make this game great. I had no clue how to play it well the first play but want to play it again to play it better. That beeing said I won with a clear margin. I managed to time shifting to get VP at the right time, a mechanic that I also am not a fan of. 

So much I don't like but still a 9 and a game I very much would like to play again. 
With another theme, nicer design, less or no take that and a bit streamlined design and more interesting board I would give it a 10 and I would buy that game.

RATING: 10
I really enjoy this game a lot. It sets up quick and you can use Altoids boxes. The play is smooth and the rule book is well documented and with lots of icons to help you get going. You can play it solo and simply play through all the different Corporations (cards that give you starting abilities). The game is not so easy to beat but you seem to always get close. You are stuck a little by the luck of the draw on the cards, but there's an area on the board which allows you to do more. Card synergy is great. You can play a series of cards to give you a domino effect. The goal in the solo game is to get the Temperature, Oxygen, and Ocean (water tiles) to a specific level in order to win. Didn't win a solo game until the third game.

This is pretty close to perfect in my opinion.  The solo game is incredible and just the right length. This is not only one of the best solo games available, but also the best space-themed game I've played so far. 

Played 2-players.  It's a different feeling from the solo game in that there isn't a set number of generations in the game.  Rather, you have to watch your opponent's actions and gauge when to go for certain things, like Awards or sponsoring Milestones.  

Solo high scores:

Thorgate = 87 points
Teractor = 85 points
Interplanetary Cinematics = 82 points
Tharsis Republic = 82 points
Mining Guild = 79 points
PhoboLog = 79 points

RATING: 8

- All mechanisms are driven by the theme;

RATING: 6
Primarily a card drafting game. Each turn you get 4 draws and can buy cards for 3 bucks each. They vary in power considerably, but over the course of the game, you'll likely get some that can be combined to get your engine going. There are a few pick on the leader cards that allow you to steal resources or hurt another player, which feel imbalanced. There's an early race for certain bonuses that you can buy, as well as a later scoring categories you can buy. It's definitely AP prone until you've learned the game and cards to look for, and even then, I would not play with an AP player. On the plus side, the them shines, and this is a real tinkerer's game. If you like tweaking an engine to try and maximize points, you should enjoy this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
After repeat plays.  My opinion remains unchanged.  It has the same card luck and tableau building feeling of RftG with a protracted play time and less interesting rounds of play. 

August 24th, 2016:

I do enjoy the solo version but it does make so many cards useless. Also the gameplay becomes one dimensional solo but overall an enjoyable experience.

Multiplayer, the game opens up quite a bit and the synergies between cards and the different avenues for vp and resource production are numerous.  It does have a similar card set to something like Race for the Galaxy, but Race for the Galaxy is a WHOLE lot better for these reasons:

1) Terraforming Mars has really bad graphics and art.  The pictures are not engaging and the framing takes away from the theme.  While the numbers and effects are clear, the look of the game overall does not add to the experience, but instead detracts from it.  In Race for the Galaxy,  you can imagine each world/card.. it really draws you in and doesn't feel disconnected from other cards.

2) Race for the Galaxy is streamlined.  Virtually doing all the things this game does with practically only a deck of cards.  No fiddly bits that can be easily knocked around and no cheap player boards.

3) Divergent strategies are more pronounced.  While Terraforming Mars does allow you to make microbes, lichen, livestock, etc  and increase your different production resources and increase the planets two stats for money/vp.. you will most likely need to do at least some of all of that and specialize in one or more.  In Race for the Galaxy it feels more like you are doing your own strategy, like you came up with the combo.  While the cards in both are stat variations, the overall strategy in TM feels more linear, even though it isn't really.

4) Action phase is more engaging.  In TM you are buying and using cards without much concern to others.  Sure, the timing of whether to use one or two actions does have consequences sometimes.  Role selection and guessing/using others roles is far more engaging with other players and tense.  Card play is the bulk of both of these games.  This is important, since in RftG your choices of what card to build are limited by the role, which reduces AP.  In TM, you can build any card, any time, and AP is rampant.


Still, I do enjoy this game but graphic development and overall streamlining might have made this game more than this, which is what it should have been.

Interested in seeing what the upcoming Race for the Galaxy board game will be.
(Jay Tummelson coined it "New Frontiers" at GenCon).

Overall though.. I really like games with lots of UNIQUE cards that work well together with mostly balanced synergies and good theme.  This game succeeds on those levels in spaids!

RATING: 8
A sprawling tableau building game that provides you with a huge variety of cards and choices to use terraforming the planet. The fact that everybody is contributing towards the shared endgame condition of terraforming the planet, whilst also building their own personal score creates an interesting tension.

The component quality and graphic design are not the best though. The cheap art puts some people off, but I find it sort of endearing (it mostly seems to consist of CC-licensed images borrowed from the Internet).

I love that you can play cards representing everything from a dust mask or a dish of algae to interplanetary colony stations and moons crashing into the planet.

RATING: 6
EDIT: After my second play I am downgrading its rating by 1. It's still a solid drafting/tableau game, but it's extremely multiplayer solitaire. This time I went for a strategy that didn't play many territories on the board and I just didn't interact with my friends at all during the game. It's nice that there's plenty of viable paths to victory, but after having tried 2 I no longer have much of a desire to play the game more. Without player interaction it's just a game of waiting around and seeing who can get lucky and draft the best point engine. There are plenty of much more interesting, interactive point engine games out there.

It's a solid tableau builder with interesting board interactions, good drafting and great themeing. I like the cards, there's a good mix of different things and interesting combos. The drafting is especially interesting in this game, the cost of keeping cards gives more incentive to hate-draft because you usually don't keep all your cards anyway. There are plenty of viable strategies and I like the cubes being used for all resources, they're pretty and there's so much resource conversion that it would be annoying to have different tokens for all of them. 

The game's biggest weakness is its interaction. There's some competition for milestones and drafting and board placement will of course affect other players, but it just doesn't feel tight. Every player could easily just stake out their own parts of the board and while it sucks to lose out on milestones and awards, there's usually not much you could have done about it and it happens very seldom. The other big interaction portion comes from attacks, which can hit very hard but it's not always obvious who's winning so attacks can sometimes feel very random. I haven't played with the included expansion and I've seen that that adds more interactive cards, but I'm worried that that will cause the game to be too aggressive. Another weakness of the game is its downtime.

RATING: 6.79
After initially reading the rulebook I thought all the different mechanics in this game would clash with each other. Instead they create quite an interesting race for the players, opening up the options for multiple strategies, and allowing players to switch into a different one when needed. The card play is fun and interesting, and making an engine and actually getting to use it through out the game is very satisfying. BUT, a lot of the cards, specially with some "take that" in them feel like the designer needed an easy out for balancing purposes which I think could have been handle slightly different. The quality of the components is fine, but just fine, nothing really feels like they went out of their way to make better. The games graphic design and artwork is terrible. This is the one aspect where I don't understand how the publisher let this style go through. The game feels about 30-45 minutes too long, and I'm surprise this was not brought up during play testing.  I do not think this games deserves all the praise that it is receiving, but I do think there is something here. I would love to see a second edition with some of these issues resolved, the game makes me want to like it, but it also makes it hard for me too.

RATING: 8
Components: the board is good, better not talk about the rest
Complex: easy to learn, hard to master
Weight: medium
Players: 3 or 4, but works well also with 1 and 2
Length: less than 2 hours
Mechanics: tile palcement, hand management, engine resource creation....
Decisions: a lot, never are too much, but you have a lot happening here
Opinion: not an awesome game, but one I have liked a lot, and have me thinking in playing soon.
We go for the terraforming on Mars, and, during some generations, we have to get some projects (cards) and get the levels of the planet to something you can live on (Oxygen, water and temperature).
I really liked the idea of the game, everything clicks and flows smoothly. Each generation you draw 4 cards and decide which ones will you keep, if any, but hey, you have to pay for what you keep (really interesting the decision you have between keep cards and spending money you will need). Once you have new cards the action phase, there you can build greeneries, cities, oceans, projects, claim to be the first to achieve something....
Also like how the cards work, you have your own board with 6 different productions, and many times you have to focus on one, or play with all of them, reduce one to increase another, then decrease the latter to increase a third one....
Must say that is a tactical game, you can plan a bit ahead, but not on the long term, you have to adapt to what you get while can focus on something, but be aware that you could not get the appropriate cards (random? no, you can play and win perfectly not depending on the cards, unless you are expecting one specific card... then the game will be random for you).
Liked how everything flows and is implemented, the decision on how to spend my money, where to focus my VP generation, should I go for a big money production or go better for energy, or do that with the steel...
While my games be under that 120 mins frame, is hard to tear down a game

RATING: 8
I really love this game right now even though it has some problems. Terraforming Mars feels like a puzzle. Sometimes there are clearly right and wrong choices, sometimes you have to just do the math and figure out which cards you want to play. And I like that. In the earlier turns everything is a lot more open ended and it's about trying to find a strategy and/or making the most out of the cards that you have. This is why I like the corporation cards; they give you a direction but don't necessarily force you down that path. Later on is when you try to focus on your gameplan, maximize the points you can get and the game feels more solvable. 

The problem with Terraforming Mars is that, in my opinion, it has to be played a certain way too shine. The box says it plays 1-5 players but I would only recommend playing this game with either 3 or 4 people. The Corporate Era is a must. Drafting is a must as well, it gives you more options and reduces the luck of the draw. 
Other issues mostly have to do with the components. There is no insert, the art on the cards can vary in quality and tone and the player mats are kinda cheap. One wrong move and the cubes will slide all over the place. 

Despite this I've played a lot of Terraforming Mars and I'm looking forward to playing it some more.

RATING: 10
Edit: this is the sleeper hit of 2016. 

Further edit: Game of the Year.

Scythe is the hyped hit of the year; SeaFall is the genre-breaking hit of the year; Terraforming Mars is otherwise the most unexpected winner. Every medium-to-heavyweight gamer should own it.

An exquisite resource-management, engine-building game, with a compelling theme and a satisfying level of production. The cards are colorful and a joy to look at. The iconography makes sense. The board is clear.

Overall, the only things I want are (a) more cards (expansion!) and (b) to play the other side of Mars (expansion!).

Very high replayability.

RATING: 9

RATING: 9
Interesting and thematic eurogame that mashes together many commonly seen mechanisms. 

Primarily a card-driven game, though there's also tile placement, resource management, and engine building.

The game gets shorter (not necessarily quicker) with more players, which gives it a bit of tension, as you try to get your card and resource production engine working before your opponents close out the game (maxing oxygen, oceans, and temperature parameters).

I find the solo-variant quite good, as you race to max the 3 parameters within a set number of turns.  

Components-wise, the board looks great and the metallic cubes look "cool".  The card art is sort of a mixed bag, though isn't really an issue.  I will agree with the masses and say that the player boards can sometimes be problematic.  The plastic cubes are quite slick and can be bumped off of their tracks easily, leaving you wondering where they came from.

Overall, a very solid game.  Always enjoy playing this with the group or solo, and can't wait for expansions.

RATING: 10
Ausgezeichnetes Spiel: elegant designed, variantenreich, starkes Thema. Wunderbare Mischung aus Engine-Builder und Rennspiel. Langfristige Planung ist ebenso wichtig wie das Erkennen kurzfristiger Gelegenheiten. Besonders gut gefallen mir die vielen Wege zum Sieg die es gibt: Städte- und Waldbau, Tierentwicklung, Weltraumereignisse und Titan, Hausbau über Stahl, Meilensteine und und und. Dazu eine aufgeräumte Regel ohne große Ausnahmen oder schrägen Sonderfällen. 

Für 10/10 reicht es trotzdem nicht, denn das Material ist angesichts eines Preises von 60€ suboptimal: die Playercubes sind nicht plan und verrutschen sehr leicht, die Ressourcencubes stoßen sich recht schnell ab. Auch die Spieldauer ist mit 2.5h an der oberen Grenze.

Trotzdem: exzellentes Spiel und der beste Titel im Herbst 2016.

Nachtrag: Habe die Bewertung nach fast 20 Spielen nun doch auf 10 Punkte gehoben denn mittlerweile hat sich gezeigt, *wie* gute die Mischung aus taktisch kurzfristigen Entscheidungen und langer strategischer Linie in TM funktioniert. Die Variante mit Karten-Drafting erlaubt es wirklich, sich eine Plan zurecht zu legen und diesen dann durchzuziehen. Das Spiel zeigt dabei eine enorme Belastbarkeit hinsichtlich der unterschiedlichen Spielweisen. Ich habe mittlerweile Partien erlebt, in denen zB Spieler die massiv auf Waldbau spielten und solche die fast ohne auskamen, am Ende genau 1 Punkt auseinander waren.  Und das bei einem Spiel, das 100% ohne Catchup. Mechanismen auskommt. Grandios

Neues Fazit: Bestes anspruchsvolles Spiel 2016.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I was highly impressed with my single play of this game and very much look forward to playing again. The theme is appealing to me as a sci-fi fan in general, but this has a much more "serious" feel than games like Cosmic Encounter, Alien Frontiers, or Starfarers. In fact, by its very nature, many of the mechanics are based on real-life anticipated requirements to terraform Mars. Certainly there are things you can do that border on flights of fancy, but everything is at least plausible. 

I was somewhat reminded of Agricola in how the cards are used. The synergies with each other and with your starting player power will provide opportunities to be very efficient with your point scoring, but they do not railroad you into doing certain things either. You will want to do lots of different things, but will be limited by the resources/money that you have, rather than by the number of "workers". 

Terraforming Mars is interactive without being cutthroat, engine-building without rote accounting, and science-based without being afraid to dream big. Those aspects are all very appealing to me. This one is a winner.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terraforming Mars is a thematic engine building game focused on future efforts to colonize Mars and to make it Earth habitable.

Players represent corporations trying radically change Martian conditions of temperature, moisture/surface water and amospheric oxygen levels.

Funds are granted them based on their success in terraforming efforts (VPs), and this resource also can be increased, along with other basic resources needed.

All efforts to reshape Mars are measured on a common board- while it isn't worker placement per se, other players can beat you to meeting desired goals.

Game end conditions at all player counts are the same: complete the tracks marking terraforming goals on the Red Planet.

All this makes for a very tasty mix of race/tableau building game, with low to moderate interaction and a solid theme.

Great new game- it has been on and off my radar since I first noted it, and I'm glad I picked it up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my now favorite games.  Excellent replayability, and one of those rare games that I want to immediately replay after finishing a game.  One gripe I have is that player tokens can shift on the player mats, but Broken Token's insert solved that.

The solo version of this game is quite the puzzle, especially when first learning.  I initially found winning impossible, but after a few rounds got the hang of it and win more than lose, and play for high score.  

Excellent game design, and with a huge stack of cards this game finds itself on the table quite a bit.  Here's looking forward to a "deluxe" version that upgrades the components (I can dream, can't I?).

RATING: 8
First play impressions: 
Rulebook is text-heavy but clear.  A bit difficult the first round but after that it was very clear and straightforward how to play.  Card text is some of the most clear and precise I've seen.  Use of the 1/5/10 resource cubes is actually simple and elegant and removes the need for a ton of bits.

2-player was long - 2.5 hours.  I imagine we can get it down to 2 hours but probably not less.  I wish the handling of the end-game conditions were a bit more ... elegant.  It just ends whenever it ends, with more of a whimper than a shout - the least epic part of the game actually.

The components - rule book actually fell apart first game.  Those play mats are as bad as everyone says.  The card art - meh, whatever.

We liked it and were definitely engaged enough to play again but it would really benefit from a better arc and tighter play.    

Second Play: Improved our impression and increased to 8.  Used the variant to speed up progression, but since we were more aware of the strategy and used card drafting, it still took 2.5 hours.  Simply speeding up the game made the ending a bit tighter as we had less choice of when to end the game.

RATING: 9
Theme drew me to this game when the first teaser images went up on FryxGames' website.  By the time I got my copy in September of 2016, my hype meter was off the charts.  I can safely say, this game met my expectations and then some. 

It as an excellent fusion of theme and mechanics.  It captures a sense of eagerness and racing against the other players as we perform all manner of actions from science fiction and science fact.  In one game, I was carefully cultivating plants and building cities.  In another, I was gleefully smashing asteroids into the planet and deploying space mirrors to increase my energy budget.  The game is intimidating at first glance with all the cubes, tiles and cards, but players quickly learn it is quite simple mechanically and find a steady groove pretty easily.  I keep thinking about the games I have played and the potential in future games, which is always a good sign for the longevity of a game.

Above all, though, it's the strong theme that captures my imagination.  If you are at all intrigued by the concept of this game, you should certainly give it a try.  You won't regret it.

RATING: 6.99
It has a similar thematic feel to Roll for the Galaxy in that you are building cards which grant benefits, there are two forms of additional currency related to building cards.

It appears more interactive because there is a board [Mars] that everyone is building tiles on. It looks like this would prevent the game from being a personal solitaire game, but it actually does not. You spend 90% of your time staring at your cube generating board and set of drafted cards. Sometimes turn order plays a huge part in who accomplishes what first, and sure, looking at what other people draft can affect what you should [hate] draft. But er no I amend my previous viewing; Puerto Rico feels far more interactive with its role selection than anything in Terraforming Mars.

Drafting is definitely the way to play this game--that way someone can win because of the draft, not because they "got lucky" drawing cards. However the first time a new player plays, drafting may be a bit counter-productive. Hard to know what is "valuable" and what you should not draft as a new player doesn't know what cards exist. ALL of the cards have different text. To actually keep the card in your hand [after drafting], you have to pay 3money/card, so you can't keep everything. 

There are three end-game timers; after all of them are completed, the game end is triggered: building oceans, temperature, and oxygen levels. These tracks only advance and some cards have the requirement that "oxygen level must be 4% or less" or "temperature must be 4 degrees or warmer" which puts this timing element into play as well.

Lots of neat sciency stuff.
Weird stock art on the cards that wildly differs in quality.
Not the kind of game I would pick for spending 2 hours of time on, but if everyone else REALLY wanted to play this I would play it.

RATING: 10
This is a truly outstanding game and deserves all the praise it is getting. The depth and variety of strategy is immense and the designers really knew how to make it all come together for a great experience. The only downside is the game playing time, with new players you need to expect a four player game to last a good 3 to 5 hours, so make sure you allocate enough time for it. There is a faster variant if you remove some of the cards, but I've not tried that yet. If you have a free afternoon and some friends who like some heavier strategy/economy, get them to come to mars!

A side note - this game is improved by about 100% by purchasing some accessories, specifically the overlays or holders for the materials sheets. The cubes have a habit of going everywhere and then you suddenly don't know what your production is, so I highly recommending spending a little extra money on 5 overlays from one of the various producers out there to make the game hugely easier to play.

RATING: 10
Terraforming Mars gameplay is so solid and well balanced that it makes up in spades for the terribly low quality components, but those same components also serve as a reminder of how this game was motivated by a great design idea despite the low budget. An example of what Kickstarter is really about, not of the likes of the CMON petulant marketing and gimmicks. The game has endless replayability and even though you will inevitably prefer certain cards to others, you will never win by trying to force a certain strategy, rather, it's all about adaptability. In this game, wins whoever will make the most of the cards given to him and plays with the most efficiency. No game yet has given me a more rewarding feeling of seeing your engine build and grow. The pace of the game is perfect and the game ending triggers are there for all to see and give you a clear idea of when the game will likely come to a close which avoids sudden, anti-climatic game endings of the likes of Scythe or Viticulture. The player interaction is just enough and it's not too aggressive, many cards allow to choose wether to remove certain resources or not and the map tile placement provides for solid interaction and requires you to adapt your strategy based on others decisions.

RATING: N/A
Never been more disappointed after opening a box than with this one...  After reading nothing but good reviews on gameplay, I was expecting the finish of the game to live up to it too.
Alas... a big box filled with a lot of air, a gameboard that is smaller than the base of the box, lots of cards but nothing to put them in once they're unpacked, lots of shiny tokens of which the metallic paint comes of at the corners, player mats that are as flats as the 16th century earth which means that you loose all track if someone accidently hits the table.
So NO insert at all!  Just throw everything ad random into the box when done playing.  Don't bother storing you box upright, on the side or even topsy turvy 'cause it won't matter: it'll be a mess anyway.
Would a simple piece of plastic insert, really have costed that much?
For someone who cares a lot for the wellbeing of his games; either prepare yourself to throw some extra dough at an insert for this or better not buy it at all (in this version that is).

RATING: 8
I have played 3 games with 3, 2, and 5 players.  I love the presentation here: game board design, shiny cubes, and the awesome cards.  The game has powerful theme - I feel like we are all leading corporations implementing terraforming projects.  The card play is very compelling with very interesting effects to the game state, cool flavor text, and awesome combo opportunities.  Playing Terraforming Mars reminds me a lot of Race for the Galaxy, one of my favorite games.  I will criticize my new cardboard darling:  This game takes a little bit longer in time to play than I would otherwise prefer and I am suspicious about the strategy aspect of the game:  I am making many choices, so many different actions I can do.  How balanced are the sundry paths to victory for this game going to feel after many plays?  How much of a factor does the randomness of drawing from so many cards play upon my chances of winning?  I am still learning the finer points of the game.  I cant help feeling like I am playing a drawn out, pretty, attractive version of Race for the Galaxy.  I get a bunch of cards and I have to choose which to play and which to throw away and which sequence to play the cards.  Building an efficient engine - how much of it is clever and how much of it is random?  I am looking forward to deeper examination of this compelling game.  I probably would avoid playing with the full 5 player complement unless all of them were very eager to play and we have a lot of time.

Played again with 5 -- There is very fertile ground in this set of cards to try to win with many different strategies.  We played with drafting every round.  That improves the game quite a bit.  Don't play without drafting :) I love this game, but I would like it even more if it was a little bit shorter in time elapsed.

RATING: 7
This game is overhyped. Yes, it is a strategic, semi-coop, board card game with intelligent, realistic scenography and background story, but the game has three major flaws. It is too much luck-dependent for such a long strategic gameplay, because of too many cards even with card drafting not manageable. Secondly, there is almost no interaction between players, it is that everyone is building something for themselves and you can only destroy something from others with less effect. And the biggest flaw is the price-performance ratio, which is far too low for the offered quality of the game material.
 
To stay fair, I had to play this game again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very pretty theme, but it misses a lot of opportunities. The color scheme and overall design could be much more thematic than it is. It gets a bump for the wonderful choice of resource cubes. I've never enjoyed a game currency more, and I love that the cubes are used to represent denominations of everything in the game. I also love that the cube theme caries through the player tokens, resources, and the sugar cubes that show progress.

Believe the hype! This is a wonderful game. Yes, it takes a few hours, but they don't drag unless you're watching other people play it. It took me a few rounds to nail down the system, and a few games to realize more optimal strategies. There are a lot of possibilities, and there are so many fun little mechanics that may come up through the cards.

RATING: 4
Have to agree with the more critical reviews here. This game is nearly unplayable without drafting. The card-driven production system can prospectively set up an unstoppable engine (be it your own or someone else's) from the beginning and suck the life out of the game...get your luck out of my euros. Precious little feels satisfying, Much too much feels frustrating.

The lack of consistency of the art and the clashing of the photographs, some of which are laughably bad, just annoys me. Much ado has been made about those awful player boards already and the lack of any immersive resource components.

You can see the attempt made to balance out the engine building and the more ameritrash "take that" player conflict, but nothing really adds up. You can mess with your direct neighbor with effective actions from position, maybe. Much more often you are ignoring them because any missed opportunity to build *your engine* is fatal. Recovery is a struggle. Boxed out of projects that play to your corporation? Suffer as you try in vain to branch out to some project you will never draw another card to synergize with again or complete a laughably inefficient standard project.

I repeat, FRUSTRATING. Frustrating to scramble from behind, and frustrating to *win* if you have a cheese factory going.

I know I am hating hard here, but the game is not awful (as long as it is played with veteran eurogamers), it is just one of the biggest disappointments I have experienced in recent history. Irks me that this game would even be mentioned in the same sentence as Scythe, let alone know that the consensus is that people think *that this is better*. Ugh, so salty.

Traded it.

(Edit: Rating revised down for my lack of desire to see this on the table again and as a counter-rating. Hey, at least I admit it.)

RATING: 9
I have owned this game for 4 days now, and between my friends and I it has been played 8 times. Yeah, it's that fun. Each game does take awhile though, so I feel like you have to play with people who can really sit and play longer games without issue. I think it plays best with 4, but have also played with 5 and it wasn't too much slower. Basically the less players the more you as an individual get to do, towards terraform mars. Haven't tried single player, but playing with 4 has been a solid experience. Playing with 3 is also fun, feeling a bit more fast paced.

In terms of build quality the board is great. The pieces for currency (gold silver bronze cubes) seem a little cheap, as the corners started to chip after our first game, but otherwise they're fine. The player mats also work perfectly fine, contrary to what some people might say about needing an overlay or something of that sort. If your group is careful and you warn everyone about knocking over their player mats, you probably wont have any problems. Knocking player boards and messing up production cubes was my biggest worry when playing, but I found that in all 8 of my games I've had 0 problems with friends knocking their stuff around. That being said, if you have the extra money lying around, the acrylic overlays being sold on etsy and etc are super nice, and would make a nice addition.

Overall this is probably one of the best board games I've played to date, and would recommend to anyone who can take longer games. Every person I've played it with so far has loved it.
