=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Juego de gestión de recursos ambientado en el desarrollo del planeta Marte.

Cada jugador resulta ser una corporación que recibe una serie de proyectos (cartas) que deberá adquirir pagando dinero para conservar en mano y construir posteriormente.

Una vez construidos algunos de estos proyectos tendrán efecto una única vez, otros representarán edificios que deberá colocar sobre la superficie de Marte (los menos) otros representarán "mejoras tecnologías", el caso es que estos proyectos irán combando entre sí potenciando las acciones del jugador durante del turno que realmente son muy pocas, aquí la chicha está en las cartas y en como gestionar los recursos. Por otro lado, para que no sea solo mirarse cada uno lo suyo, las cartas podrán afectar al jugador que la pone en marcha o al resto (según el tipo)

Además el juego te propone varios métodos adicionales de puntación basados en llegar el primero a unos objetivos que previamente han sido seleccionados por los usuarios, no estando disponibles todos, sino los que los jugadores compran, haciendo aqui dos diferencias entre unos de tipo lo compro y es para mi y otros que son del tipo los compro y al final del juego el que más tenga de esto se lleva los puntos.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Amazing, this game is amazing. The theme of the game is that every player takes control of one of the corporations that arrive in Mars at the same time (what a coincidence!) with the objective of terraforming Mars (as the name already indicates, well done Javi). The final objective of the game is, generation after generation, which is represented by every turn (how cool is that?), to improve the live conditions of the planet, which is done when the temperature gets to 8ºC, the oxygen percentage gets to 14% and the nine ocean tiles are in play. One those 3 conditions are fulfilled, the current round is considered as the last one. The players are allowed to continue playing as if a normal turn, but the end means the end of the game. The player with most terraforming points, wins the game.
The core of the game are the cards, which is a extremely valuable asset. They game uses a mechanic that it works perfectly, that consists on, every turn, the players take four cards from the pile, and they have to decide how many of those are going to keep in hand (0-4), but you have to pay 3 credits (MEuros), so you have to sacrifice something. And, at the end of the game be aware that you will run low on cards. 
Those cards are highly thematic, I am not completely sure if there are many duplicated cards, but the feeling is that every card is unique, there are combos that can be achieved, there are restrictions for playing certain type of cards, for instance, you cannot put big animals over the surface of the planet until a certain temperature has been achieved... it works, it just makes sense, it is very fun, you want to build/pay every single card that comes into hand but you do not have that many resources
The second interesting mechanic is the tile allocation on the board. Basically, 3 types of tiles can be put on the table: cities, forests and oceans. There are other unique locations that are related to cards that are explained on the card. Every tile has its advantages, its way of providing points and the way of allocating, for instance, you cannot put 2 cities together, setting a forest increases the oxygen percentage, putting a tile beside an ocean provides 2 credits...
Regarding the game itself, the best of it are the cubes. They come with a set of gorgeous cubes for the economics, I don't now the game is amazing, so many things...
But the best is, when the game is finished, you don't feel that it has been a long game and you want to play more, you want to try other combos, try to go more into factories, or biological research, or asteroids... so much fun!
Positive:
1. Very fun
2. The amount of unique cards
3. How thematic it is
4. The cubes
5. Many strategies are possible
6. The game seems to be very well balanced
Negative:
1. I would not play with more than 3 players. The duration of the game should be always more or less the same, but with 4 or 5 players you will not have time to develop a complete industrial structure
2. The player boards. If you have not bought the small wooden board that had the squares carved and that immobilize perfectly the cubes, you have to be very careful not kicking the table or whatever, because you can lose track of the production

RATING: 9
Terraforming Mars is a great game that seems to appeal to everyone.  Its theme is well implemented and the art and the components really make it live.  The game mechanics also work well.  Basically you start with a hand of cards and some income and your goal is to earn victory points by improving the three critical terraforming parameters of open water, temperature, and oxygen content.  You can also get victory points by playing cards that provide some kind of benefit to Mars (and yourself).  Your goal is to build up an engine, accumulating cards that provide powerful synergies and increasing your income of various important resources, while racing to accumulate victory points.  There are many routes to victory and you need to consider all of them since you are constrained by the cards coming into your hand.  You also have to constantly weigh spending money to keep more cards versus spending money to play the cards you already have.  This is a game of shiny where all the cards are great and you are always slavering to get the newest one out.  At the same time there is an interesting area control game going on the planet where you are laying down tiles to represent seas, forests, cities, and special sites.  You can accumulate a lot of points with well-placed cities and forests so you need to keep an eye on the board and to leap on opportunities when they present themselves.  There are also milestones and awards that your compete for that also keep the tension high.  Even when it's not your turn, it keeps you engaged as you monitor what your competition is doing.  Overall the game length and complexity feel just about right and I always end with a feeling of satisfaction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Terraforming Mars hits many of the right notes for fans of engine-building games. It is a straightforward game to teach, leaving the players to discover the complexity and depth of options through the encounters with the cards. Through many rule variations and paths to victory, it provides a great bit of variety in the box. While the presentation is functional but forgettable and sometimes the randomness of the card draw or event cards can be frustrating, there are enough interesting decisions and interactions to make it worthy of the praise it has received.

RATING: 4
Boring to me and doesn't feel like I am really terraforming Mars. Maybe in an abstract sense, or maybe I am being too hard on it. It feels like Race for the Galaxy a bit in the card buildup but goes on for hours instead of closer to a filler. I get that it makes it more of an epic feel but it also just gets draggy.

Options rapidly dwindle as the game goes on and you are fishing for point cards and playable spaces on Mars grind down to a halt between illegal plays or helping others. If the temp/oxygen tracks are max'd, you don't get credit for advancing them, thus limiting your options even further.  In the late game, did you happen to draw/draft scoring cards? Hooray! You didn't? Don't expect to win, because many of the cards are mostly useless at that point and whoever did draw scoring cards will get a nice point swing on you. Maybe keep a couple of big cards early for the late game, even though it costs you money up front.

Thematically, I never felt like I was terraforming Mars. It's mostly a card game, ala RftG, Why reinvent the wheel?

RATING: 8.5
2016-10-30

Initial Rating: 7.0 (October 2016)

I was very keen to play Terraforming Mars. It was the best game at Essen 2016 , so I had a healthy skepticism due to hype and I was right. The game is good but nothing earth shattering. In general, hype have killed many games for me, it is much better to have a neutral expectation so I can better gauge the game, sadly, many times that is not possible.

The game components are ok. Every copy I have seen (over 6) had the flimsy insert broken. The resource cubes look amazing, but they peel off rather easily. In my copy, the cards came warped. The player´s boards are very flimsy. In general, as is usual from Stronghold Games, the production values aren’t great, but they are good enough.

The theme is fascinating, one of my favorites and the cards and flavor text convey it very well.

Terraforming Mars can accommodate up to 5 players, but in that case the downtime is way too much for me. I won’t ever again play it with 5, I feel it is much better as a 3 player game. It also has a solo mode which is great for people who like to play alone (I don’t ever).

Terraforming Mars has meaty decisions (a huge plus for me). You can buy project cards, play project cards, fund an award, claim a milestone, create a greenery, raise the temperature. The game comes with many project cards and you have to purchase them before you can use them so you have to plan carefully, the idea is to get cards that have a lot of synergy between them. There is some luck of the draw with the cards but I feel it is totally controllable, you can still do a lot without projects but that cost a lot of money. In general, you have to carefully manage the 6 resources to get the better outcome, it is a lot of fun. 

I particularly like the award mechanism. To activate it, you have to spend money and it will give VPs to the player who most have the condition, the catch is that you have to activate when playing the game and the VPs are awarded at the end of the game, so when an award is active players begin to compete fiercely to be first. In our game, all the players who funded the awards lost their first position in the relevant award, thus, expending a lot of money for the benefit of their opponents :devil:. 

Terraforming Mars is an Euro game with a mean streak (a minor dislike for me), there are some attack cards that can really set you back, fortunately, I feel the game is balanced because playing them is usually expensive. I LOVE (thematically) that you can plunge a whole moon into Mars :D.

I have only played with basic corporations, I’m very keen on trying the advanced cards! 

Bottom line, Terraforming Mars is a good engine building game with plenty of non-obvious decisions. My desire to play it again is very high and it is a keeper in my game collection. 

Current Rating: 7.5
[hr]
2017-06-26

I finally played with the corporations and I liked them a lot :D. I really like the idea of having some unique advantages and using the corporations adds to the replayability. I hope and expect they are balanced, but I have played too few times to really know.

The card quality is very bad, the cards themselves get mark very easily. You need to sleeve them ASAP.

RATING: 9
Mostly played it solo so far, but that's a real blast!
I'm not even sure why I enjoy it so much, except for very suspenseful build-up: Usually, it's a very close call to successfully terraform, with most of the 'real work' getting done in the last two turns.

It's been a while since I played a game that I immediately wanted to play again after finishing a game. And I find myself thinking about the game long after it's finished, too, wondering how I might have played better.

The only thing that slightly mars the experience are several cards that are useless for the solo game. So, it's possible to be unlucky and have a really bad start.
But if it wasn't for that, it would likely be too easy to win.

Multiplayer is a different experience, but easily as enjoyable. Timing your actions now becomes a lot more important, and since you don't know exactly when the game will end, it gets a lot harder to calculate if playing a particular card will be worth it or not.

RATING: 8
A tableau-building game with interactivity driven by board positioning and the acquisition of resources from the terraforming tracks.  Despite the exceptionally attractive (to me) theme, the game would not shine without the variability provided by the over 200 cards representing upgrades and events that can occur to the player's corporation.

While the game is certainly not "streamlined" like Race for the Galaxy, it provides a similar feel with interlocking and sometimes synergistic card powers providing dynamism to what would otherwise be a stodgy eurogame base.

This game will not reach the heights for me that more complex eurogames might, but it is more broadly approachable and still provides me a very good gaming experience, so I am likely to end up playing it more than other 2016 releases.

Recommended with drafting variant.

RATING: 9
First off I need to preface this with the fact that we thoroughly enjoy playing this game and will continue to play it - with our own rule set.  Update:  Drafting rules solved many of the problems described below for 2 player games

For one of the top rated games (6th overall at the time of writing), I was unpleasantly surprised at how imbalanced the gameplay is.  After spending  7-8 hours with the game we began to realize, at least with 2 players, that one player would end up running away with the game. By hour 12 we could pick out by generation 4 who was going to win.  

It's a great game at it's core and has a lot of possibility but there are a few fatal flaws.  Lack of and expense of negative effects to other players, over powered cards like 'pay 1 energy to draw a card', and ease/lack of reason to terraform are just some of the glaring issues with the game.  Terraforming felt almost incidental - a side effect of resource management rather than something to strive for.  

In addition, many of the mechanics are underdeveloped/underused, animals/microbes & restrictions based on terraforming levels in particular, and even with the Corporate Era cards the game is often over too soon.  

A final, minor, quibble is that with 2 player games there is a lack of player markers.  We'd frequently run out of player markers of a given colour and the copper/silver/gold markers come chipped out of the box. 

Overall, I would still play it and recommend it, despite the problems.

RATING: 8
It's a simple game with a complex web of levers and point sources manipulated through card play. The cards are used to generate or modify 6 resource types, which are used to create greenery and oxygen and to pay for more cards. Cards are either one-time powerful events, business endeavors which provide additional actions or modifiers, or terraforming achievements which provide a single benefit, but continue to affect later cards according to the matching icons. When Mars has enough heat, oxygen and water to sustain life, the game ends.

I like this more than Race for the Galaxy, the gold standard in icon-driven tableau-building. I feel like Race ends just when it's getting going, while in Terraforming Mars strategies and changes in strategy have enough time to mature and evolve. The board play and resource management all give this one a lot more meat to the bones. I passed on Race a long time ago, but I think I'll keep this one around for a while.

RATING: 5
Largely indirect, engine-building, card combo game. Felt very MPS to me. Surprisingly random for such a highly touted game. The rest of the game is when to play them which is largely determined by how much money you have at the time.

RATING: 6
The new hotness, rapidly rising up the BGG list just three weeks after its initial US release in late September.  Have played 8 times already, and predict that the newness will probably wear off after 6-9 months or so.  Positives:  interesting, unique theme, card-driven with a couple of unique elements but nothing you haven't seen before.  On the negative side, the outcome seems highly luck dependent unless you use a drafting variant which will certainly add to playing time.  To date, I have mostly avoided the longer Corporate game also due to concerns about playing time, as 1 1/2 to 2 hours for the base game seems about right, length in terms of number of rounds depends on the # of players, fewer players means more rounds to hit the three endgame criteria.  Most games have lasted 12-N or 11-N rounds, N being the number of players.  (I.e., a five-player game will generally take 6 or 7 rounds), so this makes planning for the endgame a bit easier.

Overall, this is a solid game that will remain popular until the next new hotness comes along, probably in a month or two when the Essen titles hit the States.  So, right now a solid 7 but frankly don't see it getting much higher.

EDIT:  My prediction, at least for me, has come true.  I haven't played the game for over a month now and don't see any urge to rush to play it again.  I think other new releases, in particular Great Western Trail, the new Tesla vs Edision and Manhattan Project:  Energy Empire are much more interesting.

RATING: 6
I honestly don't get what the fuzz is all about - especially among many hard core players. Yes the combos are nice, but as a Magic TG player I can say: "That don't impress me much." It is definitely lacking new or special mechanisms. Drafting and card combos? I expect more of a game that won several gaming prices. 
It's not like it has innovative and complex, but also interconnected mechanisms like Great Western Trail that offer a great variety of strategic options! 

Just to be clear: It's not a bad game. It's pretty decent - but nothing special. But I was so much looking forward to it and (because I am a big fan of this theme) such I had so high expectations that the downfall was great - that's why I kind of dislike it now. But (on contrary to most critics) I do like the artwork. That's a plus. 

Also, it gets too random and disbalanced with the card / combos. With drafting it takes too long. Best choices are obvious. For what TM is and what it wants to be there a definitely better options on the market. 

To sum up I like to quote the user "adrim" whose comment gives you a pretty good overview. 

The good:
+ the theme
+ card combos (if you are lucky to get the right cards at the right time)

The bad:
- there is no way to search the deck, so you have to play whatever you happen to get
- luck factor is very high
- choices are obvious
- the game plays it self
- to long for what it is
- low replay value
- low quality components

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Terraforming Mars will be one of the hits of Spiel 2016, if not the hit game itself. And justifiably so. Given the record of FryxGames so far and first reports of cards with take-that elements, I wasn't expecting too much. But the ongoing discussion and many positive comments got me interested. After playing it, I regret it a bit that I didn't preorder.

Players try to build up an engine granting them some benefit to help in transforming Mars. Three elements are needed to achieve this: oxygen, increasing temperature and water. The variable game end sets in when all three tracks are maxed out. The game is in the cards. Players have to process a lot of information each turn, resulting in plenty of different possibilities  to gain victory points. Focus on some kind of resource, raise animals, build on the board. Not everything can be done but something should be done well. Achievements and milestones can tip the scales. Unless screwage is focused on a single player, it doesn't hurt too much.

An original game with a unique feel. Making the best out of what you're dealt is a satisfying puzzle. Replayability is guaranteed due to the mass of cards and individualized starting positions when all game elements are used. Building up the engine is multiplayer solitaire with some potential for doing mistakes or clumsily deranging the player board. Activities on the board and the joint progress on the three tracks bring the players together again in competition.

RATING: 8
The design of the game mechanics and the replayability of this game are incredible, and would get a 9 from me, but the component quality, particularly the player boards are of such cheap design and material that it's disgusting for the price of this game. The player boards that come in the boxes actually take away from the quality of playing the game as any bump of the table or a stray shirt sleeve, and your resources are sliding all over. 

Highly recommend getting a storage solution such as the one from Broken Token, as the storage trays double as replacement player boards and making keeping track of all of your various resources much easier and prevent pieces from scattering. 

All that said, it is an extremely fun and well designed game.

RATING: 5
2017-08-15 - 6 - It's an OK game, but nothing spectacular. Multiplayer solitare engine building game, where at the end of the game you try to throw on the table every card you happen to have in hand (what leads to lack of interesting decisions because you can afford everything). I prefer GWT or Ora et Labora if I need to play a little heavier rather non-interactive eurogame.
This one misses some spark, although it's fine and I can play it from time to time. The theme is pretty strong through most of the game, what is always a plus for me. 
It could last a little shorter.
Awards mechanism is pretty cool.

2017-11-28 - 6->5 - It's way too long! I played without corporation cards and special corporation powers and it still was very long multiplayer solitare, where everyone was focused only on their cards or their playerboard. Interaction is realy weak part in this game, because you really don't care what others do for 90% of time or - haha, you just lost your resources, because of someone else's card.
I don't get the hype. I got it that it's a proper working game, which many maight enjoy, but number 6 on BGG? No way. There is nothing original or unique here.

Play Race for the Galaxy instead. Quicker, more fun, more interesting interaction, still tableau building game in space. Not to mention better artwork.

RATING: 7
Terraforming Mars is a sandbox with a straightjacket, because you have a lot to do but restrained by your resources and cards. This game is all about variety and it is a good game, but not for my taste. Some thoughs: the game is long, 3 hours with 3 players (only one noob, myself); the game feels repetitive, because you perform the same things turn to turn and it is possible to run your engine several times that you get tired of it; randomness is kind of high, because all  the cards are different you can or can't make a combo based purely on luck; misplaced Take That, a game with such amount of strategy and duration has cards that allows the player to destroy/steal resources from other players, makes no sense to me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first play of this was good, I enjoyed it but wasn't super impressed, but after my second game where we played with the drafting variant I knew I have to get a copy of this game. The drafting of cards is probably the *only* way I'll play this game now, even with new players. It's an engine/tableau builder so getting cards that synergize with your engine is paramount and seeing your actions combo is what makes this game so satisfying. I'm surprised that it seems to have been such a universal hit, I was definitely underwhelmed on my first play but still found it enjoyable, glad it got so much better with the drafting of the cards.

I do wish there was a more interaction than where to place things on the board and the "take that" actions to take away plants from people really feel a but tacked on. The drafting adds a bit of interaction where you can deny cards to opponents, but I hope the planned expansions add more interactive elements to the game. I would also echo the sentiments about the art in the game, the card art switching styles is very amateurish.

Overall, the gameplay is very smooth and really enjoy the thematic purpose of all the cards and actions in the game. It's pretty easy for new players to grasp and players are often executing good card power combinations in their first game.

RATING: 9
Played 3+ player games twice, played solitaire game five times.

Great engine builder.  Because of how much money you are getting in the end game, you don't have that "ends too soon" feeling like you get with other games.
You'll get that giddy delight seeing your engine or combo start taking off and reaping its rewards.

Solitaire is fun, but not worth the price of admission alone.

Rulebook is.... ugh.  Check for better fan-made rulebooks and resource materials.  Once the game gets going though, it flows nicely, with the only thing you will probably forget are increasing your TF rating when you increase oxygen/water/temp.

The game may feel like a luck of the draw however, so fans may implement a variant to increase the odds of getting what you want.

RATING: 9.9
Holy moly, this is the first game I've owned that I've sat down with someone to play every night for about a week straight. Also my first game to sit down play a game, and immediately play another one.  And after 21 plays I'm still excited to play another one.  This game has you trying to perfect your economy of 6 different resources while also doing a bit of area control on the planet of mars. Ultimately the goal is to have most TR(VP) but there seems to be quite a few different ways to achieve it. I feel as someone very comfortable with the game I could teach it in 20 min or so. The game "clicks" within first 4 turns.  Stronghold has said they intend to release 2-3 expansions in 2017 and I am dying for them so I get even more reason to play this game.  Medium game, takes a little longer than an hour if you have 2 players who really know the game, else it's normally hour and a half to two hours. Worth your time and money to get this game!

My first eurogame in collection. Nice to play. Very interesting decisions, and pleasant play.

Terraformacja Marsa, chyba nie ma planszówkowicza, który nie słyszałby o tej grze. Gra ma swoje ewidentne zalety: Jak na eurosuchara ma całkiem niezły klimat, który objawia się tym, że wszystkie akcje mają naukowy sens. Jest bardzo prosta do wytłumaczenia i całkiem przyjemna do zagrania. Z minusów, trzeba napisać o jakości planszetek i nierównej jakości grafik, choć szczerze mówiąc mi gra podoba się bardzo. Nie jest to poziom hitów od FFG, jednak rozłożona na stole nie przestraszy jak niektóre inne gry euro. Z czystym sercem polecam, chyba, że jesteś zdeklarowanym ameritrashowcem z alergią na euro, wtedy najprawdopodobniej nawet tego nie przeczytasz :)

RATING: 8
I didn’t think I’d like this game much. I was dead wrong. According to its most ferocious critics, TM is defined as a low interaction, under produced, overly expensive cube-pusher-euro that’s also full of randomness. And while not entirely accurate, there’s some truth to this statement. Yet, in spite its flaws, I’m obsessed with it. It quickly became one of my favorite games ever. My affection for TM is comes from many places: its butter smooth gameplay feels exciting and tense every step of the way, kinda like a race, where you get to build your own ship and watch it fly (or stumble) across the galaxy as you wave your enemies goodbye. This process has a very tangible sense of buildup and progression, that translates visually onto the board and your player mat; and while your choices are plenty, you never feel overwhelmed. The amazing card system provides emergent depth, so learning is a breeze, but it will take some plays until some of its most refined subtleties unveil themselves. I don’t consider this game to be too long, because I barely notice time passing. 

In a world full of trading in the Mediterranean, the Terraforming Mars has one of the most refreshing and enticing themes to date. When I introduced my friends to Agricola they said “Who wants to be a farmer anyway?” which is valid criticism. And even if what your doing here is basically being a farmer on Mars, the game makes you feel like your doing grand  things. 

Based on its design, I rate TM a 9. But the game has two critical flaws: the player mats and the art on the cards. The player mats are so bad it’s hard to believe they went with it. I had to buy those acrylic overlays, which pushed the game cost > 100€. And this is **not** a 100€ game. This feels almost revolting, especially since there are games out there with AMAZING quality of components and overall care in production such as Scythe and even Inis. The single most used component in the game is the player mat. And in this game this is a thin sheet of paper, that requires you to have the skill of a surgeon in order to maneuver properly. This single aspect could detract potential buyers from getting the game.

The art on the cards is barely serviceable. You get a mix of pictures and paintings that make no sense together. Some images just feel like you googled “Team building exercice 99”, or “Sweet white dog”. Quite honestly some of it is laughable. However, I was able to ignore this part of the game that annoyed me. Which is a different case regarding the player mats, which made the game unplayable for me.

The art on the tiles is serviceable, the board is fine but sub-par, the resource cubes are amazing but chip easily. I do like the box art, although the box itself is very flimsy. 

This feels like the world’s most precious flower in a 1 dollar vase. But it’s a truly amazing experience, and I’m so so happy to have this on my shelf. 

Will make a video review soon.

RATING: 6
[size=12][b]Top 200 board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Terraforming Mars:[/b][/size]
+ The game has a good theme
+ The game has decent replayability
+ The game requires meaningful decisions to win the game. 
+ I am not a fan of pure card drafting games so the other mechanics and the game board kept me engaged for a large number of plays. I definitely prefer this game over games like 7 Wonders. 

[size=12][b]Fixable dislikes in regards to Terraforming Mars:[/b][/size]
/ The player boards are awful if you do not upgrade them.
/ My main criticism of the game is that the game is not balanced for a game about optimization. Some of the corporations are significantly better than others and this is made worse by the blind card draws. The Hellas & Elysium expansion just makes this game worse. After all, changing the awards / map and nothing else is obviously detrimental to the balance of the game. I refuse to play this game unless I get to pick the corporation that I want to play with. I cannot tolerate the randomness of getting bad corporation cards. 
+ The duration of the game is fine with 3 players.

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Terraforming Mars:[/b][/size]
- The game is hard to teach
- The art for the game is awful. 
- Most people do not like letting me choose my corporation because of the balance issues. 

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Sometimes willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 2
Takes forever, but some folks really like it. Not me, I find it too chaotic. The effects are usually spectacular, like crashing a second moon or nuking some part of Mars.
But it takes up a lot of space when playing, you really need the plexiglass overlays for managing your chits - that are NOT present in the game itself. Even for the $80 the makers didn't care for them. 
Gameplay wise: 
The card drafting is very weird especially if you have no idea what is in the deck. So you're just blindly flaying around in the dark on the odd chance you hit some combo. 
I like that you get points for reaching some temperature/oxygen threshold, but everyone is competing with that; I like the bonuses to go for. 
In the end it's just hard to make the cards work for you and for that it takes too long.
It's like Race for the Galaxy the board game plus untold expansions in Race.
I don't hate to play it, but will only choose to play it if there is nothing else. But it certainly does not deserve an 8+. 
If your group likes Innovation, TM is just like that. But far longer.

RATING: N/A
In the 2400s, mankind begins to terraform the planet Mars. Giant corporations, sponsored by the World Government on Earth, initiate huge projects to raise the temperature, the oxygen level, and the ocean coverage until the environment is habitable. In Terraforming Mars, you play one of those corporations and work together in the terraforming process, but compete for getting victory points that are awarded not only for your contribution to the terraforming, but also for advancing human infrastructure throughout the solar system, and doing other commendable things.

I'm enjoying this one quite a bit and have bumped it from 8 -> 9. I really enjoy card games with unique cards and tableau building with a bit of an engine development process. Prefer to play with the draft and the corporations. Have yet to try the advanced deck - perhaps next time. 

I also broke down and picked up the Broken Token insert which is beautiful and works very well. However, expansion boards won't fit so well with the BT insert if that is a concern. Games still take 2-3 hours but I don't think about how long the game is going on as I'm engaged in the process most of the time. I probably will seek to avoid 5 player games if possible. I'm intrigued how different Mars looks after each game. I wish I had taken a photo after each game! I've played a game where there was just 4-5 cities and one forest tile on Mars and the game was over and others where 10-12 cities and 15-20 forest tiles are on the board. 

FIRST IMPRESSION:

I really enjoyed it but I tend to enjoy card games where one builds tableaus and builds a bit of an engine. Did not play draft, but would prefer to going forward. Game production values aren't the best - poor insert, cubes are chipping already, etc. but the game play is excellent. There is obviously luck of the draw in play, but there is generally something one can do every turn. Played with corporations in play.

[u]Comments:[/u]
Holy smokes was this game a bolt lightening from the gaming gods! Ever since playing this game for the first time I have been obsessed with it and played it 2-3 times every week for four months now. One you get past the awful (but functional) graphic design and the amateurish art direction, the game is the best thing that has come out in the past five years, if not the past 10 years. Each game will be unique and there are different setups for those that enjoying playing different styles of games. Almost everyone I have taught this game to has wanted to either a) play it again immediately, or b) asked when they can play it again shortly after playing it. I am so obsessed with TM that I ordered a Broken Token insert for the game before I had even ordered the game.

RATING: 9
In diesem Spiel versuchen die Spieler gemeinsam den Mars bewohnbar zu machen. Es ist aber kein kooperatives Spiel, denn derjenige der es am besten macht gewinnt am Ende.
Wer am Zug führt 1-2 Aktionen durch und dann ist der nächste. Das geht Reihum bis alle spieler gepasst haben.
Aktionen sind Karte ausspielen und bezahlen, Karten vekaufen, Siegpunktprämien beanspruchen, Globale Parmeter erhöhen usw.
Wer am Ende das Meisste dazu beigetragen hat den Mars bewohnbar zu machen gewinnt.
Tatsächlich gab es ein paar knappe Situationen, in denen ich fasst meinen Anspruch auf die Prämie verwirkt hätte, da mein ganzes Geld schon wieder für die Runde aufgebraucht war. Es hat dann aber in der folgenden Runde doch noch geklappt.
Ein Spiel, das man öfter spielen sollte um die Karten und deren Effekte kennenzulernen. Ab der zweiten Partie kann man auch die verschiedenen Konzerne mit integrieren und dann auch die weiteren Karten mit hinzu nehmen. Für Anfänger ist das aber zu schwer, weil sie gleich zu Beginn Karten aus ihrer Starthand auswählen müssen, von deren Nutzen sie aber noch wenig bis keine Ahnung haben.
Mir gefällt das Spiel, allerdings wird es dem Hype darum auch nicht so gerecht wie ich das gedacht hätte. Es macht Spaß und funktioniert reibungslos, aber die Spielertabloes sind lapprig, die Marker darauf verrutschen und ein Inlay hat das Spiel 0,0.

RATING: 8
I myself have been able to play Terraforming Mars ten times and none of these games went the same way. This is mainly due to the number and order in which the projects become available. These projects decide especially in the beginning the actions that you can choose during your turn. The actions on the cards are very balanced compared to their price. It is therefore not possible that a player can immediately immediately increase his production of raw materials without having to submit in other areas. The cards are very diverse, but the final score in our games always seemed to be reasonably close together.

The manual of the game indicates that the game can last an average of 60 to 120 minutes. In our experience this is a bit longer, depending on how long players have to think about which projects they want to execute. In our experience, a game quickly lasted 3 hours, which may be a long time for some players. We found this no problem at all. Because each player can perform a maximum of two actions in succession, there is also very little downtime and waiting time between turns.

The game consists, on the player board, of very good components. During play, it occasionally happens that someone touches their own player board when they take a card or place a tile on the board. Sometimes the cubes are moved too easily and you do not know what your production value was. The system with the cubes for raw materials is very good, but perhaps a plate with relief had been enough to hold the cubes in place.

I like to join if someone asks me to play Terraforming Mars. For me, this is certainly one of the good euro board games of the past year. This game will definitely come out a few times in the coming months. Anyone who gets the chance to play this game should not miss that opportunity!

RATING: 6
Initial Impressions: About as good as I thought it would be: good but way overhyped. It is kind of like Imperial Settlers in that both are tableau builders where you are given a lot of options, and you have to figure out how to chain your cards together in the optimal order, to create a sprawling tableau that makes it difficult (although in this game not as bad as I feared) to tell what your opponents are doing. The differences are here you trade off having unique faction decks (yes the starting corporations are unique but I don't feel like they change up your playstle nearly as much), for tile placement, arbitrary scoring goals (which I don't like as it feels like a very artificial way to grant points) and a more sandboxy feel since you don't keep all your card options. 

There are a lot of different card combos and your starting corporatiom will make certain pathways better, so in that senseI assume there is a lot of replayability. However, the different strategies I sae in my first game all seemed to have a similar chain-like and mad grab for bonuses and points procedure. Despite my doubts if the different strategies actually feel different, I think I would probably find the engine building of this game addicting like Imperial Settlers, albeit the less slick nature of Imperial Settlers being a card game may make this game less so.

Im terms of the theme, they definitely did their research, but I don't know if it was evoked that well in the gameplay. It is kind of the same problem I have with Inis in that a lot of different things are referenced, but they are abstracted to all have similar effects.

Not sure how much luck of the draw plays out. Definitely drawing a card that combos with what you have on the last round can be huge, but perhaps there is enough adaptability that is required that card draw luck before that can be mitigated significantly, like Race for thr Galaxy.

Anyways, if you like modern euros where you are thrown a ton of cogs and have to piece them all togethet into a functioning engine, you will love this game. If you like elegant old school euros (not that this game is super inelegant), or want a strong mars theme, you may be disappointed, although I could see some people who are really into mars disagreeing with me themewise.

EDIT: I don't think the take that cards are that mean, but I still dislike them as they feel like such an artificial way to create interaction and stop a runaway leader.

I honestly don't understand all the people who say the game's components are unplayable without upgrading. Sure, a table knock can really mess up your income stats, but that is not unique to this game and it's easy to remember at least roughly what your stats were.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Its an OK game. I wish there was more player interaction or more mobility to change strategy later on in the game. In games like these the lack of much player interaction is usually made up for by the difficulty of player choice (i.e. that you need to figure out which option is the best for you) but this game does not have that so it comes off as a rather bland Euro.

RATING: 7
My first two plays of this game- a definite 10.  Love the theme and mechanics.

After my third play- 7... maybe 6.

What happened during my third play definitely soured my opinion of this game.  We played the "normal" way with no card drafting (as we had done before). However, this time around my luck was abysmal. For the entire game I was getting very poor cards that did not help me get my engine going. Meanwhile, my opponent (2p game) was getting a ton of cards that perfectly energized with his corporation and strategy (Space corporation- got a ton of cards to boost titanium production, reduce space card costs, etc).  My engine basically languished and I was unable to do much while my opponent took an early lead and snowballed from there.

By the end of the game I was able to get my engine going slightly but I never really had a chance to catch my opponent. He took 2/3 milestones and 3/3 of the awards.  He doubled my score.

I still like this game but I am soured by the experience of getting whooped this badly due to very poor starting cards and other card draws during the game.

I hope this was just very bad luck and not something indicative of a greater problem with this game.

RATING: 9
Someone brought this to this week's Tuesday Night Gaming, and I found it very enjoyable to play. With a variety of strategies on hand, one player was ahead of everyone the entire game in terms of scoring on the score track (did a lot of things to push the conditions of the Mars toward terraforming, but built nothing on Mars), yet came in second in a 5 player game, while the player who was in last place on the score track the entire game, but built lots of cities and projects and forests, and qualifying for rewards... ended up pulling ahead for the win (which happened to be me).

I could see where I might not have quite pulled it off during certain critical turns, or kept the wrong cards, or even played the cards in a less ideal order. 

Everyone seemed to have fun getting there, too. The gameplay was surprisingly fluid and never felt like you got stuck for long, in terms of resources and what you can do with them.

RATING: 7
This was the hot game at one of my local conventions in the Fall of 2016.  I played both the basic and advanced game.  The advanced game is much more interesting.  You start with little income but a unique power for your company that is terraforming mars.  You are playing cards to improve steel, titanium, economic, green or energy capabilities.  There are three tracks for heating the planet, improving oxygen and creating oceans.  The advanced game features card drafting which can make the game run very long for what it is.  The game is solid and with more experienced players the drafting may go more quickly.  I liked the game and would play again, but I don't think it deserves the hype it is getting.  I know that the Dice Tower liked it but I see it as a good 7 game.  Component quality is ok.  I am not keen on the color scheme of the board.  It is not family but it is not too heavy either.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A really good aggro-engine builder game. Competitive, but player interaction is limited to moderately dirty tricks. You can not ruin other player's game, but there is a possibility to snatch some points they were expecting. The mechanism is fun and extremely polished, the rulebook is short and clear. Tile placement complements production(s) and hand managment like charm!
Best thing: The game offers tremendous replayability (more than 30 already accomplished, seems not to loose its momentum). Even italic texts are well invented and enhance the already strong atmosphere greatly. You really feel like a megaconcern gardening on Mars.
Worst thing: player mats could use some rework to hold production marker cubes more firmly. Parts are stylish, but cubes tend to loose some metallized paint.
Drafting method is recommended after the first game! Have fun!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Some of my favorite games are engine building games (Race for the Galaxy, Imperial Settlers, 51st State, Eminent Domain).  So, I was drawn to Terraforming Mars when I heard it was an engine builder with board manipulation thrown in.  A little extra to think about/consider while playing - sounds great!

Play Time:
This is easily a 2-3 hour game, even 2 player.  I don't see the play time dropping much with experience since it takes quite a bit of build up to get an engine going.   Now, don't get me wrong, I don't mind 2-3 hour games.  However, I'm used to knocking out heavier 2 player games in 60-75 mins, at the very most.   Just means this likely won't be a weeknight game and will be competing with a few other games for table time - such as Imperial Assault, Descent, Mombasa, etc.  This is more of a neutral point for me - game time is fine, but makes it a little harder to get to the table.  Luckily, game time doesn't really seem to increase with more players.

Complexity:
TM is definitely a medium weight game.  The rules are very straightforward with only a couple of tiny rules that could be easy to forget or mess up.  However, there are quite a few things to keep in mind as you play:
-Which milestone(s) do you think you can work towards?
-Same with the awards.  However, once the awards have been determined for the game, how are you going to make sure you can compete in those areas?
-What can you do to push up the global parameters with the current cards in your hand?  This is reevaluated every round.  
-With the point above, hand management is a huge part of the game.  How will you manage your current resources to get your cards played?  What can you do to help meet the requirements for vital cards? Which effective combos can you build?
-How will you get cities and greenery tiles out on the board for end game points?

Now, how does the play time and complexity compare to the other engine builders I enjoy?  
Race for the Galaxy (2 player): 
-20 mins
-Slightly lighter than Terraforming Mars due to not having to account for as many game mechanisms
-Lots of decisions are made in a very short play time

Imperial Settlers/51st State (2 player):
-45 mins
-The same weight as RftG (so a tad lighter than TM)
-End game (rounds 4-5) is where the complexity tends to hit since you've spent the first part of the game building up an engine that needs to be ran effectively at the end to win.  Sort of similar to TM in that regard.

After a few plays, I consider Terraforming Mars to be a very solid game.  

Update after 5 plays: I'm done with it for now.  May look into playing it again in the future since the first few plays were fun.  Didn't offer enough interesting decisions for the amount of playtime required.  I have a ton of other engine builders that were roughly the same amount of decisions making (but with more interesting decisions to make) and they all play faster.  Ramping up production took too long.  Bland engine building.  Really liked having an engine builder that tied into a map - that was the highlight of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After playing 3 times, once with the corporation/draft, I'll say this right now: This is not a bad game and it's well-designed engine builder.

This doesn't mean it isn't overhyped though.  While the 2 to 3 hours you'll be making interesting decisions, most of the mechanics of the game boil down to getting cubes to score points or do fancy things with them.  Unlike most engine builders like Race for the Galaxy, there is a map portion that plays a much bigger role than one might realize, especially when playing with corporations.

That being said, my main problem I find with the game is most of the cards are variations of the same thing.  You'll have cards that allow you to turn cubes to cash, or turn cubes to other types of cubes, or reduce the cost of future card purchases.  Unlike most engine builders that I enjoy, such as Roll for the Galaxy or Scythe, there isn't various mechanics that completely change your view of the game.  Your engine is either going to be focused on combo making with your cubes or manipulating the map to your advantage.

This wouldn't be a bad thing if the length of the game was shortened to 20-30 minutes per player.  Unfortunately, this isn't the case.  The last game I've played we had 3 people who played Terraforming Mars twice and we've played with the Corporate Era and Draft mechanics.  The game took around 3 hours, which is far too long for a game with mechanics that are straightforward.  Unless your game is thick full of complex parts like Lisboa or Trickerion, your game should not go over the 2-hour mark with experienced players.  I would also never play this game beyond 3 players because the downtime would be too significant.

It doesn't help the game is overpriced for what you get.  The component quality is shoddy, the artwork is horrendous, and the playmats are complete utter garbage.  The fact that you can totally screw up the game with a simple accidental nudge is ridiculous.  If a game like Wasteland Delivery Express can come up with an amazing tray for their game while maintaining a reasonable price, Stronghold Games could've easily done the same thing for this game.  It's one of the most overpriced games I have ever seen.
.
In the end, I do enjoy this game and would only play it with 3 players, but there are so many alternatives that I would rather play over Terraforming Mars.  Games like Race for the Galaxy, Roll for the Galaxy and Evolution: Climate entice the same interesting decision-making and combo-making as Terraforming Mars but within an hour timeframe.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
At first, I found the graphic design a turn-off; the game looks like it was designed by an engineer, not a graphic designer, and there's a lot of information to absorb at once. (It also makes the peculiar choice of having both iconography and text conveying the same rules on many cards, which I found off-putting.) Compounding that, for the first couple of turns I felt like I was just pulling levers with my eyes closed, making point salad.

But over the course of the game, everything fell into place and became intuitive. Turns became quicker, I was planning a few actions ahead, and I identified the course I was trying to chart to victory. (I came in second out of three.) By the end of the game, the story of Mars has been told -- the map suddenly green and full of oceans, and our individual corporations each having made their mark. It's neat.

I can see this climbing after another play or two, but for now it's a 7. There are plenty of other games in this time bracket that I'd rather play, but I'll happily play this again.

Getting combos is the trick to a good score, particularly with your corporation.  This is one reason recommend playing with the draft option as without it, can be to big a swing who gets the best combos.

RATING: 4
I like the theme and the three ending conditions (thematic; beautiful board too), but after playing once I feel I'm done with it since:

1) Too much card-reading, especially for newbies (e.g. during drafting, when planning sequence of actions) so easy to lose track (e.g. missing a particular condition or resource needed during the sequence). Never mind tracking all other players' abilities and what to prevent them from getting. I guess I can summarize as excessive rules / paperwork... I much prefer elegant rule sets in my games.

2) Runaway leader: There are a couple cards that allow you to damage other players, but these are rare. Even when we ganged up on the leader, it was obvious halfway through that they would win (they had a sequence of cards that gave them 3 VPs every generation!).

There's definitely some strategy there (not too much luck; just initial draft) but I feel the real overhead is *familiarity* with rules, cards, and distributions rather than depth of play. Even as a newbie who was lost/inefficient at first, my final score was comparable with people who owned the game and played many times (though not the leader, who had every card memorized, and could correct actions from across the table).

RATING: 9.5
Bought from Boardgameshelf 11/14/16.

Great game.  Feels a bit like Race for the Galaxy with its engine building / tableau building, but has an interesting spacial element and is a bit heavier.  The gameplay is quite intuitive, and it helps that the cards have their rules written out (in addition to iconography).  The production, however, is severely lacking - especially in terms of art.  The cubes are a bit fiddly, but that will be fixed with the Gametrayz.

Although the game runs a bit long with corporate era, it manages to cram in as much decision making as a heavier game like Trickerion, but doesn't feel like it has much downtime.  Both players end up so engaged in their next play that you don't quite feel the duration.

+ Simple gameplay, deep strategy
+ Elegant engine building
+ Good sense of escalation
+ Lots of crunchy decisions mean low downtime
+ Variable player powers / variable setup
0 Card draw determines a big chunk of the game
- Low proudction quality for price
- Fiddly cubes require aftermarket tray
- Higher play time

Avg Game Time (Corporate Era, 2P): Under 120 minutes

---
Update 11/21/16.  Rating increased from 9 to 9.5.  Played at 4 players and while downtime was higher (especially playing with one AP prone player), there was still so much to think about that the downtime wasn't very painful.  The game plays quite differently at higher player counts, with more emphasis on tile placement due to limited space.  Still loving the game and how different each one is.  I also find myself thinking more and more about different strategies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Positive: The corporations. The theme. The cards. The drafting. The milestones and achievements. This game has a lot to offer. There are a ton of different corporations to play. And while it seems that some may be stronger than others, I'm not quite sure that they are. A lot of this game is deciding when and what to spend your limited resources on. I believe that you can win a game of TM with any corporation, as long as you play it right. The theme of this game is really neat. The idea that we are all different companies trying to do the most to terraform Mars using things like Giant Ice Asteroids and Pets is a neat concept. In terms of the cards, there are TONS of them (I believe over 200) and every single one is unique. So what if you never get lucky and draw the card you need to win the game? That is why drafting is so great. You can only take one card from the four cards you drew and then have to pass the rest to the next person. I almost never have problems getting cards that I need. It's more common for me to get a bunch of cards that I want, but having to decide which ones to actually spend the money on, and which ones to throw away. There are many ways to score points in this game. Cards give you points. Cities and greenery tiles give you points. However, milestones and achievements are also very important. Every milestone costs the same, but there are only three that can be claimed. After that, nobody else can take any of the others that also offer the much needed five points. I think that achievements are done even better though. They become progressively more expensive as players buy them, but whoever buys them, does not necessarily win them at the end of the game. Brilliant. Also, I love your ability to take one or two actions on your turn. It makes for a real interesting way to stall on your turn to stay in the game to see what other people do.

Neutral: As with 51st State, player count is a neutral. The game isn't meant for one player count to be the best, but the more players there are, the less turns you have before Mars is terraformed and the game is over. Essentially, it's the same pie, but you just get fewer slices of it when there are more players. I think I like the game best at three players, then two players and finally four players. However, the solo mode is also well done and interesting. A second neutral is the artwork. I have heard a lot of people complain about the artwork in this game. On the cards, it is all over the place (clipart, photographs, drawings), and the board is attractive, but not beautiful. It doesn't really bother me at all, but it's also not very consistent which is strange.

Negative: The freaking components suck. This has been said by everyone that has every played this game, except maybe the publisher. The board is thin, the cards are thin, the resource cubes suck, the player boards without an overlay to keep cubes in place! What the hell were they thinking? I bought four overlay boards for my copy because if someone was to bump the table, your resources and cubes for tracking production would be everywhere. Even the box that the game comes in is thin and pretty weak. I digress. 

Final Decision: 9/10
I would probably give this fantastic engine builder a 9.5/10 if the components weren't so freaking awful. I would probably give this game a 8/10 if I didn't buy the overlays. Knocking my cubes all around the table would be an extreme annoyance. Overall, it's really a shame that the components bring down an otherwise very well done and thematic engine-building experience. I have yet to find another medium-weight game that can bring my non-gamer friends into the hobby and actually have them talk about it outside of game night. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In Terraforming Mars, players are working together to terraform the planet by creating oceans, increasing the oxygen levels, and raising the temperature. However, this is not a cooperative game in any way. You are working as independent corporations, trying to best capitalize on the red planet. You do this by playing cards, building cities, growing forests, and purposeful global warming.

Pros:

+ Right amount of tactical card play and strategic decisions.
+ Forces you to have a different strategy every game.
+ Theme is heavily integrated and works well.
+ Appeals to a wide range of game players.
+ Fantastic card engine building.
+ Asymmetrical powers and setup.

Cons:

- The game length does not scale to the number of players. A 2 player game is not much longer than a 5 player game.
- Long game. It runs around 2 - 3 hours.
- Mediocre component quality.
- Player boards are awful. It is too easy to bump the table and mix up your resources.
- Card play can be really random at times. The more players, the more the random elements will effect the game.

Final Thoughts:

Rating: 10 / 10: Terraforming Mars is a brilliant game that integrates a card tableau / engine building mechanic with solid thematic elements. The game combines the right amount of tactical card play with long term strategic decisions. The random nature of drawing cards, though there is an option to card draft, allows for a unique experience each play-through. These random elements force you to adjust your strategy each time you play the game.

Terraforming Mars is not for everyone. It has flaws. It is long. It is random. The component quality is mediocre at best. Despite these flaws, I find that I'm constantly thinking about how my engine will turn out the next game. Terraforming Mars works with all player counts, but I prefer it with three or four players. It's a game that is frequently back to the table and it is easily one of the best game of 2016. It deserves a spot as one my all time favorite games.

RATING: 3
I am tired of this push toward games that are designed to be replayed rather than played. With a huge deck of unique cards, no one could possibly know what they're doing on a first play. This game is for those who have decided to become Terraforming Mars players.

I know that all games reveal their strategies over multiple plays and that experience yields better play. That's not what I'm talking about; a first-time Puerto Rico player will get clobbered by experienced players, but he will still be able to grasp how the game works and make decisions accordingly.

In a first game of Terraforming Mars, how could you know that you should hold on to Card# 51 because it and the yet-to-be-drawn Card# 163 will combo very nicely with your corporate power? You wouldn't, because the game is not designed for you to know until you've already played it.

This is what I'm talking about. This game caters to the breed of player who loves committing to long, heavy games and doesn't mind the game not clicking until a future play. Fine for them. For me, I want to be able to play a game with people outside of its fan club.

All that being said, I found nothing fun about playing this and for a game featuring a common map being built upon by all players, I was surprised how much this game feels like solitaire; the tableau is the game, not the map, and the map is what caught my interest. And holy crap is it long.

Also, what are arbitrary attack cards doing in such a long, complex game? Am I suddenly playing Milles Bornes? They're aping Dominion's tacked-on attempt to inject interactivity into their game. "Say, this game feels like solitaire." "Ummm, throw in some attack cards?" "Brilliant!"

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
Sadly, this game is overhyped.  It is a very solid game, but it has too many issues.

The easily bumpable player boards is the least of its issues.  The theme is really present, until the game gets into swing and the theme drops away as you puzzle over more cards with more interactions.  The card draw luck is significant, which can be mitigated by the drafting variant, but that adds to game length and the game is already too long for what it is.

The issue is that there are simply much better engine building games.  This one seems deep at first, but it's so open that card draws are the determining factor.  The choices become mathematical rather than clever.  After several plays, it feels more and more tactical and less strategic.  However, hovering over all of this is that the game has too much down time and is too long for it's depth and luck.

My only guess is that the many new BGGers that have come to the site in recent years simply haven't experienced a decently thematic engine builder of medium complexity.  When I can play Race for the Galaxy 4 times instead of playing this once, and I'm actually interacting with my friends, it's hard to recommend Terraforming Mars.

RATING: 2
I have watched this being played enough times to weigh in with absolute confidence that this game is exactly as deadly as wandering around on Mars without a spacesuit. The main difference being that you die of boredom rather than whatever it is that kills you first on Mars, which for all I know could also be boredom.

Seriously, you're planting trees and creating oxygen and placing cities and pushing a bunch of cubes around for no apparent reason, and wow here comes a card with a volcano, but it's the pointless kind of volcano which doesn't wipe out your civilization in a glorious wash of superheated stuff that comes out of volcanoes like in movies. And there's a card with a puppy. Oh, back to the trees and cubes.  Okay, time to count your trees and cubes and puppies--okay, I'm not sure if you count puppies--and shiny things. And...oh, too late, everyone has died.

I feel very confident that a large majority of people on this website would rate this game about an 8.4, a number which I totally did not look at in the upper leftish area of my screen while I was typing. This probably proves something about the appalling taste in games of the sort of people this site caters to. But I don't want to be impolite, so I won't say anything more other than to again mention the word "appalling." And "nauseating." And "good gravy, it's like having a fat squirrel living in your hair, and even though he is polite and fairly sluggish, he has an overactive bladder." But no more. I don't want to be impolite. 

In addition to obvious queries like "What's for dinner?" and "What's that thing over there?" I feel sure you are asking yourself, "Why is this internet person who I've never met but care deeply about watching people play this game so much?" Well, the answer is long and complicated, and it involves octopods and beets and voodoo spells and general stupidity. But in its simplest form, the explanation is that sometimes the vicious, painful realization of just how stupid a thing is that I am doing is not enough to overcome my laziness. Also, I wanted to see if the puppy would survive. Spoiler alert: There are no puppy-shaped spacesuits.

RATING: 10
I really like this one. With the 208 different project cards there are plenty of opportunities, to develop. Especially with the Company cards there are even more possibilities for different direction of your developments. By the ongoing Terraforming and the growing cities and forests some projects become more attractive while others might be better played earlier. Your growing economic and production extend your action range. I like the enormous variety, which comes mainly through the interaction inbetween the different types of projects and the ongoing Terraforming. So in one round you might drop a project, because it seems worthless to built. Next play this might look completely different if the surroundings have changed and you would even pay twice to keep it. Really nice game with good mechanics, fitting graphics, clear symbolic, atmospheric game play, perfectly implementation of the theme, lots of different possibilities and strategies and still a low down time. That's the kind of game, what I really like and want to play again and again. For me a clear 10 and one of my favorite games at the moment. Hopefully we will not find any bigger bug. It seems nearly to good to be true...

RATING: 8
Very good euro, not very complex, with very stream-lined mechanics. While explaining the nuances takes some time, it's actually a very simple game to play and easy to pickup. Unlike most Euros, Terraforming Mars seems to have a lot of viable strategies that you can follow in order to achieve victory, and they're more or less balanced.

The one thing you need to watch out for that scores big though is getting cities with forests around them. That's really a big key to victory, but how you afford those forests and cities is very variable. This is one of the few Euros I know, like Five Tribes, where you have a lot of ways to success that are equally viable.

RATING: 7
After my first play, I was luke warm to the game. Things I did and didn't like. Felt way overhyped as it's problems seemed large, but still had a lot of interesting gameplay. 
My second play was a ton more fun (I scored great both, so that had nothing to do with it). What I didn't like about my first play was that it felt way too long for having the lucky card draws of Race for the Galaxy.

The draft theoretically helps mitigate this, but grinds the game into the painfully slow territory that doesn't nearly make up for it's small gain. I feel I was on average the slowest drafter, so it's not like it increased my personal down time, but did wreck the flow (a highly undervalued game play attribute). Also, because of how you have to buy the cards (and how money is tight), the leftovers you get from a draft are even less valuable than in standard drafting games. There just is not enough benefit of the draft to outweigh its disadvantages. This was highly surprising to me as I had the exact opposite preconceived notion.

Both times I played with the asymmetric corporation cards, and with starting resources at 1. I can't imaging the game being better without these (with new or experienced players), but I was wrong about drafting being important, so maybe I'm wrong about this too.

OVERSIMPLIFIED SUMMARY:
With that second play, I was ecstatic to see there was a diamond in the rough. But it's a non-draft diamond, and a draft turd.

RATING: 9
It was hard to ignore the popularity of TM so I gave it a try. The first time I played it (2 Player) I was disappointed. It seemed too long and I was not impressed with the drawn out end game. But I found myself thinking about it and looking forward to a second try. We used the designer variant that entails moving one of the terraforming factors forward each turn. That shortens the game somewhat. I've now played it ten times (all two player) and find TM absolutely absorbing. Yes, there is some luck in the card draw. Yes, the end game can get a bit fiddly. Yes, it is derivative of many other Euros. But the copious card selection, coupled with the interesting territorial dance on the board is what makes the game so interesting. We like the fact that more familiarity and experience enhances your skill. In essence TM features a fascinating series of interconnected economic systems, dressed up in science-fiction garb. As a huge fan of Kim Stanley Robinson's great science fiction novels, I'm delighted to see the Mars series come to life in a board game. TM is robust and worthy of exploration. Expansions will provide an opportunity to tinker with the system even further, especially in terms of linking board and card play, and possibly making the game tighter for two players. I'm sure the drafting approach mitigates the random factors somewhat. But I don't mind some luck in my games. And I can't blame luck for the fact that my wife regularly wins! We find that even with the variant referred to above, TM takes us two house to play. But we're sufficiently absorbed and entertained. Excellent first effort and a true labor of love.

RATING: 6
SPIEL 2016

Very good thematical game with a good combination of hand management, economic motor and tile laying with awards and milestones goals. Plays very swiftly! Only downside is the clumsy rulebook and the thin player boards. Until now the best game of 2016 together with Clank!

Update 03/02/2017: I'm downrating the game from 9 to 6. The game is very much take-that with 2 players, a little bit too much for my taste. Secondly, game lasts around +2.5 hours which is just too much to see it on the table very regularly. Third, after playing for several hours, it seems like the scores are too tight in the end. In both games we played, scores of first and 2nd/3rd player differed with 1 point only which is very marginal and one take that action made the difference between a win or a loss.

After all, it's a good thematic game with a lot of interesting scientific events that make sense. A game I like but not love because of the long play time, the take that cards and the tight end game scores and the flimsy production counters.

Component quality is also so-so - with all the lightweight cubes on the flimsy score boards, one sweep with the arms of a nearby kid would wash 3 hours of game play away in one move... luckily it didn't happen to us but I just imagine... sold my copy

Played this at a convention and nearly missed out on this gem. What happened was that it was getting a bit late and there were five of us looking for a game. Once chap suggested we try Terraforming Mars as he hadn't read the rules or anything but had watched the first hour of a game earlier in the day and was confident he could explain it all. None of the rest of us had any experience with the game but were up for a challenge. Terraforming Mars was also getting pretty good 'buzz' so we were keen to see what it was all about.

So, we sat down to play and really struggled with just about everything. After about 30 or 40 minutes the 'rules observer' pretty much said "Sorry, guys. This is beyond me". At that point we could have quit and tried something else but we persevered, fumbling our way through one trial turn.

Then it clicked.

Once we worked out how the game worked all five of us really got into it and found ourselves absorbed in the game. It worked and worked very well indeed. Plenty of challenging decisions, great art and gameplay that really captured the theme. The only criticism I'd venture is that the player mats could be better designed with indentations and suchlike to stop tokens sliding about in the course of play.

I probably won't buy this as It wouldn't get much of a run in our house, but I would definitely play again.

RATING: 7
Played with the card drafting variant—without drafting, my rating would be lower. I'm not sure where the hype is coming from.

The ability to make things—whether on the board or in your tableau—makes it feel like there's always something (often, too many) good things for you to do on your turn. By offloading most of the complexity to cards, Terraforming Mars feels more accessible than it otherwise could have been (similar to Food Chain Magnate—maybe there's a design trend here?). By the end of my first game, the iconography was second-nature, and the card text was helpful for clarification.

The game seems to be about building a resource engine to score points in a number of different ways, trying to play synergistic cards to produce or score more efficiently. Given the infrequency of many cards, however, these synergies seem to require much more serendipity than in, say, Race for the Galaxy. With so many cards, holding out for the right cards to optimize your engine seems unwise.

- YOU get nothing of it, just the smug feeling.

Stopping terraforming-rating, as soon as there is 14 % of oxygen, when Mars' gravity is one third of that of Earth and we here need around 21 %? Why the money from building next to oceans? Why is there a dedicated field for cities?

The game definitely isn't bad or stupid. However, Imperial Settlers have quite the same feel (and samely prone to randomness), while being less of a chore and less unnecessary evil.

RATING: 5.5
Mixed bag. The theme is fascinating--I love smacking asteroids into the planet or playing cards that give you microbes or plants or kelp. The game is not particularly interactive, aside from some crude "zap" cards, and takes ages to play, but it's a soothing experience wrangling cards into an engine and plopping down aquifers and greenery. The most interesting and only original mechanism in the game is the way that players pay money/cubes to specify the endgame goals.

The bad stuff: a really pricy game is basically unplayable unless you buy custom player mats for YET MORE MONEY, because otherwise you will inevitably jostle your cubes and counters midgame and TOTALLY LOSE TRACK OF EVERYTHING--there is basically no way to recover. Lazy dumb design--just use pieces that don't slide so easily. -- And for that pricetag I want something a lot prettier than this game--the card art is random and sometimes terrible.

[after another play] .... OMG I wanted to die after a while. So slow, and AP-prone players just kill this one.

Also, I'm wondering if the complexity and copiousness of the cards is a mirage. Especially if you get a corporation with a good-sized starting fund, often just paying straight up for greenery, aquifers and asteroids is a more effective use of money than bothering putting cards into play at all. Like, you could barely ever draft any cards and often do just fine.

RATING: 10
Wow! What a game that plays so differently in solo mode as in multiplayer mode.
In solo play the game poses a very hard challenge to complete the terraforming in just 14 generations. With no card drafting and the extended card set this makes for a lot of replayability with each game requiring a different approach.
In multiplayer mode the game is a superb engine builder with different corporations giving a different focus for each player. The card drafting variant is essential to limit the randomness of the card draw.
This is only the second game I have rated a 10 - mainly due to the solo game experience.
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

RATING: 9
Enjoyed this way more my second time around. Not only is the subject matter great, but they support this with scientific concepts using the cards. There are two things holding back TM for me, however. One is the length. For such a simple game, I wish that it could ramp up and finish a but faster. The other thing is that the game lacks a sense of urgency. In Race for the Galaxy, I want to score a bunch of points while being mindful of the amount of cards my opponent has. Here I feel like I'm in a bit of a sandbox. At the same time, however, this is probably my favorite game of "building stuff" in a relaxed and satisfying way. Something that Uwe Rosenburg attempts to do in many of his designs, but I still feel like it eludes him. It's difficult to gauge how you're doing as the game goes along, but I enjoy this anyway. Could be my favorite game from 2016 at this point.

RATING: 5
Swedish designs are rare and I was very curious to see how Terraforming Mars stood a comparison with other acclaimed games. When I finally got to play the game, I could appreciate the effort put into the engine building mechanics. But there are many buts.

Terraforming Mars is one of many examples of how loads of cards does not equal depth since you can't plan which cards you draw and their impact on the common game board is too small. Furthermore, the attempt to fix the luck of drawing the right cards with drafting only adds to the playing time while the attempt to fix the low interaction with take that cards is just annoying. The result is a way too long multi-player solitaire that ends with a big hand of cards rather than a terraformed planet. Terraforming Mars is a well crafted game with a unique theme but somehow I feel that an opportunity was lost here.
