=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Each player controls a corporation in Mars, attempting to make it more hospitable. In this card driven game, you are dealt a number of cards, and your first decision is to decide whether or not to pay for each card. In the game, your resources are money, steel, titanium, plants, energy and heat.  You are trying to raise your terraform rating (TR), which is your VPs. By getting rid of heat, you raise the temperature, and advance your TR. Similarly, by planting greenery, you advance oxygen, which also raises your TR. The cards range in various costs, allowing you to increase production in some areas, gain advantages, plant greenery tiles, and so forth. 

There are 5 milestones in the game, and once 3 of them have been reached for 5 VP each, no more milestones can be attained. Similarly one can fund awards in various areas to earn VPs. 

There are standard actions such as building a city, adding an ocean tile, planting an greenery tile so you don't have to rely on cards. 

This is a very good tense game, You are racing to get the milestones, and you are trying to make sense of your cards. You are trying to optimize your engine, but other people might have beaten you to a certain objective. Most of all, the fun is the interaction of the cards and trying to create combinations that might match and give you an advantage.  Each game is very different. My only criticism of this good game is that  a few of the cards feature "take that" against your opponents and I'm not fond of games that do that, but in this game, they are not crippling, but they can slow you down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Very good game! It's a real pleasure to discover the cards during the first plays. The past discovery, you know better the different strategies that you could follow. There are a lot of strategies and every game is different: the draw of the cards, the placement on the board and the different corporations you can represent give a good replayability. The interaction is present with some effects of card, the placement on the board or the claim of the objectives and rewards before the other players. The tension is here. For some aspects, it reminds me Race for the galaxy. It's important to adapt your strategies to the drawing cards and choose your card to keep according to two or three definite strategies, otherwise you can quickly lose yourself. I played it a lot with two players, around 2h30 for a game but it's also a good game with more players. So it's a long game but you don't bother. The rules are not complicated and logic. I really recommend it to all players (except for family) and it can be a good gateway game to heavier games.

RATING: N/A
Only played once - took, way, way, way too long - literally hours - contributing to the game length was that we were playing with the non-beginner rules that assume you already know what you're doing.  Extra cards and the drafting took up tons of extra time.  These rules seem necessary to add depth, otherwise it isn't much of a game, but they add length even if you know what you are doing!  As a new player it was a lot to process - how do these cards work, should I keep them, should I deny them to my opponent, etc.  Now, I love that kind of thing, but I was shocked how long it took - now where near the advertised length of 90-120 mins!

I hope the time to play this comes down by leaps and bounds, or this one wont be one I can play very often.   I don't really need another long game in my collection collecting dust, that never gets played.  And that would be too bad because I really like it.

Possibly the solitaire play is actually good?  Then I can probably whip through it faster and get more use out of it.

The only other complaint was the stupid little cubes.  My particular strategy used tons of cards that added cubes to them and it got very, very messy.  One bump and my score was obliterated ... my opponent didn't have that issue, as he had very few cards collecting cubes.  Fiddly, fiddly mess and cross-referencing cards that got triggered by other cards was time consuming.  Like I said though, my opponent didn't have that ultra-combo cube issue with his strategy.

Otherwise, a completely awesome game experience!

RATING: 9
Very good and thematic game. The Components could be a little more sturdy, but otherwise brilliant. The thematic science is close enough, the card texts are flavorful, the pictures are evocative, the board is inspiring. Mechanics seem to be working well, our first games came in very close, with several strategies working roughly evenly well.

You get a good feel for building your little engine in the first part of the game. Some small take-that elements but not so many that it would spoil the fun for anyone on the receiving end. Then the game ramps up hard for the second part of the game. Anyone who have played will know what i'm talking about. Rush to the finish.

All in all. I recommend this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Still don't know, how I feel about this game. Theme is super interesting (at least for me) and very well integrated, with a clever game ending goals that practically set the game lenght around 2-2,5 hours for every player count (so it scales well). You can even have some nice plays, that will make other people go: "cool move!" and I think that replayability is really high. Especially the ending is very tense and interesting, as everyone tries to squeeze som last victory points, and got us even standing on our toes one time. On the other hand, engine building is somehow loose, You can upgrade few things here and few there, but rarely are they connected as I would expect and I never felt (but I just could be a bad player, this may or may not improve with several more plays) that I created a well oiled specialized machine. Then there is very low interaction, which should possibly be solvable with draft variant, but I must try it first to form an opinion, altough I suspect that this will prolong the game. There is also so much information on the cards, which makes the game really AP prone, but if You play with people without the need to calcute every step it is not so bad. Other minus is that there is a potential problem with a runaway leader (VPs=income, leading to more VPs) without a catch-up mechanism. And the last thing. The art. First, it all feels a little lazy as many components (main board included) look like they are 1-2 steps from being finished (and possibly good looking), but the artist did not put in the effort (balancing colors, doing some final polishing). Also, it lacks consistency. Some cards have painted images, some photographs (badly done, I must add) some are quite nice, even beautiful, others really horrible. The design of the cards also isn't clean and there is a lot of unnecessary stuff there (more in this case is much less) as if it was created to distract You from some of the ugly images. I know, that it was supposed to mimic the look and "feel" of a journal publishing popular science articles but still... And the ugliest have to be the player mats, which look like they were done as a last minute high school project in MS Paint in 1997. But overall I still like this game and even enjoyed it more everytime I play it, which is probably due to its well done theme, as the game design certainly has its flaws.Edit: 5 player experience is very boring and the already low interaction resulted in total lack of interest for other peoples moves. I would play the game in 2-3, possibly 4, but never 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
El año pasado había largado con el Terraforming Mars y me había dejado la impresión de un juego extraordinario. De movida me iba a caer bien, porque soy un fan de la exploración espacial y la ciencia ficción "realista", y para el diseño del Hábitat Espacial pude estudiar muchas de las teorías detrás de cada cartas que aparecen en el Terraforming Mars.

Tenía tantas opciones para explorar y una engine de cartas con tanto espacio para el pro-play que me reservé comentarlo porque sentía que tenía que conocerlo más.

Un año después, ya con varias partidas encima, en el Ficus y en solitario, creo que es el momento de revisar si el juego está a la altura de las primeras impresiones. Cha cha cha chaaaaaaaannnn *suspenso*

Una de las dudas que me surgió fue la capacidad de especialización. Si bien terraformar un planeta es un proceso complejo que tiene muchas aristas, no me atraía la idea de que todos termináramos "haciendo lo mismo en distinto orden", como pasa en muchos euros. En este juego esperaba un costado más temático, que hiciera brillar las capacidades asimétricas de las distintas corporaciones.

En este sentido, el juego cambia completamente de acuerdo al número de jugadores, porque el objetivo final de terraformar el planeta no escala para nada, y creo que por ahí es un elemento de diseño que le faltó, pero es opinable.

El resultado es que cuando son pocos jugadores, cada jugador tiene más turnos, y baja más cartas, y termina haciendo más cosas, y al final, se diluye un poco "la" especialización en diversas especializaciones. Por supuesto, con menos jugadores las engines son enormes y tremendamente potentes, algo que sin duda resulta atractivo.

Por otro lado, cuando son más jugadores, la especialización tiene más personalidad, porque en menos turnos no se puede ser tan abarcativo, y temáticamente creo que le suma.

De todos modos, un elemento fundamental para lograr esa especialización es contar con cierto control sobre las cartas que te llegan, y la mecánica básica del juego en ese sentido tiene una alta dosis de azar. Creo que para lograr el efecto temático de especialización hay que encararlo con más jugadores y con la variante del drafteo de cartas, para tener más control.

Si por el contrario, buscás un euro power-builder con increíble profundidad, encararlo con menos jugadores es suficiente y el drafteo menos necesario.

De cualquier modo, Terraforming Mars sigue siendo un título que recibe mi mayor recomendación y hasta donde mi experiencia lo indica, es sin duda el mejor juego complejo lanzado en 2016.

RATING: 8
There are so many things I like in this game. The only thing that will stop it rising in the ratings is that the game goes half an hour longer than it feels it should – next time I play I’m going to try the designer’s variant where each turn the new start player increases one of the three game-ending conditions a bit. Regardless, I like how the corporation cards drive you to try different approaches from the get-go, I like that you have to make hard decisions on cards right from the start (and each turn ongoing), because they cost you to acquire them AND to play them. Essentially that's the game, ie what you pick and play. There are lots of currencies for card effects to mess around with, and lots of approaches to earning VP's. I like the milestone and award races, and how you need to fund them to get them operational and only the first 3 (and ergo the most desired for this game) of each will make it into play. This, and the fact that you'll see a different card mix each game, has the potential to drive a ton of replay.

RATING: 9
Finally Fryxgames produces a really excellent game, and of course it's Jacob's creation, the best designer in the family. 

I like games with a lot to do where the skill is to optimize and maximize to be able to do more and more rather than games with a limited number of actions, so this game suits me well. 

The engine that drives the game to an end, terraforming, is cooperation and at the same time as you actually compete for those terraforming points. I know some players that have problems with games where you can decide to end the game or not regardless of how you are doing and that wont "allow" you to end the game if you're not in the lead (Worst of all are the french online "Gang of Four" players). But in this game you're not entirely sure if you are in the lead or not, there are a lot of hidden points. That in it self might also be a problem for some players, but not me. 

One of this games strengths is that there are several very different strategies to win. Some companies might be stronger than others, but what differs more is how you play them. 

I have been of the opinion that draft is necessary to make this game fun, but I have realized that randomly dealing cards has its merits too. The Standard Projects come more in play when you get less cards that suit you. 

When I play with my gaming group we always use drafting though. We also draft the ten first cards. This is how we start: Deal 2 or three companies each to chose from. Deal five cards, draft those clockwize. Decide which company you wanna play and display it. Deal five cards and draft counterclockwize. 

I got to try the fast start with the prototype for Alliances at a convention this spring, which was really good. Everyone got going faster, which is more fun for everyone.

RATING: 9
Terraforming Mars is a card-based engine-building game based on achieving three goals--increasing the planet's temperature, increasing the oxygen level, and placing ocean tiles on Mars. The game has six different resources, and for each of these, you have a bank and an income track. Some of these resources can be traded in directly to impact the three goals, while others just help you pay the costs of cards. The real heart of the game is card play though--the game has hundreds of cards, all different, and each of these manipulates your resources or the planet in various ways. In the end, players add up how much they've contributed to the three goals, along with points from tiles they've placed on the Mars board, points from cards, and various other bonuses to determine a winner. While I'm usually pretty theme-agnostic, I have to admit that this one kind of takes me in. The card play is very engaging, as it's just fun to set up your combos. There is are some take-that elements I didn't enjoy, but those are a minor part of the game. On the whole, this one was a winner. 

(5+ plays)

RATING: 4
I'm undecided on how much I enjoyed it. I keep thinking about it, so that's a good sign, but I wonder if the shine will wear off. This has potential to raise a point or drop a point with future plays. 5 seemed a little long, but it was more the downtime than the actual play time. I thought the card play was pretty cool though and reminded me like a sci-fi version of Seasons.

I do think the components are a huge letdown. Shiny cubes are cool, although they don't make a whole lot of sense theme-wise. Keeping track of resources with them was a little bit of a pain. I do think the player boards could have been made to have holes punched in them to have cubes stored in there including a +10, +20 etc spot. I can't comment on the quality of the box.

Overall, the game was solid and I'm interested in playing it again. Preferably with 3-4 players.

Update: Alright, played it with 2 players and while it plays just fine, I found it lacking somewhat. It felt a bit more solitaire and obviously it's tit for tat. I'd like to try the standard game as we've played extended twice and both times it felt a bit too long for what the game actually is. Plus you end up pulling out like 1/3 of the cards which I think might make it a more strategic game. I also liked the drafting variant, but it might just add a bit too much time to an already longish card game.

I think it overstays it's welcome by ~30-45 minutes. If this was an hour game, it'd be great, but it tends to push 90-120 minutes without too much trouble. Playing time doesn't really decrease much with lower player counts.

Update 2: Alright, played it solo and it seems to have firmly cemented my opinion of the game now. I like a lot of what it does, but it very much reminds me of Prosperity with the constant fluctuation of resources. I liked the solo game well enough and I do think it seems to play good with solo and probably 3-4 players. 2 and 5 seem to be the odd man out on this one. I'd play it again if asked, but I'm not jonesing like I once was to get it to the table.

I also find most of the cards to be rather bland. The blue ones are the interesting ones and most are really retroactive or just "place an ocean down". Nothing exciting.

RATING: 9
--- This is a quite nice production-type game.  Each player can do his own thing (plans & plan execution) with minimal fellow player, Act-Of-God disasters inflicted upon the player.
--- As an important notice however, TFM has a characteristic, which some people may find off putting.  If via the random, "Act-Of-God" cards, a player jumps off to a first or second turn, important production lead over the other players, & if that favored player subsequently plays competently, it is almost impossible for the other players to catch the player receiving the early production lead.
----- In my informed opinion, so be it.  In the next game in the early turns, the Act-Of-God cards will probably favor another player.  Otherwise, the players can play their game & try to outwit the other players.
--- This is a good game.  It is enjoyable.  :)

RATING: 6
An inoffensive game, but not groundbreaking or especially interesting. 

The main issues: (1) effectively multiplayer solitaire, (2) the card pool is way to big -- this is an issue because it means what you get is highly random, so there aren't really interesting decisions vis-a-vis the engine building. This is lessened if you play with the drafting rules, but but that only addresses the issue somewhat. It would be much better if there were 25% fewer cards, so that the deck cycles 2+ times. (3) Some games can plainly better than others, some are highly situational. It's a total crap shoot (luck of the draw). 

Not bad, but certainly not great nor amazing. If I was being charitable, I'd give it a 7

Also, this is not a heavy game at all. It's a light euro (ie. lighter than mid-weight)

Card drafting, hand and resource/currency management, engine/tableau builder. Compelling, engaging theme enhanced by mechanics, plus flavor text. Variable player powers. Med-low player interaction, Med high-complexity (will take a few plays to grasp everything). Solo variant available.

-Marred by several mean take-that card actions (albiet anti-hoarding measures). AP prone, a bit fiddly with the player boards and multiple resources. RATING: 6
In this game, players get a hand of unique cards, and then on their turn they chose to take 1 or 2 actions, which could be playing a card, using an ongoing effect card, or paying some number of accumulated resources to bump a marker up one of the charts that represent the planet getting a little better. Each time you improve the planet, you get a personal point. The game has a lot of luck in terms of which cards you wind up getting, and a lot of downtime between turns as players ponder which of their many many cards to activate. There are take that cards, but they don't seem to be very strategic, as their effects are minor, and maybe cost your opponent up to 1 vp. The player interaction is low, which isn't something that discounts a game for me, but the games that are like that, that I do like, all have some special shining mechanism that makes them stand out, but there isn't anything like that here.

:star: Art and components
:nostar: Innovative mechanics
:star: Handles 5 or more players
:star: Good with different player counts
:nostar: Low time between turns
:star: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment

RATING: 9
Based into physical reality (well, mostly - it's an SF theme) the game evolves around terraforming Mars. This is accomplished by executing projects or facilitating events (or, as game mechanism: playing cards or choosing standard places). Since each project not only costs money, but effects your resources in a complex way, all projects are more or less depending/building on other projects. In the game you play one corporate which has its own set of conditions/rules to follow. This is the solo part of the game

Since there is only one Mars changing of global parameters (temperature, oxygen level, cultivation) will effect all players. So there is a strong interactive component, e.g. building a city on the "right" spot just before your opponent manage or rising the temperature to get a bonus.

You follow a strategy (based on the corporation you represent), think tactics to outsmart your opponents and, optimize everything to get the most victory points (most of them through the terraforming value, which represents your contribution to the terraforming of Mars).

I see only one negative point: the rules are explained in condensed text rather than pictures and repetitions. This leads to some paging through the nice booklet until you get everything right. But once you got it, the game is fantastic.

RATING: 5
Let me start out by saying this rating is after playing once with three players. I suspect this rating would be quite a bit higher for the solo game. 

The reason for that is because for the most part in this game I was not focused on what my opponents were doing or considering what they did. And even if I had been paying attention to whatever they were up to, I'm not quite sure how what actions they take really impact what I'm about to do. 

For the most part the game is about managing your economy and hand of cards, and there is relatively little you can do to influence anyone else. I didn't draft, and I can see how that would add a little bit to the game, but still with so few cards you're drafting each time and still needing to set up your own economy, I'm not sure how that's supposed to magically fix the issues I had. 

Every card does something different and they are all pretty cool. But the issue is that most of the game is spent intently considering how all your own cards will work together and what I can be doing to maximize my stuff--I didn't really have time to consider what all my opponents had or what they were doing. And frankly I don't think it really matters, because even if I did, I'm not sure how that would have really influenced what I would be doing. Your cards and starting corporation pretty much dictate what you advantages you need to leverage and what path you are going down, so I'm not sure what sort of reacting to other's actions there is supposed to be, and if I'm not doing that, then how are we really interacting or even playing a game together? 

With all that being said it is rather fun to build up these crazy engines and see everything paying off while terraforming the planet. I will play this again and enjoy my time maximizing what I'm doing. I just would rather play many games that see me actually interacting with my opponents that allow me to plan my strategy out a bit more rather than largely having the game play me and lead me where it says I should go (based on corporation and cards I draw).

RATING: 7
Solid euro-solitaire, that combines multiple resource management with card playing and Suburbia-like tile laying. Abysmal graphic design and artwork is the reason why I will never play it again in its current state. Absolute rubbish in this regard. 

It's a smart combination (cards/resources/building common boardstate), the end game condition vs fixed rounds is a step in the right direction, but all in all it feels like this design didn't reach its intended peak, as such it feels not polished and a bit meh. Tile placement is largely superfluous. The take-that interaction seems tacked on and totally random and unnecessary (I love games with interaction, but it needs to be meaningful). There is a lot of cards in this game, which means that the draw deck is very diluted and the game will play you for most of the time - there are no big decisions here, you just decide what to do with more or less shitty draw. There aren't many ways to get more cards, so you are the slave of the variance. Also, I didn't like the fact that it snowballs towards end of the game - your income is 20 at the beginning, and ~70 in last rounds. 

The game itself isn't that different from Imperial Settlers and IS play in 1/3 of TM time.

RATING: 8
One of the best engine building games I've played with a wonderfully integrated theme. I now believe the hype. 
It's not perfect. The sheer variety of cards is both a benefit and a impediment, though.  It creates a steep learning curve and the randomness of the draw, while adding infinite variety, can also lock you out of certain resources available to others. 
It also can be difficult to follow other players' engines, and sometimes it doesn't seem to matter, giving that multi-player solitaire feel; however, the main things you need to know are on the production boards mainly. Still, you can get surprised by cards triggering that you didn't really know that they had.

RATING: 6
I enjoyed this as a card drafting game, but can't imagine even remotely liking it in any other format.
Crunchy enough to require some serious calculation and tactical play, but the fact that cards can severely limit the scope of what you can do with your turn gives you focus and generally prevents too much AP.
That said, this game is still LOOOOOOONG, especially when playing it as a draft.  Our last session ran 5 hours, and we had all played before.  Also, as much as I did like the flow of play, ultimately who wins and who looses comes down to who drew cards that work well with each other and who didn't.
A game that requires this much time, brain power and strategic focus just ends up feeling disrespectful to its players when so much of your engine is up to the hand of fate.   
I won my last game by a landslide, but in no way felt I deserved it.

RATING: 8.5
After a few plays, replayability seems to be high with variety of cards and many different start corporations. Still enjoy waiting to play it again to see which engines I build. Every game gave me different engines and combos, but sometimes the right cards simply didn’t come out. Can be tactically mitigated fine wth other actions, playing cards or passing to the next generation.

Scores were also very close so runaway leader may not be a problem here unless everyone decides to use red take that cards on one person. Red cards can affect other players slightly like taking resources or slowing down production slightly. Making sure you get at least one award or milestone and placing ocean and greenery tiles out can make the different in close games.

Very enjoyable because it’s thematic and you feel like you're playing together to support humanity while competing with others to terraform Mars the best. Plays well with two, but best with 3-4. 5 players will have more downtime, but will be the most competitive if you don’t mind it. Game time is 60-90m for solo and closer to 120m for 2-5 players while Corporate Era adds about 20-30m to the game.

Only other complaints I have is that the end game could drag if everyone focuses on their engine building instead of terraforming the last of Mars’ requirements (usually not a problem though since terraforming gives you VP’s). The components are fine, but the player boards could have slots to place cubes in to prevent them from sliding if accidentally bumped. Again, just a minor complaint since I doesn’t really happen.

RATING: 8
Awesome game play.

This game would probably be a 10 if we're just considering the mechanics and theme.  Everything ties together really well and is very streamlined.  Rules can be fiddly, but aren't fiddly due to poor design, just fiddly because there's a lot of good stuff going on.

The good:
Theme and how it is implemented was refreshingly new.
Mechanics are amazing and really tight.  This game keeps you drawn in with your next choices.
Downtime is short unless you have a player who is very new or prone to AP.
The theme fits in with the mechanics very well.
Game has a lot of depth, but it can also be scaled down for newer players.
The game is very fun to replay, without getting stale.

The bad:
I felt like the game was more random than I was expecting.  You can get shafted with a bad first draw of 10 cards which aren't very usable until late game (which is unlikely, but did happen to me).
The components are extremely basic and dull.  Most $60 games have a little more plastic in them.  I've personally ordered some 3D terraforming tiles from Etsy for my game.  The box is way bigger than it needed to be for such basic materials, which kind of gives the wrong impression of how much stuff is contained inside.
I despise games where the deck of cards used is taller than my ability to shuffle all at once, this is one of those games.

Verdict:  Worthwhile purchase, especially if you are a solo gamer.

RATING: 7
Terraforming Mars is an odd game to me. There are a few things I dislike about the game - most prominently is the single target take that aspect. I don't understand the decision to include cards that lets one player punish another player for no other reason than "I had nothing else to play" or "If I didn't take it, you would". It is strange and uncommon to find such mechanic in a euro game (and for good reason). There is no mitigation, no preparation - it just happens. There are some cards with abilities that hinder an opponents strategy (like the Predator) - I don't mind these as much, because once they see play, players can begin to play around these cards.

I didn't like the first two plays too much - however, the game is slowly growing on me. Although the last game ran a little longer than I would have liked - and ended in an unsatisfying way, it was a good experience. I might increase my rating after a few more plays.

RATING: 7.8
[i]After replaying the game with the advanced deck and card drafting, my rating improved from 6.5 -> 7.8. I advise to use the advanced deck and card drafting mechanisms[/i]

[u]The Positive[/u]
(+) Fun and more or less scientifically grounded theme

(+) Easy game mechanics: the game is quick to explain and easy to understand

(+) The addition of a huge set of optional 'advanced cards' incorporated within the base game makes for great replayability. I advise to use these cards: they allow you to build up a unique economy which adds the required strategic depth necessary to truly enjoy the game

(+) The different company perks you can play with combined with the vast card deck allow for interesting combinations and a game that develops differently each game. I advise to use the card drafting variant in which the 4 cards acquired during the research phase get drafted in stead of just randomly drawn. This adds interactivity and increases the chances to successfully pursue a specific strategy.

(+) Iconography on cards makes a lot of sense: most of the time players do not need to read the explanation written on the cards, which is helpful. Overall the game is cleverly designed.

(+) The game offers players more actions to shape their game compared to similar games which are based on building up an economy, and still the play time remains reasonable with about 30 min per player. Of course the wealth of actions offered in the game is only possible by giving players plenty of 'small' actions, many of which have limited impact, but it still succeeds in giving players the feeling the get a whole lot done in one playsession and it keeps players involved.

[u]The Negative[/u]
(-) Truth be told, this game may lack some character. The mechanics are 'been there done that': there is nothing new or exciting about the game engine (laying out cards in order to build up an economy and getting stuff transformed into points). Honestly, many older games have created game engines revolving around building up an economy in order to build up scoring engines. 

(-) There is a bit of a strange mechanic in which the game starts out extremely slow with players being unable to get any serious stuff done at the beginning. Once the engines start and things are getting interesting the game is over before you know it. This can leave some players who relied on more long term strategies with a bit of an empty feeling at the end.

(-) The game is prone to some downtime due to players trying to put together the right combinations of a whole mess of cards. This can make the game drag a little. Still, despite this disadvantage, I would still advise to always play with the card drafting variant: it does slow the game down a little, but that's a small price to pay for the additional control over the game this offers. Without card drafting, the game loses too much of its strategic appeal.

(-) After playing a few rounds the cards are everywhere on the table and it is useless to try to keep track of special 'blue' actions/abilities of every player. It is also a bit of a chore to keep track of certain milestones (like: 'how many small symbols has this or that opponent acquired?') This makes the game a little messy.

(-) There is quite some luck involved in creating your engine: the right card combinations can be really powerful, but getting those cards together depends on a simple card draw at the beginning of each round. Playing with the card drafting variant seriously helps in this regard, but still a certain luck factor might bite players pursuing a strategy based on really big and expensive cards in the butt: they risk getting no such cards after spending much time and energy in optimizing their engine for those type of cards.

(-) Some negative player interaction cards feel simply stupid and unnecessary. It's no fun when an opponent magically plays a hidden card from his deck destroying your production capacity or well planned for resource stock. Those things don't happen very often - but all the more reason for me not to understand why they were incorporated in the game. Generally speaking I'm not a big fan of negative player interaction in games, so this could just be a very personal thing. Overall, negative player interaction is limited in Terraforming Mars - but at critical times, it does happen. The card drafting variant again improves upon this point: while drafting you can try to hold back negative player interaction cards which would hurt your cause more than opponents.

[u]Tips[/u]
(*) Money is tight in the beginning: if the cards allow for it: start investing in your economy early!
(*) An easy  source of points are milestones. In the first half of the game, keep a very close eye on them and on what your opponents are going for. Awards are similar, but more risky: paying for a certain award too early in the game might open up competition for those points: be careful not to pay to fund an award which gives 5 points to somebody else!
(*) TR rating is more valuable than plain points, as they both increase your score and your income.
(*) The combination of one or two cities and many greenery tiles is a great points generator, but getting many cities out is a costly affair without the right special abilities or construction cards! There are also many points to be had by building good combinations of point scoring cards.
(*) Refrain from buying too many cards: only pay to keep cards which you are able to build immediately or in the very near future.
(*) We played our first game without the advanced card deck. That was a mistake, I expect the game to be more interesting with more strategic possibilities for some economy/engine building when you play with the full deck (incl advanced cards). With only the base cards this game is dull and uninteresting in my opinion. Also, use the card drafting variant for the research phase to allow for more interaction and give players some more control to lay their plans out.

RATING: 3
***
Update 10/25/2017, One year and 3 more plays later:

Terraforming Mars was one of a handful of games I was introduced to almost a year ago, within the first ten or so "hobby" board games I ever played. Since that time, I revisited it thrice more, interspersed between plays of hundreds of other games of all types. I can say, unequivocally, that my initial feelings have not changed in the slightest. If anything, they've degraded.

-It still plays out over an absurd 3 to 4 hours of multiplayer solitaire.
-The aesthetics are still horrid.
-The resource conversion is still an overwrought, repetitive slog. 
-The random card draws still place the game on rails. In the early game, some cards will be clearly better than others, and in the late game, some cards will be nigh on useless.

...Last but not least, at the end of every game, I still could not care less about what I supposedly achieved on mars. 

Altogether, it is a perfect storm of too long and too repetitive, and this kills the game for me. The mechanisms feel disjointed from the actual theme, and the variety of cards only provides an illusion of depth, and no more. Quantity over quality ad infinitum. I can see there is a dramatically large demographic of players who enjoy this sort of fluff, but I can't find any fun in it. 

***
Original comments:
Terraforming Mars felt surprisingly underwhelming given all the hype. I played with the full complement of players using a drafting variant, and the game just seemed to slog along. The card combinations provided avenues for some neat engine building, but there seemed to be an overarching and nagging disconnect to them all. The non-intuitive card iconography and jarring art variations may have contributed to that disconnect. It was also rather difficult to shake off the feeling of multiplayer solitaire, and that does not sit right with me. In the end, it is just another resource to point conversion game, and I do not care much for the delineated strategy defined by the scoring bonuses.

I found little enjoyment to be had in the game and kept wishing I were playing something else. I will give it the benefit of the doubt and rate it as average, given the positive response by the peanut gallery. It's just not for me.

(+) Given that no two cards are the same you will need to spend some time to learn it all and spot the synergies, allowing for replay-ability.
(+) The mechanism of engine-building is executed well, in its purest form.
(+) You have a means of scoring in a variety of ways.

(-) Seriously lacking in player interaction. There were concerns for take-that mechanisms? They are not abundant, and in the event that they do happen, their impact is lackluster. A diversion. I almost wish there were more.
(-) The art is a mishmash, the icons are non-intuitive, and the components are physically poor in quality. This hurts the already thin thematic connection. 
(-) For a system touting engine building, your freedom to build is seemingly hamstrung by luck. Aside from luck of the draw, the drafting system puts you at the mercy of other players. The player drafting to you can simply assess what you are attempting before willingly keeping a card that would benefit you, despite it being absolutely useless to them. You are constantly attempting to work with what you have, for better or worse, without ability for retaliation.

RATING: 7.5
Overall, this is an enjoyable card driven, engine building game that- unfortunately- goes on so long that it allows  players engines to get quite unwieldy towards the end of the game with too many things to manage. It has plenty of cool combos and interesting card interactions.

The base game is too luck heavy. Too many cards require other cards to combo off of and each card in the deck is unique. With the way that the base game distributes cards (randomly dealt to you), it means that you are not seeing 50%- 75% of the cards in the deck, and you may not ever find the card you need.

The extended game with drafting goes a long way towards solving the issue with the base game, but it becomes much too long and overstays it's welcome. The engine starts becoming unwieldy in the base game, but in an extended game can become overwhelming. 

The solo game is, surprisingly, maybe my favorite way to play this game. Having a hard timer on the game, and fighting to terraform the planet in that much time, puts a sharp focus on the game and really ratchets up the tension. The multiplayer version of this game is a meandering, slow affair, while the single player game is a tight, pressure filled experience. I wish the game included rules for playing a cooperative version of the solo game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
as printed: 5/10
with small house rules and a low player count: 7/10 or maybe higher

The directed spite is unfun, unthematic, and out of place in the game.  If you house rule that you must target players as evenly as possible and must target the player with the most of the resource in question, it is less offensive.  But still sometimes randomly hurting people and adding to the playtime.

There is way too much down time, especially if played with 5 (and probably with 4, too).  You can easily be in a position of taking very fast turns running your engine while others are drawing cards that they have to read and replanning their strategy.  You can easily wait 10 minutes for a turn that will take 10 second to perform.

The card draft, especially with the extra cards mixed in, is fun with lots of variety but at the same time very high variance.  You can easily get a high point swing early or late in the game based on a good or bad draw that is really beyond your control.  Drafting the opening 10 cards helps, but the draft on the last turn can still be highly variable.  And you can easily go the entire game and not see a card that supports a particular strategy, or luck into several just when you need them.  This will be better with fewer players, but maybe not good enough.

I REALLY like how the increase terraforming tracks (water, temp, air) mesh with card pre-reqs that make for good drafting decisions.  If there were less luck in the drafting, this would be really cool since it forces you to think about tempo not just cost and effect.  I really liked the spatial board interaction, which were tight but not frustratingly tight.  I also found the engine pleasing to build, intuitive to understand, and satisfying to run.  I just wish I spent more time running it not waiting for others to take turns.

Minor issues:  I liked the photo art and the drawn art, but found them jarring and ugly mixed together in the same game.  I also wish the game had been colorblind friendly -- clear red/green cubes are not, but slightly different choices would have easily and completely solved the issue.

All in all, I'd try it again with 3 player and with house rules.  Then it might shine.  But I am frustrating that there are so many good things wasted in a game with so many bad things going on.

RATING: 10
Wow, what an awesome game for solo-players :)

+ great artwork
+ very thematic

+ always different (companies, cards, KI tiles)

RATING: 8
TfM is the second game I'm encountered (after Viticulture) whose play gives me significantly more enjoyment than I would have predicted just from reading its rules. This makes me think about its design, because I view that as a clear sign that it's doing something very right -- either something which is easily overlooked or else something which is undervalued.

My preliminary thought is that TfM does so well because it directly, steadily hits the 'rewards' part of the brain. Most people respond positively to steady achievement, to spotting beneficial combinations and to creating a visible or tangible achievement. Terraforming Mars makes all of this easy and accessible. Moreover, the game marries these mechanical successes of the player to a real-world theme which also relies directly on these traits. The theme is enhanced by its emphasis on cooperative effort as a prerequisite, meaning that the whole competition is cast in the light of a shared endeavor. I believe that this might make a play session more rewarding, losses slightly less painful, and the subject matter more appealing to a broad audience.

However this also highlights the one consistently jarring note during play: the small segment of take-that cards are almost uniformly ill-received at first. I've seen them almost ruin the first two multiplayer games in which I played, and I am fairly certain that it's exactly because they shatter that thematic synergy with the gameplay to which I've written so far. If that's true then this interests me specifically because it actually points out exactly how much this synergy is contribution to the appeal of the game. More thought is merited here.

At any rate, the game is a very good time, especially with its moderately low rules overhead, and is also  surprising nice for solo play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Glad I got to try this one before buying.  It's a good game, but is way overhyped.  The game centers around the big deck of cards - the rest of the game (tile placement, competing to be the first to claim goal points, competing for the lead in different scoring categories and paying to decide which end game scoring will count) is all pretty run-of-the-mill Euro.  Players contribute together towards advancing the oxygen/oceans/temperature, but really since these all give you a VP and other benefits (1+ VP for forest tile and touching your city; resources for ocean placement; temperature doesn't give you any other benefit but what else are you going to use heat for), it doesn't feel like you are cooperating to terraform Mars before time runs out or to meet some overarching crisis (some of your cards can't be played until a certain temp/% O2/# oceans, but that's more like a timer you have to wait to go off to play the card than something you're going to really work hard to reach on your own).  The deck of cards are full of great cards, ok cards, and pretty mediocre cards (the cards that let you attack just 1 other player seem like a really bad attempt at making the game more interactive), and there's a lot of randomness what you get dealt (drafting them per the official advanced variant doesn't seem like it would fix it that much, since you will be passing 3, 2, or 1 cards that aren't that great after you've taken the cream, unlike drafting in Agricola where you're trying to draft synergistic cards that will last the whole game or 7 Wonders where you are passing good cards you want to play but can't).  I really don't know why the designer decided you had to pay 3 each to keep cards in your hand that you were dealt.  It's clunky (don't mix them up with your old hand until you've decided which you're buying), it takes a lot of time (how much is it worth it to me to keep this card and spend my precious money I need this turn), and holds up moving forward with the game.  It would have been so much better if he just made all the cards cost 3 more to play them, you get to keep all 4 cards you're dealt (or draft), and then leave it up to players later on in their turns to decide if it's worth it to play a card (you'd have to remove the 16-card-hand goal and maybe a few other minor changes).  I'm happy to play it again and explore the cards I didn't see (note it was difficult to really pay attention to most of the cards my opponents played), but I'm definitely not itching to play it again right away.

RATING: 10
Solo Play: 
This is a game which is designed with the solo gameplay in mind, and it really does show. The solo gameplay of 14 generations create its own set of challenge, with the building of engine in the first 7 rounds or so, while balancing the global parameters increase. Highly recommend to those who refuse solo gameplay altogether, cause this is a whole set of challenge. 

Multiplayer: 
Multiplayer is a different case. Instead of only focusing on engine building in the first few rounds, you have to keep your fellow terraformers under check, and increase your engine efficiency, while keeping in mind the map orientation and availability. 

Would recommend to all to try out.

RATING: 5
If the people teaching the game forget to mention that there's a new player variant, you will have a miserable first-play story. It dumps ten cards on you right off the bat, which you now need to evaluate as to whether you want to keep them or not, and your early game is heavily dependent on you making the right decisions before you understand the rhythm of play and the relative values of cash, cards, and other resources. Having to pay 3€ to keep each card, both here and after each round, is quite punishing, as it requires you to decide if you want to be able to play something before you can play it. New players are terrified of closing off options, and wind up overpaying for chaff they won't use.

RATING: 9
Fantastic game design, graphic design and production quality. I am not giving it a higher rating simply because the game is fairly long and that keeps me from wanting to play it repeatedly. 

My first game was with 5 new players, none of which had read the rules and it took us about 4 hours. We used the basic corporations, kept all 10 of our starting cards for free, and started at 0 on each production track.

My second game was with 4 players, each of which had played a couple times and it took us about 3 hours. We used the advanced corporations and cards, paid for our starting cards, started at 1 on each production track, and drafted our cards each round.

Having these multiple variants that can be used to alter the ease of learning the game and modify the length of the game is very helpful. 

I do love everything about the game, except the length!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I guess this is an ok game, but nothing really stands out as particularly innovative or flavorful. Yes, we are terraforming Mars and everything is in it's place to make that clear...still there's no exploration, no "movement" on the map, no sending things to Mars or out of Mars, no mechanics that involves the population of the cities we are building, no events. Soon, the map becomes a huge bag of points you begin to depend on in mid-late game, when you happen to draw cards that can't immediatly help your engine. In this sense, the game feel like another overcosted card game, with the components and all attached to it to make it "bigger" by not really that more interesting. Speaking about that, i personally think that better solutions could have been found to tie cards to game mechanics, instead than confine them to a draft completely disjointed by whatever is happening elsewhere in the game. Designers, in a sense, should sooner or later accept that if there is randomness and a considerable luck factor in their games, and they can't or don't want to directly fix that, well, they should deal with it and try to get advantage of it from other sides, not throw in a draft and hope the players will be convinced they are playing a fair game. Instead, half of the duration of this game will be spent waiting for other players to make up their minds about cards, and in the end someone will still got the worst side of it because the game won't be any less random as a result. Please STOP these draft going rampant everywhere in games!

RATING: 8.7
TM was the hype train of 2016, and in my opinion well deserved. It hits the right spot in terms of complexity and accessibility, making it ideal for the more experienced gamers, as well as the casual gamers. The core mechanics are surprisingly easy to get into, but the layers and depth of strategy is enough for experience gamers to bite into. 

I feel TM used the Martian theme in a thought-provoking and educative way.

It's fun to have an engine builder where you can still play after the engine fires up. In most engine builders, the moment your engine clicks the game effectively ends. 
Because the end-conditions are attached to the board, and not the deck in front of you, players are able to experience their engine humming away.

RATING: 6
[2017-06-17]
A játékosok a Mars bolygó terraformálásban vesznek részt közösen egy-egy multi céget alakítva, a játék végén a legtöbbet a célért tevő aratja le a babérokat. Kártyák kijátszásával vízeket fedezhetünk fel, növeljük a bolygó felszínének hőmérsékletét és oxigéndúsabbá tehetjük a légkört.
Tetszett a játék euró volta ellenére az erős tematikussága. Minden kártya különböző, rendkívül kidolgozottak és jók a mellékelt tematikus szövegek rajtuk. A bolygón a városok és növényzet terjeszkedése felgyorsul a hőmérséklet és oxigén növekedés hatására. Tetszett a térképen a különböző táj- és épületelemek egymásra hatása.
Nem tetszettek a díjak és mérföldkövek. A mérföldkövekből 3 váltható meg a játék során egyenként 8 pénzért, amikor teljesítette valaki a feltételét, ezekért 5 pont jár a játék végén. A díjak viszont 8-14-20 pénzbe kerülnek egymás után, itt viszont a játék végén nézzük meg, hogy az adott feltételben ki bizonyult a legjobbnak és ő kapja az 5 pontot, a második 2-őt. Nem értem, hogy egy bizonytalan, szerencsén is múló dolog miért drágább. Sok a mérföldkövekért kapható pont is. Nem tetszett, hogy van nyersanyag, ami a játék vége felé semmit nem ér, nem hasznosítható, erre figyelhettek volna. Bár kiegészítőben biztosan orvoslásra kerül. Négy új lapot kapunk körönként, amiből megvásárolhatunk. Ezt kevésnek éreztem és nagyon szerencsefüggőnek. Lehet jobb lett volna ide valami draftolós mechanizmus, bár akkor még hosszabb lett volna a játék. Legjobban a játékidő nem tetszett. 3-an 3 órán át játszottunk. Izgalmas volt, de ennyi nincs ebben a játékban. Kicsit rövidebbre is tervezhették volna.
Lehetett volna egy nagyon jó játék is ebből, de kicsit csalódtam az eddigi pozitív kommentek után.

RATING: 5
I don't mind the game, but it's overrated and doesn't deserve to be in top 10. I'm sorry but this game has no business being in the top 10 nor should it be rubbing shoulders with the likes of Scythe or Terra Mystica.

This is NOT a strategy game. There are no difficult decisions to make. All you need to do is some simple math conversion to figure out the best value cards to play or which ever builds/exploits your engine. It's basically a race game. 

Premise is simple: buy cards that either give you more resources, build an engine, or take resources away from someone. Then use resources for VP. Pretty standard fare.

Cons: Looooong play time for a fairly simple game. No box insert (components are expected to just free fall around in their baggies). The publisher cheaped out on the player mats which aren't very functional. Only 2 sets of crib provided. Art direction is horrible - inconsistent mix of art and cheap looking stock photos which really hurts the aesthetic.

Pros: Cool theme that works well with the mechanic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not quite sure why this one exploded as much as it has (currently rank 10 as of typing this). It is certainly a serviceable, above average, if not very good design. I just didn't feel like it brought anything new to the table. The player boards are a bit of a mess, so easy to knock cubes around. Is it the theme? I did think the theme was quite cool, which I why I was initially excited to give it ago. Is it a refinement of what has already been done before? It really felt like it was just a middling tableau builder with some decent board elements. Maybe there's a lot more to explore, but my first play didn't grab me enough to be excited about said exploration. I wouldn't turn down further play as of yet.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Rambling tangent:
There have been a couple new hotness games that have skyrocketed to the top of the charts that I just haven't really understood. Maybe I'm just settling into the scene after 5 and a half years. 
It seems like the first game to crack the slowly moving top 10 or 20 was Pandemic Legacy. It really shook things up, and probably for good reason. I am currently playing through it and enjoying it immensely. I am tempted to even give it a 9 or a 10 rating for doing what it it was designed to do [I]really[/I] well. 

Then there was Scythe. I think a huge reason Scythe has done so well is marketing and art direction. The game is good, but I really fail to see the hype. It was another, like Terraforming Mars, that when I actually played it, my experience fell far short of my expectations.  How is Scythe #6 overall? I feel like Stegmaier is a fantastic businessman who has been creating these middling games and marketing them really well. I've only played a couple, but not a single one has blown me away. 

Then we have Terraforming Mars, which I have discussed above. An ok game, but #10 of all time? Really?

Then there's Gloomhaven. Where did this come from? It bursted on the scene without me even really getting a glimpse of it approaching. I have not yet played it, so cannot pass judgement. #7 overall ATM, and likely to rise. This at least appears like another boon in the marketing strategy. I would love to try it someday, but I feel like I'll need to wait a couple print runs until the dust settles. 

There's only one old guard left in the top 10 from when I started gaming- Twilight Struggle. It's possibly the best game left in those ranks, though I imagine I'd love the new edition of TTA, and hope to try it someday. 

I think a lot of the above phenomena ultimately has to do with the hobby increasing in popularity, and therefore stuff being printed now is getting A TON of exposure, reaching a wider audience than ever before, This is making new stuff sift to the top at a much higher rate. I guess I am just sad that stuff I adore is being pushed out of the top 100. All this said, I am pleased as punch that this hobby is flourishing and especially that the Brass Kickstarter is doing so swimmingly (one of the good oldies that is reaching a brand new audience!).  

/end curmudgeony rant.

RATING: 6
Rating after one play:

Good - The game feels really unique and is fun. It is primarily driven via the cards that you draw and finding synergy between them. It feels like there are a lot of different combos to be made which is great. I found myself thinking about all of the possibilities in the game the day after we played it.

Bad - The component quality, graphic design, and the card artwork are atrocious. The box is thin, the game board doesn't lay flat and the insert came ripped. The art on the cards is a mix of real photos (that look like stock photos), clip art, and decent illustrations. The player mats look like they were designed by a high school student in MS Word. And the worst part is that this game retails for $70!! Blood Rage retails for $80 and it is packed full of minis. There is no reason that this game should be $70. 

The game also overstays it's welcome. It feels like the game should have ended a couple rounds sooner. Our first game with four players took about 2.5 hours. Terraforming Mars isn't a heavy game. 2.5 hours is just too long for a game that is this light. I hope the play time gets better with more plays.

RATING: 8
Have only played the basic game so far. Enjoyed a lot, The heart of the game lies in the cards so I could see this game making some people unhappy with bad card draws. This can probably be mitigated a fair bit with the drafting system (which I haven't tried yet). That said, I'm pretty tickled. I didn't mind getting random cards. Lots of strategy choices, other players matter, not just for the occasional "take that" elements, but because you're trying to beat them in achieving certain milestones. My only real problem with the game is the fiddlyness. There are lots of "when you play that you get those and then that means you get that too" added to "oh, and that card ALSO means you get that". It can be a little brain burny for that reason.

The game is also quite attractive, barring the somewhat dull looking planet itself (and it looks better as soon as you start planting trees and creating oceans). I love the goofy cubes for keeping track of your resources. The tracks on your individual player mats are prone to being knocked so that's a slight ding (it didn't bother us).

RATING: 9
This is an incredible game.  In this game each of the players is terraforming Mars to make it habitable for human beings.  Once there is enough water, oxygen, and heat on the planet for human beings to survive the game ends and the player who contributed most to the effort is the winner.

The gameplay is almost entirely made up of three components.  The first, and largest, is tableau building.  The game is entirely driven by a project deck you buy cards from each round.  The cards do everything from increase the levels of water, oxygen, and heat on the planet to provide you with pets to cuddle on Mars.  The second is tile placement.  While we are developing Mars we are adding oceans, greenery, and city tiles to a map and their placement matters a lot for end game scoring.  The final component is the resource economy.  There are 6 different main resources to manage, each of them being varying degrees of important depending on the strategies you choose to pursue and many more ancillary resources can enter the game through project cards.

I absolutely love games with a lot of content and high replay value.  After one play I knew I would love this game.  And this was even the "beginner" mode where a third to a half of the "advanced" project cards were removed and we played with the same beginner corporations with no powers.  I also love games with asynchronous player powers so I'm sure I will enjoy future games more.  My first game was also with the max 5 players and the main concern I had going into the game was whether or not the max player count would crowd the map too much.  Now my main concern is that with fewer it would be too open taking away meaningful decisions and player interaction.  We did go through the entire project deck but this was also with a huge chunk of it removed.

The game itself is great but it also has serious component issues in my opinion.  The cards, player cubes, and tiles are fine and the rulebook is actually pretty well written but past that it could use some serious love.  The board is tiny and crowded, it makes an otherwise epic feeling game feel much smaller.  The player boards suffer in the same way being thin paper boards with sections for each of the resources.  Resources you collect a lot of and can easily lose your place do to an errant elbow.  And finally, the resource cubes (the same ones are used for everything which is fine since there are 6+ resources in the game) are of terrible quality.  My copy (which I got used) has supposedly only been played 3 times now and according to the previous owner the paint on these cubes was already peeling and warping when he opened it.  A quick search online reveals this is a pretty common complaint.

It's sad because such a great game deserves better care.  This has actually been a common occurrence with Stronghold Games in my opinion (although there are worse offenders, like Splotter Spellen).  They get hold of such great games but the best level the components have ever reached for me has been mediocre.  And this one certainly falls closer to "poor".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Wow.  Finally got to play this and was impressed.  VERY fun game, will play this anytime.

Now that I have many plays under the belt I can describe this game in more detail.

This game should take you about 2 hours to play.  The biggest drag on this is if you draft.  i get that people like drafting, as they think that it will let them see more cards.  The problem is that the cards that get passed to you have been sifted for the best stuff, and often they have been hate drafted to you.  This leaves you, on average, with fewer useful cards each game, and the game takes at least an extra 45 minutes.  An experienced player will understand that cards are NOT the only way to get points or build your engine.  So a bad card draw where you ditch all four cards really is no big deal.  Bad cards only matter to the player that is literally sifting the deck for the one specific card they think they need .

As is, the game is an acceptable length (shorter IS better after all), but much more than that and you can start looking at your watch, wondering if you'll get to play anything else after this one ends.  The average player will be surprised often by the winner as the points aren't quite clear, though with experience it can become pretty clear who is going to win, even though there is still another 30 minutes left to play.  This is fine so long as you enjoy playing it as much as I do.

I'm not one for theme to matter in general, but this one really hits my sweet spot.  I will play this multiple times in the same day which is unheard of for me.  I would rate it an 11 if possible.  Just, please, no drafting....

I have to ammend this 10.  It is a 10 so long as there is no drafting.  With drafting it falls all the way down to a 5 or a 6 at best.  Friends don't let friends draft.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Tableau-builder sort of reminiscent of Phil Eklund's recent output in its combination of vaguely scientific basis and large numbers of unique cards with special powers. Players build up six different kinds of income (!) which can be spent either on cards, things worth victory points, or to change certain global parameters. These global parameters indicate the progress of terraforming -- i.e. the increase of oxygen levels, global temperature and water to a level capable of sustaining life -- and trigger both the end-game and restrict the play of various cards, e.g. you can't introduce fish into the oceans while the oceans are frozen solid so temperatures must rise substantially.

While the thematic integration is pleasant I am not convinced at all by the cards. A large number of unique cards is fine and dandy, but players generally pick up at most 4 per turn. There are a limited number of other opportunities to draw, but card cycling is not a focus as it is in e.g. Race for the Galaxy. While many cards are good, it's difficult to deliberately pursue synergies and play is likely to be extremely tactical.

To be clear, I'm not saying that card synergies are impossible. They are, in fact, required to win. Rather, the issue is that luck of the draw is substantial and there are limited avenues for mitigation. I would never play again without the drafting variant, which in my experience does tend to leave players with cards more useful to them than not (i.e. minimal hate-drafting). But it is still uncomfortably easy to have, for example, a starting company that gives a bonus for building with titanium and then never getting a titanium production card.

A number of cards also have a "take that" element, usually of the form that a target players loses X resources or Y income. They're rare enough that these attacks aren't constant, but they do compound an already capricious card pool.

It's not a bad game, just not a great one.

RATING: 9
This is an outstanding game! Love the thematic synergies, tons of interesting choices (game never dragged), and fairly easy to learn (but still feels quite meaty). 

The design hits on a lot of different cylinders (card play, resource management, tile laying, goal achievement, tableau building, etc.).

Production values are good (with a few minor exceptions), while the luck of the draw can have a moderate effect on the game. Drafting is available, but it does increase play time by 15 minutes or so (recommended).

TM excels at giving players a real sense of purpose and satisfaction - it's extraordinarily  thematic. Indeed, this may just be the most thematic game I've ever played.

For those concerned with the slight "Take that!" element of card-play, don't be - it's relatively minor (not that many cards), and they help keep the game balanced. Good feature in my view.

As if that wasn't enough, the solo game is very good (difficult to win and plays fast).  It plays similar to the multi-player version, but with different goals (so you'll need to adjust some of your strategies).

Extremely replayable, even after 12 sessions it still seems fresh to me. The 200+ card deck is awesome!

Lots of hype surrounding this release, and yet it meets and even exceeds that hype. TM has strong potential to be a major hit, I believe. 

Best "Game of the Year" so far!

RATING: 8.5
Pushes all the right buttons. Decent amount of replayability, unique player powers, a combination of both resource management and game progression. Overall a very solid game that does a lot of things very good.

My complaints on the game are that while it has a decent amount of replayability I wish there was more (hopefully an expansion will solve that). Also, some cards are insanely powerful early game (like the "discount future cards played" ones) and many others are completely useless depending on too many situations. I also feel like there isn't as much long term planning as I'd like. Like if there was something akin to the 6-cost developments in Race for the Galaxy that give you huge end game points and guide your overall strategy. There are a few cards that synergize together and push you in a certain strategy (like the research resource one or the animal growing card), I feel like the game would be improved with more cards like that. Finally, there is a bit too much "take that" on some aspects of the game that are hard to mitigate if everyone gangs up on you.

Definitely good though and highly recommended. Hope they do an expansion for it and soon!

RATING: 10
Fantastic game, perfect for space and/or science enthusiast - potentially a must have. Many of the developments and events in the game are based on actual ideas for terraforming Mars. The games does an excellent job of mixing real science into a fun game. At the end of the game, your group will collectively build cities, create lakes, and cover the surface of Mars in plants, animals and possibly even pets (there's a card for our four legged friends in there). While there are many routes to victory (points), regardless of who wins or losses, everyone works together to collectively transform Mars into a livable planet, leave everyone with a sense of satisfaction. The one shortfall of this game is there can be moments of the game that can feel not entirely smooth or polished, keeping this game from a perfect 10. Who am I kidding! Despite a few rough spots here and there, this game is excellent and deserves a 10!

RATING: 8.5
Really good game.  A lot of great things going on, but component quality is horseshit.  I personally hate the metallic cubes in general, why could different color cubes just be used?  If the table is bumped this game is toast.  A cube floating into the wrong box could be game breaking.  Also, every single card being unique is rough but at the same time something I enjoy.  There are just so many cards to know and so many in general that forming  a strategy I would imagine is difficult, also can get a bit unbalanced when someone knows the cards much better than others.  It's a very reactive game, your corporation determines what you are looking for and then you have to react to the cards you are dealt in order to maximize your ability and production stats.  I actually enjoy that part the most!  Placing of tiles is interesting, and i really enjoy the end game conditions.  Getting all three tracks to max capacity allows the game to progress differently each time and ensures some cards are more or less powerful in different games.  That randomness could also kill an individual game as you may only see cards that are useless for that particular game-flow.  Interesting game I'd like to explore more.

RATING: 9
Game that obviously was designed with a lot of love. It is a very thematic engine building tableau game. 

Rating is for the multi-player experience and is preliminary as so far, I've played multiplayer only once (with the wimpy settings of starting resources and beginner corporations). Surprisingly, this was just an 'ok' experience. As we all not yet knew what we were doing, for most the card pick was not yet clear and it was hard to estimate the time of ending (let alone influence) and this prevented us from pre-arranging ourselves to grabbing the right things at the right time. But all of our gaming group, even our wargaming/competitive buddies, could see the potential.

Now, I have played (and won) the solo game with all corporations but the extended ones, getting 100+ VP consistently. And as a solo game, this game has already proven its' superb design to me. Though some cards are pretty OP in solo (think Aquifer Pumping), it is winnable even without those cards and it is a very enjoyable experience playing it solo. The genius is that the relative card value assigned to each card does vary a lot between solo- and multi-player. As an example, the aforementioned Aquifer Pumping is usually quite worthless in multi-player. I don't care about putting down oceans so other can get more placement bonuses, I'd prefer to focus on oxygen instead. And the 'take that' cards, while sometimes quite valuable in solo, become really great in multi-player. 

Result? I found myself wondering the value of each card I drew.. in solo I'd take Lichen, Advanced Lichen or any other non-prerequisite plant production card anytime but in the full game... it all depended whether I'd go for greeneries and it's corresponding milestones. Or heat. Or money. Or... and you have three other players all scheming as well. 

Fully expect this rating to go up with multiple plays. As a solo game, this game is already rated 9.5 for me. Great game, if you like engine builders you have to pick up this one.

[APR 2017] Played a couple of times multiplayer since and yes, also then it is a winner. What a great thematic game, what a great way to spend time together. Rating revised upwards to a 9

RATING: 7
Will only play draft variant.  In an engine building game of any length and depth, it's not acceptable that luck should determine who ultimately wins the game, and that can definitely happen in this game.  Early synergy can be stumbled upon, and it can give a leg up that can be difficult if not impossible to eventually overcome if another player simply isn't drawing the cards necessary to set up an equivalent engine early enough.  Still, there's a lot of good to this game, and it could have been an 8+ if either the luck element weren't so great or the game weren't as long.  7 is still a considerably high rating, and I do think this game deserves it.  It just isn't the most amazing game ever, and definitely not what I think should make top 100 - most overrated game of the year, imo, but still pretty good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
tl;dr: very good indeed

I played the prototype of this game in late 2014. I quite liked it, but it did still need some work. That came in the form of redoing the turn structure. In the original when it was your turn, you did all your actions. Now you just do one or two actions on your turn and on to the next player. This is a great step forward as it streamlines game play a lot. It makes downtime lower and allows you to think about your actions while other players are at it.
What I like a lot about this game is that it offers a huge amount of variety. The amount of unique cards is staggering but there also seems to be a variety of strategies to explore. In our game one player focused on energy and heat. An other player focused on animals and other cards that gave points. I focused on building cities and greeneries. Scores were pretty close.
There is a tiny bit of take that in the game, but it's not too bad.
The rule book is sometimes a bit confusing, it could have been worded or structured a bit clearer, but in did fall into place pretty nicely when we started playing.
Good stuff. Maybe not the 14th best game of all time, but I haven't agreed with a lot of the current top 20 lately. It seems like new games are being over hyped quite a bit. Good games, but THAT good?

Initial rating: 7.5/10
BGG scale: 8/10

Score after prototype play: 7.2/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Point salad and no knowing about the game without studying the cards in detail. :( Small type.

Cards are mostly clear, but it's a Deck of Many Things game where you can really only play well knowing how the deck is composed--unless it's remarkably fair and all paths are equal. The deck is huge, so only in a 5p game will you cycle through it, meaning it's essentially a 1D[i]n[/i] system with no really coherent strategy possible--roulette, basically.

Tile buying is more certain, but more expensive. So, you activate cards hoping at random (unless you've analysed the cards) that they will happen to blend into a coherent strategy.

To be sure, optimization is possible, but this is a very beginner-unfriendly game; the antithesis would be a Knizia game where generally all the mechanisms of the game are known from the rules.

RATING: 6.9
I like Terraforming Mars well enough but I don't get what's so special about it that it routinely gets multiple full tables at large gaming meetups. Perhaps it's that in the end, there's very little on top of its core mechanic -- build engine, receive resources, repeat. It's very much a raw engine/tableau builder with no pretenses or distractions like worker placement, auctioning, timed random events, or face-up drafting. And I think that design really speaks to a lot of people: unvarnished and unfiltered access to engine pieces with tempo as the primary indicator of performance.

Note.
We now use the "Solar Variant" which shortens the game and makes the game more enjoyable for me because I found the game dragged. 

Solar Variant
At the end of each generation, the starting player has an additional phase (the Solar phase) in which he MUST choose to raise one parameter or place an ocean tile. There is no cost to perform that action nor does he gain any TR or tile-placing bonuses. Abilities from any player that trigger when certain parameter raises or when an ocean tile is placed do still apply, though.
