=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There's been a lot of hype around this one.  After one play I can say it lived up to the hype.  The game reminds me a lot of [thing=154203][/thing] in the way that it is mostly multiplayer solitaire with unique races and a similar action system.  However, TM fixes my biggest complaint with Imperial Settlers, which is that your starting cards can single-handedly determine who wins the game.  Similar to Imperial Settlers, TM has some cards that are good early and some cards that are good late.  But instead of starting with 4 cards and drawing 2 per turn, you start with 10 cards and draw 4 per turn, just keeping that cards that you want to pay for.  I think this extra card draw mitigates the randomness enough to make me happy.

The theme is great.  Some of it is a little wonky (building asteroids and comets), but it is unique and works well.  I love how many different paths there are to victory.  That combined with the wide variety of corporations makes me think the replayability will be very high.  Our first play took about 3 hours, which seemed a bit too long for me.  But if that gets down to more like 2 hours, this game will be a classic.

Update after 1 year and 3 more plays: TM has grown on me.  The play time is still about 3 hours, but that doesn't bother me.  Two of those 3 plays were with the standard rules, and my complaints about randomness of the card draw remained.  But, oh man, drafting makes the game significantly better and I will never go back.

I just love the asymmetry and multiple paths to victory so much.  The decisions and combo building are satisfying.  The mechanics are married to the theme, which is the #1 thing I look for in a game.  I still don't like the "take that" cards, which might be the one thing keeping this game from a 10 for me.  The only reason I'm not buying this is because the only game group that would actually play it already has 3 copies.

RATING: 7
I found Terraforming Mars to be an interesting, albeit somewhat flawed game. The theme works well, and the three-part end-game condition was works well. There is a constant tension, at least early on, over which cards to pay for and keep because playing cards also costs money, making for some challenging decisions. The production upkeep each round is a little fiddly (and felt a bit like Through the Ages in that respect), but this isn't a fatal flaw. The only real downside is that you are dealt four random cards each round and decide which of those to pay for and keep. However, it is often the case that the new cards you are dealt have no synergies whatsoever with your starring cards (and thus your overall strategy). So, people who are randomly dealt cards that work well with what they happen to be doing are going to thrive, while others may simply stall out due to the luck of the draw. It seems a drafting system that let players see and select from a greater number of cards might have worked better here, at least in terms of competitive balance.

RATING: 8
Only played once, so rating might change. The core system is great and offers a lot of fun gameplay. The 'take 1 or 2 actions' rule is very clever.
Our 3 player game took close to 4 hours to complete (corporate era + drafting) which is way too long, even though the downtime wasn't bad at all. I wish there was some builtin progression that forced the game onward, to create more pressure towards terraforming and the endgame. But I only played once so I really have no say in the matter. Apart from that I also don't like the take that effects. I honestly don't think it adds anything. There's enough interaction anyway. 

Update after a couple of more plays:
I enjoy the game but it still feels unnecessarily long. We've played with drafting each round which I actually doubt is a good idea. Drafting is generally a great mechanic, but it works best when there is some uncertainty regarding the other player's strategies. A couple of rounds into the game, it's quite clear which cards you should avoid to pass along. Also, hate drafting comes without a real cost in this game. In other games, hate drafting would cause you give up a card that you could have used yourself, but in TM you rarely buy the cards anyway (typically 0-2 of 4 each round), so it's cheap to hate draft. This leads to the drafting often becoming rather pointless and just time consuming, instead of adding depth. I know the designer prefers the game without drafting, so I guess he knows what he's talking about. Next time I hope to play without drafting.

RATING: 6.7
Decent game, but suffers from randomness.

It's a good concept and definitely fun for a few plays. The game revolves around building cities, greenspace and water on the surface of mars, and building card engines to do these things efficiently.  The game encourages players to build semi-cooperatively by allowing players to score points from one another's constructed tiles, and setting goals that are shared by all players (Increasing temperature, oxygen, creating water, etc).  As more terraforming is completed, more cards and options are unlocked for all players.

As a card-based game, it suffers from a lot of randomness.  Sometimes you'll get stuck because you can't build a good engine, or you're drawing cards that you're unable to play.  Other times you'll get way ahead of everyone else because you hit a few cards that interact really well together.  My biggest gripe with the game was how much luck was involved.  While there are a lot of strategic elements, ultimately you'll have a hard time getting ahead if you don't have a bit of luck on your side.

A solid game, I would play it again for sure, but somehow it just doesn't feel as rewarding as it should.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a great game of simplicity and theme. Go and get your copy today.

RATING: 10
Terraforming Mars was a game that hit my radar recently. I guess there's been a lot of buzz about it, but I missed all that until a copy showed up in my group. I was immediately intrigued as the game is beautiful and there were many cubes, tons of cards and you're building things. Also, the idea of terraforming Mars is an incredibly appealing theme to me. I almost always love when games incorporate a realistic science element, which this game does well.

While the game has a central board, the heart and soul of the game is the cards. You're drawing cards, buying them and then playing them to do various things in the game. Mostly improving your production capabilities or actually building things on Mars, or just flat out making Mars more Earth-like by increasing the temperature, amount of oxygen in the atmosphere or the amount of water on Mars.

Cards have a monetary cost, sometimes an additional cost or penalty, and sometimes prerequisites that you must meet to play them. Many cards combo off of other things you play. Doing well in this game is going to require that you play cards that synergize well. Almost every card I saw was something that I really wanted and I spent way too much money buying cards only to realize that I just was never going to be able to play them all.

Whenever you do something that actually improves conditions on Mars, you get a bump on the income track (which is also the VP track). There's also cards that get you points. And building cities next to forests gets your points as do your forests.

There's just a lot going on in this game and a great deal to think about. It's definitely a game where it took me the first play to know what anything was worth and what a good strategy should be. And a game where I immediately was looking forward to the next play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
About [thing=167791][/thing]:

[b]1) What is it?[/b]
[thing=167791][/thing] is an economic and strategic game about making money while turning Mars into a proper planet to live. It mostly use variable powers, hand management and tile placement as mechanics. The goal is to have the best terraforming rating, which can be achieved in several ways.

[thing=167791][/thing] calls for attention right way, with is thematic board, pretty resource cubes and a stack of cards bigger than the one in [thing=28143][/thing] after some expansions.

The game offers a lot of options and paths to victory, leading a little on a way by the company taken by the player, as they do something better than others, and using this advantage is important, but not determinant or impossible to stray away. And there is a sort of cooperative feel, since increasing temperature and oxygen levels might help others by allowing them to play certain cards.

It also counts with a heavy dose of timming, which, alonside with the amount of available choices and decisions, makes for a learning curve that will take some plays to get around and, due to high random factor of the card draw, will demand constant adjustments and watchful eyes to not lose opportunities.

While the game revolves around making Mars better to receive people, plants and animals, it has, surprisingly to me, some dose of "take that" elements in the cards - usually by lowering resources from the others, be from grabbing money or using their animals to feed your carnivores, and so on. Sure, companies don't tend to play nice with the competition, I get that, but in this sort of strategic game, this does seems, while not out of place nor even unthematic, a bit unnecessary - likely the "best" way the designers found to include more interaction during gameplay, and, if so, pretty weak way to go.

[b]2) How do you play?[/b]
I will try to surmmize: players start with 20 of terraforming rating. This is also a value of income and doubles as points - the bigger your rating, more money you will get each round and more points you will have.

At the start of the game each player will receive 2 companies and pick one to play. All of them give different starting money, resources, income and/or special ability. At the same time, players will receive 10 cards and must choose which to keep in hand: there is no maximum amount of cards in hand, but retain cards cost $3 per card (once paid, you don't have to pay for them again in later rounds).

At the start of each round, except the first, players will get 4 cards, and will choose which to keep and which to discard. The cost to retain cards is the same: $3 per card (but this is only valid for the new 4 cards drawn).

During the rounds, players can do 1 or 2 actions each turn they have. They can be the same. Some actions are: play cards, use 8 plants to build a Greenery, use 8 heat to increase the temperature, actions in cards, build standard projects, trigger a Milestone, create an Award, and so on.

Some of these actions will allow players to build stuff on the board, usually a Sea, a Greenery or a City, but can also be some special constructions. Seas have proper places on the board, and adding them increases your rating in 1. Greenery must be placed adjacent to a tile you already own, if possible, and increase oxygen level in 1, your rating in 1, 1 point and the end of the game, and $2 for each adjacent Sea tile. City increase your income in 1 (not the same as rating, but both give money), $2 for each adjacent Sea tile and, at the end of the game, will be worth 1 point for each adjacent Greenery. Several places on the board give an reward when a tile is build there: usually plants, but also can give steel, titanium or cards.

Cards will do all sort of things: increase income (be of plants, heat, energy, steel, money or titanium), place tiles, give discounts, new types of actions (as breeding animals, creating beneficial viruses, etc), attack others, and so on.

Many of the actions will cost money. Therefore, build and managing your economy will be key.

The game will end once the oxygen levels reach 14%, temperature hits 8°C (celsius) and all the oceans tiles are on the board.  In the round these three things are true, it will be the final one. After this final round, players will get income and have one last opportunity to build Greeneries. Once this is done, players will score their Greenery and City tiles, and also points coming from Milestones, Awards and cards.

The player with the most terraforming rating (points) will be the winner!

[b]3) Which are the decisions made during play?[/b]
Wow. So many. To put is simple:
- Which cards to keep (money is used to retain then and also to play them);
- Which cards to use (considering their effetcs, restrictions and cost);
- Where to place tiles (the location is important for gaining a immediate reward, and also for end game scoring purposes);
- Which action to do (timming has some great importance here, as, say that you increased oxygen - this can allow someone else to play a card she wouldn't be able until then; or you build a Greenery and, almost afterward, someone puts a City next by, meaning you just gave 1, 2 or more points to that person; or using a card to steal or reduce the resource of someone else, preventing them from being able to do an action; or advancing temperature or oxygen to the limit, blocking others from gaining rating with their heat or when building Greeneries; and so on).

Though the decision tend to not be overly complex, almost all have lasting effects, be for income or by acting on the board. Money is tight and prioritize is normally the order of the day. Thinking ahead is also required, as is usual to keep cards not only for the current round, but for way down the road, when a restriction for it to be played (like temperature of -4°C or warmer; or 4 science icons; etc) will be achieved.

Sure, there is a lot of tatical play going around here - making the best of that projects (cards) appear is very relevant in doing well in the game, but forethought and preparation can win you the race.

[b]4) What are the good things in the game?[/b]
- Huge amount of decision points with lasting results;
- The special abilities of the companies era good enough to be taken advantage of but not to corner a player to a single path of development;
- High replay value, as the amount of cards alongside the different companies make for a varied play experience;
- Very good production value;
- Strong theme, present both in the board (the placement of seas and mineral deposits), actions (like purchasing projetcs - cards -, than paying to implant them), effects of cards, and so on;
- Interactive, as players battle for positions of the board and opportunities, both in awards and milestones, but also in the main ways to increase their rating: oxygen and temperature levels.

[b]5) Which are the bad news?[/b]
- Luck of the drawn can help or harm one more than others;
- "Take that" cards, which simply I don't think fit properly with everything else in the game;
- As with games with many choices, timming and considerations, some AP can happen and downtime issues can be present.

[b]6) How do you feel while playing?[/b]
I looked across the table, to that silver and coppery cubes, above the Heat space of my opponent, just knowing he could increase temperature. Nay, that he definitely would. But when, goddammit? I look my cards and see my dear Trees - but they require -4°C, only one more step. I do some trivial action and pass - I'm worried, I don't have any more of those left, and I spend too much already, and if I spend on something else, to delay, then I won't have enough for my trees!

Then, when you think, by reading, that you have figure the game out, you learn that the requirements also work the other way around: having maximum of something in order to be allowed to enter play. Sure, there is no way of knowing what cards the others have and what limitations are holding them back. Yet, you do know that, for each step ahead taken, one window might be closed and another might open. And it must be beautiful to look outside a window in Mars. And near the end all this is left behind, as everyone just want to increase their ratings and prevent others from doing the same.

Anyway, it was already mentioned and I add to the chorus: is similar, in feel, to playing [thing=72225][/thing]. You have the same "cooperative end goal while competing" (reduce carbon emission; make Mars livable), and in the process, there is a lot of timming considerations and ponderations. In [thing=72225][/thing] you don't truly want to start a project that someone else will take over, but, sometimes, you will either have to or must to, in order to avoid an early defeat. In [thing=167791][/thing] there is no defeat for everyone (maby in an expansion nearby...), but you want to increase oxygen levels and temperature, as you gain rating with this, which means more money and points - win, win, right? Except that, by doing this, you might allow someone to play a kickass card sooner than later, and reap the benefits for more time. Maybe even a single round gives and edge. 

This is one of the many positive aspects in [thing=167791][/thing], one that brings more color to decision-making and interaction, but hardly the only one. Resources, particularly money, the board state and using opportunities are also there.

There are some oddballs, like the "take that" cards and the AP that all the considerations around your actions might lead ("If I spend this, I won't be able to do this. But this is better now. However, without this, I won't be able to to that later, and if I keep delaying, there is not even a point in holding this damn thing. But, wait, wait, maybe if I place this there, get that $4, I could play this! Yes! Now... wait. I could then build a City...") - it goes with the territory and, while this is player dependent, the game sure doesn't make it easier for the poor sod.

In the end, [thing=167791][/thing] gives a lot for the players, providing a rich environment for development of the companies, many decisions, all wrap up in a very nice presentation. Recommended!

RATING: 3
First few plays: What a game. Relatively long, your engine goes from nothing to massive over a slow, fun arc. But: if you fall behind, the length and the downtime start to seem eternal, your opponents' turns taking forever and making your situation ever worse. There's a point when you need to concede this game, because playing it out can be like waiting in a doctor's office. I don't see that problem going away. But if this is not a perfect game, it is DEFINITELY a great game, and a lot of fun as long as it stays close.

Couple more plays: yeah, no. It looks and feels like a great game, until we played it enough to see that it's often wildly unbalanced, with amazing downtime, extreme swerves of randomness, and the opposite of fun. Eg, to start the game with Helion vs Cinematix, you have 28 less spending units to start the game. You sit on your hands and watch your opponent take actions. You take 45 minutes just trying to get some production going, because you can't afford anything, and then your opponent spends 1 dollar (earning, as Cinematix, 2 dollars back for the event, so making a profit on playing the card) on a card that robs 7 dollars from you, and you say, oh, now I can't take the action I've been planning for three turns, so you sit on your hands some more while your opponent continues to play. That card cost ONE DOLLAR for the opponent--the cards' costs are NOT balanced to their effects. Really not fun at all. Biggest disappointment I've had in gaming so far.

Gave it a another chance. Game was balanced without any random take-that swings, but the same problems started to come up--VERY long downtime even at 2p, and really just a matter of playing what cards you happen to draw. In this game, we forgot to do the card drafting, and were just taking what we drew. With drafting, it's definitely less luck-driven, but to me, the bottom line is that the overall arc of the game is bad: too long (fix it with a house rule), with the early rounds being much quicker and more fun as you build the beginnings of a strategy, gradually slowing down into a slog in later rounds as you grind through the deck hoping to get good cards.

RATING: 6
Two issues with this game: scaling and random card draws:
I played at 2 players because of the way the game comes to a close it is just as long as it would be at higher player counts, possibly longer. As a consequence you wind up doing a lot more stuff as many of the cards have odd rule exceptions and lasting effects it becomes impossible to keep track of everything that you can benefit from in a given round. It becomes as fiddly as the little bronze cubes.
The other issue comes from getting the right cards, this ultimately is an engine building game and so most of the satisfaction in the game should come from building a finely tuned engine which is just starting to hum as the game ends. The problem is with this you could build an engine and never get any fuel. People complain about the random card draws in Imperial Settlers, I know that a bad hand at the start can really hamper you but ultimately there are always things to do with those cards because they truly are multi-use here your options are: don't buy the card, pay to trigger it's effect or buy it and give up later costing you 2 money. The cards not being multi-use isn't the problem here it's the fact that the randomness of the draw prevents you from planning for the future and building an engine in an engine building game, and in a game of this length I really should have more say over the route I take, it shouldn't just be 3 hours of trying to do the best with the cards I have now. All that said I hope that the drafting variant will mitigate this and when I play again I will definitely try it but: I fear it will add to the length of the game which will only add to the problems it already has. Perhaps one thing they could have considered is making you move up the tracks quicker in a 2 player game.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game is so extremely satisfying to play. 
Being able to gradually expand your empire and customize your strengths while planning for short term and long term goals is very rewarding. 
The card play is enriched by the resource management and production manipulation; having to think "I could pay for this expensive card now and reap the rewards, but if I sit back and first play these other three cards, then in 2 turns it will all be much cheaper"
Over the course of the game your engine builds into a strong and versatile machine and every production phase feels like christmas.
The interaction with other players will vary greatly depending on whether you play with the Corporate Era cards, but at all times it felt very balanced. It can be cruel to steal / destroy other players resources, but it's only a minor setback and it never takes someone out of the race. 

Now, about the two primary ways to play:

Standard Game
Much shorter than Corporate Era and in fact falls in line with what is written on the box. This version of the game feels very smooth and there is lots of tension as people push the global parameters around much faster, which puts pressure on all aspects of play. The Standard Game has a lot more significant player interaction and jockeying, and the focus is very much on the surface of mars. It is, in my opinion, the definitive version.

Corporate Era
As you probably know, in the box are the Corporate Era cards and variable method of play. This style of game is much longer and has players really build their engines from scratch. It is a much more cerebral and insular style of game, where players will sit and stare at their own tableau and play-area rather than at the board of Mars. The player interaction, while more aggressive and (possibly) frequent, is not as interesting as the Standard Game, as there is so much more room and time to rebuild anything lost / stolen. The global parameters will go up and you will not so much as bat an eye-lid unless it's the final one or two spots.

Of the two styles of play, I prefer the feeling of building my engine with the Corporate Era cards and variant setup, because it is more deliberate and controlled. You really feel as though you built that company up from scratch and it satisfies.
The Standard Game, though, would have to be my favourite method of play, not just because it fits into a reasonable time-frame, but because it's really all about the terraforming and the board-state. Everything you do contributes more immediately to your goals and strategies. 

The bad?
Sure, it doesn't get 10/10 for me and I'll let you know why, but please understand that despite the following, this game should be on your shelf if you like Strategy, Science, Card-play, Resource Management and Engine Building.

I hate the player boards. They utterly fail to deliver an appealing look and feel. Everyone has said it, so I won't go on about it, I will be finding a suitable solution for this mess as soon as I can but it seriously detracts from the experience. BUT. It has to be said that this negativity melts away as SOON as you start playing. The game really is good enough to distract you from this.
It is a bad thing but it can be fixed. 

There is only one other thing that lowered the score of the game for me...

Between the different player counts that this game supports (2 up to 5) the feeling, strategy, play-style and evolution of play is wildly different. Because the global parameters remain the same throughout the player counts, a 2 player game will see roughly the same amount of cards played as a 5 player game, but the distribution (as you can tell) is different. In 4 and 5 players you will only just be getting your engine up and running, technically, when the game ends, compared to 2-3 players where your engine will be purring like a kitten as you cross the finish line. 
This disparity isn't really a negative thing, but for me it loses merit in the overall experience of the game because the game is SUCH a good experience and having to adjust that within the amount of players doesn't so much feel like "replayabilty". It could be said that this adds depth to the way you can play and that you must be versatile but I disagree. My experience of the game will vary depending on the amount of players which adds unnecessary complexity to the explanation and anticipation of play. The consistency of the experience falters and it must be noted. 

In any case, at least give it a try, ESPECIALLY if someone has custom player mats ;)

Thanks for reading.

RATING: 7.5
Ever since Race For The Galaxy, I am a big fan of tableaubuilders. As such, I was really looking foward to trying out Terraforming Mars. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I can understand where the hype is coming from as much as I can see why TM will not be a cup of tea for everyone. The game uses card drafting to build a personal tableau of powers for engine building and scoring. There is a spatial element on the central board where players compete to place cities, form oceans or add greenery tiles. I would contend that this board is a minor element of the game. Where there is competition for spots, in general, you can place the tiles and get a few points. Therefore, if you are not a card drafting fan, this game is not going to pull at your strings. That said, the card iconology is not complicated and the text on most of the cards are superbly written.

Like most card drafting games, TM suffers from low player interaction. Each turn as players go through their motion, I have no clue what they are activating or triggering. It becomes impossible to voice out every action. Subsequently, late in the game, everyone just goes through their turns quietly doing what they do or mumbling their actions as others try to listen in. The map does present some interaction but these interactions are relatively passive as there is nothing can be done to interrupt or alter placement of tiles on the board. One just has to anticipate.

TM is highly rated for a reason. The card drafting mechanism is married beautifully with the theme of terraforming mars. I felt that each card I played altered the mars landscape and there is a rush between companies to produce a habitable planet. It's too bad that each player is so busy with their own individual tableau that a more complete story arc never develops. 

Lengthwise, the basic game fits within the mid-heavy weight category and slots in nicely as the main course for the evening. It should be noted somewhere in the booklet that the basic largely ignore steel and titanium as a resource.

RATING: 5
I've only played this once, so maybe it gets better after multiple plays, but my first impression was that it was just really, really............. ordinary. Like, I'm sure I've played a game just like it, or almost like it before somewhere. Maybe I've played several games just like it and forgotten all of them!

RATING: 7
1st impression. SU&SD nail another review. I'm struggling to see what the fuss is here. There is not much game - it's more about playing some cards and telling a story. It looks like a heavy euro, but none of the decisions are difficult - the game basically plays itself and you, as a player, just watch it unfold while you keep the books up to date. I also find the talk around the drafting variant fascinating. People seem to claim it reduces the randomness, but drafting only four cards in a four or five player game doesn't reduce the randomness at all. The cards are very easy to order, and that order is unlikely to vary between skilled players. Really, you might as well just deal em out and save 30 mins. Initially I thought this was a more elaborate 7 Wonders, but the drafting in 7 Wonders is much more agonising and therefore impactful.

RATING: 6
There's a great game in here, but it's buried under lots of luck and bad incentives.

The actual planet board tends is decentralized as everyone focused on engine building. It's unfortunate that the gameplay as promised: "Terraform Mars" is really different than the game you actually play: "build an efficient corporation". It's definitely enjoyable, but I wouldn't recommend it to most players.

Many of the resources are not mechanically different from each other other than that they are essentially "special money" and there are many corporations that make them "slightly better special money".

Unfortunately, the game is really luck based without the drafting variant, but drafting significantly slows down the game. I would play with the drafting anyway, as it's worth the extra time.

Side comment: Truly horrendous graphic design and art direction. Whoever thought "red square on brown background" was a good idea to represent "an opponent loses one production"? The art is a bizarre mishmash of bad photoshops, real pictures, and generic art.

RATING: 8.12
There is a lot to like in this game. Soo many different cards and cool effects. The theme really shines through, and it feels scientific. This is my biggest positive impression of the game and I will always enjoy playing it because of this.

Now I really like this game, but I have some negative points about it I want to state:
- The tile laying part of the game feels underdeveloped (I would have loved if they did something more with this part of the game)
- There is a little to much randomness in the card draw, some people can get lucky and get their production up early, while others will lack behind until the right cards come to them. 
- Because of the point over there can be a runaway leader problem. 
- The engine building in this game tends to be a little slow for my tastes, and the game and go on long with 3-4 people.

I still really enjoy playing this game, even solo! Will be interesting to see what the upcoming expansions will do for the game

RATING: 9
I know this comes with a big board, lots of tiles, and a bunch of plastic cubes but trust me, this is not a Euro game. It lies completely on the card game side of the hobby. Everything you do is based on card interactions and most people play with a drafting variant, that reinforces the CCG/TCG feeling even more. The deck provides an incredible amount of variety, as every single card in the 200+ count deck is unique. They all have very cool effects as well, each feeling both powerful and thematically appropriate to the title and illustrations.

This is one of those games that just make you feel smarter playing it, which is why I think so many people love it. The board and tile placement rules are fairly constricting, so I wonder if it will still have legs after a dozen or so plays, but for now...it is certainly one of the year's best.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Solo play is poor. You necessarily miss out on much of the game, and to win you must ignore even more of it. Maybe worth a couple plays to figure it out.

It doesn't work particularly well at two, either. The take-that cards, which are unfortunately needed for balance, are much less reliable with only one target. The board is too large. And the last few rounds are clumsy and anti-climactic, both because there are only two players responsible for all three terraforming goals and for how unwieldy the tableaus can get.

In general, the game feels under-developed. Some synergies are better than others, with many victory point engines falling short even with the larger number of turns in a two player game. There are many dead draws throughout the game. Key strategies and effects are often represented by only a few cards making them unreliable, which is made worse by the limited card draw effects. There are not enough counters to plant production. I would have much preferred additional ways to generate oxygen to the anti-plant take-that cards.

Still oddly compelling. The award mechanic is excellent. And while the components were terrible, I very much enjoyed the theme. A game I kept wanting to play despite its flaws. Although I can see that changing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Interesting game. Love the huge variety of cards. Sure, there's a lot of minor variations on a theme, but I love that everything has its own wrinkle. Overlays seem like a nice idea given the slipperiness of the mats, but it's already expensive. (I opted for the boardgameboost overlays on etsy; indulgent but they seem nice.)

My biggest concern is how much luck is present. You have to make some bets, and even if the odds are good, they can fail to pay off. Or you can get massive windfalls, just whim of the deck. I don't think the draft is the right solution (so slow/tedious), but rather the cards should have been staged (2, maybe 3 tiers). In a game with such obvious feedback loops, fast starts are a little too key.

Still, really cool game, great variety of play, and what a fantastic and well-implemented theme.

RATING: 8
Great game, a number of different pathways to victory. It's an interesting combination of competitive and cooperative play (you all work together to make Mars habitable, but are also trying to outmanoeuvre each other with your engine building and planetary development). To those critical of the game taking way too long to play, you may have made the mistake the we did (apparently its fairly common), ensure you are facilitating the 'generations' properly, you don't just get 1-2 actions each turn, in succession you keep taking 1-2 actions until everyone has passed (makes a HUGE difference). On the downside the player mats (and board) are pretty flimsy and the marker tokens can be easily bumped around (potentially causing issues deeper into the game when its tough to remember where everything was). Would happily pay for a pricer edition aimed at a higher quality product (firmer player boards with ridged trenching for markers would be great). The variety of cards is compelling, but as some have pointed out, it can take a few plays to figure out how they connect and draft, and some seem a little overpowered.

Would recommend utilizing the 'draft' option with cards, otherwise you can (and will) find yourself benefitting from, or falling victim the luck factor with some receiving too many over-powered cards which can unbalance things.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
There is some fun combos and engine building here, but the game is very long and totally solitaire, except for the tacked on milestones and awards, and the agressive cards, and some passive-agressive plays on the map. So it's not solitaire then? Yes it is, you will look up once every 20 minutes from your way too big tableau of cards and curse at your mean opponents whose birds ate your plants. Every time I play a game like this I feel like the designer just didn't give a shit. This is my gut feeling, not an objective assessment mind you. Agression just feels easy to design. RATING: 8

[b]/update, January 2018:[/b] Downgraded from 9 to 8. It's just too long for what it is, Race for the Galaxy offers even deeper engine building experience in 30 minutes so it's hard for me to get Terraforming Mars to the table these days - there's always something else to play when I have 2+ hours. Don't get me wrong, I still think it's a very good game and I enjoy playing it, but when I play something that long I need a game that offers a bit more player interaction to keep me involved throughout the entire thing.

RATING: 7
I've only played the game once, so consider this a first impression. First, let's talk about the good. Mechanically, this game is a finished product and fun to play. The replayability is very high, because you start each game with a different company and with different cards, which push your strategy towards a certain direction in the beginning. The box itself is very thin and fragile, and people are saying 90% of the inlays are torn upon opening the box. The resource cubes have a thin metallic coating which wears down after just one or two plays (especially the smallest, bronze cubes). Not what you'd expect from Stronghold Games and from such an expensive game. Before considering to purchase it, I will wait for a possible second edition with components that are up to standard.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like this game but it has its issues. 

The game is unique and plays differently owing to the plethora of cards. How they come out affects how one's attempt to transform Mars occurs. 

The placement of city tiles if you can get them out, as well as greenery tiles is important. Placing near the water reservoirs is important for extra Mega Credits, but is not necessary. I would say that the right hand of the board should maybe have a little more water. I saw someone rack up lots of points by starting a greenery area away from water and expanding from there. If I were to tinker with this game, I' might have the players designate the areas where water might be placed. 

The Milestones and Awards are cool ways to win victory points and I like the three out of five limit. They are not to be ignored. The game really seems to pick up speed as it progresses and one develops their company's strengths/strategy. 

The game could use a little more interaction between players. To note, one player said to me during the game he felt as if you are playing against yourself. There are some cards that allow this, but they are mostly cards which have you screw over the other players. This does not bother me. There probably should be  more cutthroatness in this game. The research phase where you draw cards has an advanced rule for passing cards to other players, but this is really the only other interaction. While this prevents the game from being a 9, it does not take away from the game too much. The reason why the lack of interaction does not kill the game is due to the fact that a player spends much of their time focusing on what they are going to do and what their opponents are doing themselves. Therefore, the down time is not too great/long if other players know how the game works. 

Nonetheless, more player interaction would have made this game stellar. Maybe they can create an add on to this game and tinker with the rules to include more interactivity to make it Advanced Terraforming Mars. A gambling mechanic for earth investment to gain more Megacredits, stealing cards, an industrial sabotage feature, or a mechanic to bid or block hostile takeovers of owner tiles or empty tiles on the board, in order to represent company risk reward efforts, so as to increase player interaction would be a cool feature, The danger with this suggestion might be that it would affect the balance of the game which is quite good as it is. It might be too late to make any changes. 

After more playing I 'd like to offer an observation here concerning teaching the game as well as finding people who will enjoy the game. The game is about the cards. You must play this game with someone who can focus on the cards. Too many times people do not read the cards carefully and they struggle because for some reason or another they cannot concentrate on the cards. One person I played with did not like the game because he struggled with interpreting the cards and their tags which was clearly explained to him. Another player, I played with took to the game with ease, never needing explanation owing to the fact that eh too the time to read each one. So my observation is that you must play with people who are willing to concentrate.

One other note I have after several plays now is that this game is very fiddly on the player board. Keeping the cubes in line on your production track is a little tricky as moving cube resources to and from the bank. For instance, because I knocked my player board my electricity production went down. I thought I had two electricity but had only one marked. I could not remember if I had two or one. It was not until I remembered that I paid to raise my electricity one step during a standard action that I reminded my other players that is occurred. Same thing happened with my Mega Credits as well. I had 10 + MC, but knocked my board and could not remember if I had 7, 8, or 9. The player boards could use an upgrade so that they are dishes for the production tiles or cut out holes for cubes to be inserted into for player production. I realize that this would be a costly addition, but since they already have fancy cubes and the fact that this game could have been a near 10, the extra cost would have been worth it in my opinion. As the saying goes, you get what you pay for.

This makes the game a 7.5, but not quite the epic 9 or 10. After two plays my other friend said it dropped down for him from an 8.5 to a 7.5. I concur with him after even another play. To me it is getting way more hype than it deserves, but oh watch out if you criticize it among its devotees. I will never put up a review again.

RATING: 6.5
I love the theme and resource engine building of Terraforming Mars.  I didn't like how dependent everything is on that very random card deck.  If you are lucky you form a long term strategy and the cards you draw support it.  If you are not you can end up buying a lot of useless cards while you try to change tack to follow whatever strategies the cards give you.  I enjoyed it enough to play again if offered, and would like to try it with a card draft to see if that helps mitigate the card draw luck a little... but there are other games in this weight class with more control that I prefer.

RATING: 10
OK. I've now played this at least 15 times with 3 different groups. It is an unbelievably fantastic game. The last game our groups played this many times in this short a time period was Pandemic Legacy: Season 1! 

Two of us have now ordered our own copies both to save our friend's copy but also because we're now curious about solo play. 

We've played it with 3, 4 and 5 and it works great at each. It takes 3-3.5 hours to play, but the time just sails by. No complaints.

--------

Played it twice on Monday. Excellent game. Looking forward to playing it again. Both games were utterly different, which totally surprised us. We played 3 player and all of us agreed 3 player may be the sweet spot. We've put this onto our "3 player game" list.

The only downside is the component quality. The player boards were flimsy so I laminated them. And we only had 2 sets of the player aids, which is weird to us as why not have 5 and why not on a single sheet instead of 4 cards? Just weird.

I can see why people are hoping for an updated edition with better player cards, etc. However, we all liked the art on the cards. We'd definitely leave that alone.

RATING: 9
Terraforming Mars is seriously one of the best games I've played. It's certainly not my favorite, but I think that it's quite an interesting game. It's slightly advanced for novice gamers, but for someone like me who's more advanced, it's a breeze and always fun to play. One of the best aspects of the game is that you can play it either solitaire or collaborate with multiple players. Although when you play with more than one person you collaborate throughout the game with them, you have to keep in mind that scoring in the end will determine a winner, therefore your greatest allies can also be your greatest opponents. Great game, y'all should definitely check it out.

RATING: 6
An ok game but it left me feeling : is this all there is to it? It has one half with a very simple card mechanism and another half with tactically putting tiles down. 
Luck in getting the right cards in your hand made it feel rather railroaded. Though this might be partially solved by drafting. 
I found the strategies to be very one sided, while the choices are more tactical. Either you get a chain of the right cards during research or you don't and play laying the tiles and pay hard cash to do that. 

Card design is very one sided too. Most cards are just one effect green cards. The red cards while having a big one time bonus, feel very weak when targeting other players and they seem to target plants in particular. Very weak interactive elements. Blue cards with a recurring action are the most interesting though the actions are mostly bland. 

Also every card only exists once in the game, this leads to more randomness. 

We found a 'problem' with the heat VP goal, where if one choses it early , other players will stock up on it too, not helping to raise temperature. 
 
Very expensive game with components that aren't of great quality. Aweful resource board and cubes show wear quickly. 

The solo game is really boring. Lacks human opponents that block you with tiles and doesn't have the tension from the race for achievements and VP goals. 

Yet, great and awesome theme and game translates this rather well because you can easily imagine what's happening by what's on the cards. (The artwork looks a clumsy and awkward though). Thematically it is still very weird to have researched something that other players can then never use.

RATING: 8
This game is great for what it is. As a tableau building game it has more player interaction than most, and it is not all interaction by dick moves. To be sure, dick moves are there, but there is also competition for awards and achievements and tactical placing of tiles to block opponents or gain points from opponent's tiles. In closing, if you are looking to buy a Stronghold game buy Great Western Trail first, then buy this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great theme, it's fun to build your little terraforming enterprise. Basic game is a viable way to play, it's quicker and gets going faster. Corporate game seems to have swingier luck, with significantly more cards in the deck. You are often at the mercy of the cards you draw. Often it's a matter of getting a certain critical mass of cards that combo well, or getting the right cards at the right time. The deck is huge, so randomness will play a part.

UPDATE: 25 plays as of writing this; it's a popular one, stirs the imagination (especially if you like science-y things) and the cards you look at are always suggesting various plays and plans. Definitely play with the optional drafting rules, since it evens things out for some corporations/strategies that require seeing particular types of cards, and moderates the luck factor.

I liked the expansion maps for the new milestones and awards, and Venus Next adds some variation but nothing huge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My personal Game of 2016. Players control corporations (each with a unique ability) seeking a hand in the terraforming of the Red Planet. Using cards hat represent events, technologies and buildings, as well as a range of "Standard Projects" available to all players, each person must increase the oxygen and water levels and raise the average temperature.

Theme: Sci-fi, planetary terraforming
Mechanic: Card play / Tile placement
Ideal Players: 1-5
Length: Long
